headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Kimco Realty Corp. Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Bujnicki, Vice Preside
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Kimco Realty Corp. Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this event is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Bujnicki, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning. And I thank you, all, for joining Kimco's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning are Milton Cooper, our Executive Chairman; Conor Flynn, Chief Executive Officer; Glenn Cohen, our CFO; as well as
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning. And I thank you, all, for joining Kimco's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning are Milton Cooper, our Executive Chairman; Conor Flynn, Chief Executive Officer; Glenn Cohen, our CFO; as well as other key executives who will be available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking. And it's important to note at the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors.
During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures are available on our website. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. First, I would like to thank Milton and the board for giving me the opportunity to lead this incredible company. At our recent Investor Day, we laid our 2020 vision, underscoring the work we've done over the last several years to position Ki
componenttext:
Good morning. First, I would like to thank Milton and the board for giving me the opportunity to lead this incredible company. At our recent Investor Day, we laid our 2020 vision, underscoring the work we've done over the last several years to position Kimco to take full advantage of the evolving landscape for retail and become a leader in our industry. Our team has executed over the past few years dramatically transforming the portfolio from a scattered collection of assets across the U.S., Mexico, South America and Canada to now a tightly concentrated footprint of high-quality asset clusters in the major metro markets in the U.S., where we see the highest growth potential.
The top U.S. markets showcased the highest growth in population, household income, education, both significant barriers to entry and present the most potential to add value for our shareholders. All of our resources are now laser focused on what we do best, owning, managing, leasing and redeveloping assets here in the U.S. to drive net asset value. Our portfolio has 2 distinct advantages. First, we have a 37% mark-to-market opportunity that is unmatched due to the low in place average base rent and the spread to market that we can unlock by recapturing and repurposing assets to meet that need of today's shopper. Second, we have more raw material to work with, the large collection of assets we own provide numerous redevelopment opportunities to adding grocery components to overpower centers and adding technology to extend the hours of our shopping centers to fulfill the everyday needs of our shoppers 24/7.
Our 2020 vision provides the roadmap for how we plan to take the company to new heights in the next 5 years. The 3 main pillars of our strategy are simple. First, it starts with management. We have to continue to motivate and empower the best talent in the industry and create a vibrant and rewarding place to work. Second, the balance sheet. We have to be of capital by keeping watchful eye on our cost of capital, so we can invest wisely and position the balance sheet to whether any storm. Finally, a major focus on NAV per share growth and the major metro markets in the U.S. Asset values are close to peak or even above prior peak pricing, as a healthy balance in supply and demand continues for open-air centers. We believe the best use of our capital is to take full advantage of that demand and redevelop our assets to drive outsized growth by leaning on a tremendous team, fulfilling our redevelopment opportunities and executing on our select strategic developments.
We have planted the seeds to and redevelopment and development to bring to life assets that will significantly enhance the value and quality of our overall portfolio. We will continue to remain disciplined, pre-leasing, phasing and ground leasing are just a few of our risk management tools that are in place to analyze each and every investment opportunity versus our cost of capital and to ensure we generate the highest return for our shareholders. The future is bright, and we're passionate about delivering for our shareholders. 
Turning to our results for the fourth quarter and the full year, I will give a brief overview of our portfolio metrics, a quick update on acquisitions and dispositions, followed by an update on redevelopments. U.S. occupancy at the end of 2015 was 95.8%, up 20 basis points from last quarter and 10 basis points from the beginning of the year, driven in large part by the small shop recovery. Small shop occupancy is 88.7%, up 70 basis points from last quarter and for the beginning of the year. U.S. leasing spreads continue to display of the mark-to-market opportunity at Kimco, with an impressive 31% on new leases and a combined missing spread 13.1% in the fourth quarter, the highest combined spread in almost 3 years. U.S. same-site NOI growth was 2.8% for the quarter, primarily driven by minimum rent increase and a 20 basis points basis point in positive impact from the development. 
For the full year, you a same-site NOI growth is 3.1%, including a 50 basis point negative impact from bankruptcies experienced over the year.
The average base rent for the U.S. portfolio continues to improve with 5.2% gain from the prior year end. Competition continues to be fierce in our top markets of acquisition, with some staggering cap rates recently reported in areas of California. This bodes well for the NAV of our holdings in California, which is our largest state by NOI contribution and continues to direct us to deploy capital towards redevelopment of our existing assets versus acquiring in the open market. 
For the year, our total gross acquisition of $2.1 billion is heavily weighted towards the purchase of our joint venture interest in 57 assets. In contrast, only 2 assets were acquired in the open market for a purchase price of $155 million. Disposition market remains healthy, as we completed a total gross disposition value of $2.2 billion for the year. We completed the exit from Mexico is out of America and announced the closing of the JV transaction in Canada, that will pave the way to achieving our goal of simplifying the company to be strictly U.S. focused by year end.
In the U.S., we completed the sale of 95 properties in 2015, for a gross price of $762 million, at the blended 6.9% cap rate. Pricing expectations for our disposition have not changed, as you continue to see the demand for high-quality anchor open-air shopping centers. Our redevelopment program remain the focal point of our strategy. For the year, we projected $189 million of projects, delivering a 10.6% incremental return. We're pleased to announce that due to some cost savings we came in under-budget on cost of $184 million and above budget on NOI, improving the incremental returns to 11.3% for the year. Perhaps the most exciting redevelopment completion this quarter is opening in our flagship Long Island assets Airport Plaza and Farmingdale. Early indications from students and shoppers are incredible and from the video footage of the parking lot, we think the benefit of this grocery addition to an existing power center will create a significant NAV and same-site NOI improvement for years to come.
In Florida, we also had successful openings for public at our redevelopment and redevelopment on Orlando. we signed new leases with Joe's, one in California and one in Washington. The tremendous grocery additions improve the percentage of ABR from grocery anchored centers to 72%, up from 65% at prior year end.
To be the best, we continue to question the status quo and take a deep dive into every aspect of our operations to help drive results. Open-air retail continues to evolve and embrace omni-channel, as a physical store has proven to be a driver of online sales. Our retailers know their customer better than anyone inside their 4 walls, and our job is to more people to the shopping center and get those consumers to come back time and time again. The open-air retail landscape is healthy, as limited new supply is forecasted and our strongest retailers continue to grow store count. The shadow supply from potential closings or consolidating retailers and future developments supply is what we are monitoring closely. 
Looking ahead, we are starting to see the activity pick up in every category size. Big-box retailers are back looking for space. Junior box players continue to be most aggressive. Traditional and specialty groceries are active and our small shop leasing indicates a healthy trajectory. All of these ingredients indicate we are well-positioned to unlock the value of our real estate for our shareholders.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Glen to revise more granularity on our results.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor, and congratulations on your appointment to CEO. It's going to be a fun go for us all. Good morning to everyone. We finished 2015 with a solid fourth quarter, delivering strong results for the full year, while furthering our transformation
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor, and congratulations on your appointment to CEO. It's going to be a fun go for us all. Good morning to everyone. 
We finished 2015 with a solid fourth quarter, delivering strong results for the full year, while furthering our transformation and simplification efforts. We successfully executed on our TSR strategy plus and delivered a total shareholder return of 9.4% in 2015, in very tough environmental market. In December, we unveiled our 2020 vision at our Investor Day, focusing on owning and operating fine quality U.S. properties in the major metro markets, where we have deep concentration. We also continue to execute on our redevelopment pipeline and select roundup development projects. Our 2020 vision includes operating in a more conservative capital structure, with plenty of liquidity and even stronger debt metrics than today. Finally, as an added benefit, we have the upside potential for PLUS business, position is clear, the team is focused and aligned. 
Now for some details on our fourth quarter and full year results and further call regarding our 2016 earnings guidance. Our FFO is adjusted per-share or recurring FFO, which excludes nonoperating impairments and transactional income and expense was $0.37 for the fourth quarter, an increase of 5.7% compared to last year's $0.35. The increase was driven by NOI from the operating portfolio of $24.8 million, offset by $4.4 million of decreased management fees related to the significant reduction in joint ventures and higher G&A associated with severance charges, attributable to our anticipated exit of Canada. In addition, interest expense was higher by $5.6 million, primarily from the debt assumptions related to the Kimstone acquisition earlier in the year, the recent JV buyouts of and and the acquisition of property impairments.
Our full year 2015 FFO adjusted per share came in at $1.46, achieving the high-end of our revised guidance range and $0.06 above last year's results for $1.40, a 4.3% increase. Headline FFO per share representing the official was $0.35 for the fourth quarter, in line with first call consensus estimates. Headline FFO per share was $0.02 lower than FFO is adjusted, primarily related to the $5.8 million noncash charge for the redemption of our $175 million, 6.9% series H preferred stock redemption during the quarter and the acquisition of related costs. Our full year 2015 headline FFO per share came in at $1.56, achieving the upper end of our guidance range and a $0.01 ahead of first call consensus. Our 2015 results were $0.11 higher than the 2014 amount of $1.45 per share, a 7.6% increase. The primary drivers of the headline per share increase are the $0.06 increase in recurring FFO and the gain on sale of our SUPERVALU stock investment, which contributed 40 million or $0.10 per share. Acquisition cost and nonoperating impairments offset these increases. As Conor just articulated, the operating portfolio delivered solid results with improved occupancy, a 23rd contributive quarter of delivering positive U.S. same-site NOI growth and double-digit leasing spreads. 
Ross Cooper and his team are very active during the quarter on the disposition for rent. We completed the sale-of-interest in 64 U.S. properties, 23 Canadian properties and our last asset in South America generating proceeds of approximately $600 million, which we used to fund $175 million of mission of preferred stock, pay down debt and fund the acquisitions. We remain focused and committed to operate with a strong capital structure. We finished the fourth quarter with consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA of 6x, the high-end of our 5.5 to 6x range, down from the 6.6x at end of the fourth quarter after acquiring $1.4 billion Kimstone portfolio.
We achieved this level even with the redemption of the preferred stock which had a 0.2x impact on the metric. As part of our 2020 vision, overtime, we plan to reduce the consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA to a range of 5 to 5.5x and on look-through basis, including pro-rata JV debt and preferred stock to a range of 6.4 to 6.9x, with a fixed charge coverage of 3x plus. 
During the fourth quarter, we capped the bond market issuing a $500 million 7-year 3.4% fixed-rate bond. Our liquidity position is in excellent shape, ending the year with 0 outstanding on our $1.75 billion revolving credit facility and over $180 million in cash. We have already begun to address our 2016 maturities, both consolidated and in our JVs, which are anticipated to be funded from sales proceeds, the unsecured bank and bond markets and mortgage financings, all at lower coupons than the maturing debts.
We are reaffirming our guidance for 2016, which was provided at our Investor Day in December. Our FFO is adjusted or recurring FFO per share range is $1.48 to $1.52 and our headline FFO per share range is $1.54 to $1.62. The guidance range takes into account the significant level of dispositions throughout 2015, and the accelerated exit of Canada during 2016, which had a combined impact of $0.06 to $0.07 per share on the 2016 growth expectations. We anticipate that by the end of 2016, we will be a purely U.S. owner and operator with assets concentrated in our key metro markets. The transactional expense and income included in the headline guidance range, but not in acquiring range, is primarily comprised of acquisition costs and the commencement of modified investments, assess the transactional income portion is heavily weighted towards the fourth quarter of 2016. The guidance range is sensitive to timing of acquisitions, dispositions, redevelopments coming online, lease-up and financing initiatives. Our 2016 plans supports our recently increased common dividend level of $0.255 per quarter, which equates to an FFO payout ratio in the upper 60% range. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glen. Kimco is back to basics. The company focus on property advantages in the United States. It took a tremendous effort by our exceptional team to execute on all the transactions last year. In 2015, we reduced our foreign investments by $1.5 b
componenttext:
Thanks, Glen. 
Kimco is back to basics. The company focus on property advantages in the United States. It took a tremendous effort by our exceptional team to execute on all the transactions last year. In 2015, we reduced our foreign investments by $1.5 billion, of which $749 million was our share and we reduced the number of size and joint ventures by another 43%, a 65% decrease since 2010. Now a portfolio is much more streamlined, predominantly self-managed, located in the United States, with 564 properties in all the major markets. We look forward for the opportunities in the years ahead. There are some very exciting redevelopments and developments that our team is working on. We're committed to unlocking the value in our current portfolio and to grow the NAV for our shareholders. And now, we'd be delighted to take any questions.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

Can you just remind us where you are in the sales process remaining 35 assets? What portion of the $900 million of dispositions guidance is And then what cap rates you expect on those assets relative to the real deal?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Christy, it's Ross Cooper. In Canada as of now, we have 25 assets out of 35 that are under contract to be sold. We expect that to happen in next 2 to 3 months, ending the outcome of some of the due diligence that's still remaining. And at that point i
componenttext: Hi, Christy, it's Ross Cooper. In Canada as of now, we have 25 assets out of 35 that are under contract to be sold. We expect that to happen in next 2 to 3 months, ending the outcome of some of the due diligence that's still remaining. And at that point in time, we will be approximately 86% completed from an NOI standpoint. So we feel really good about the pace at which it's going. The pricing is very consistent with where we were on the other assets, so we don't feel that the quality is necessarily lower. And we are in the low 6 cap rate range on those assets as well. The remaining assets to that point in time we're still working on, getting into the marketplace, doing a little bit of lease up in some scenarios. But as Glen mentioned, we're very much on track to be completely out by the end of the year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. It's Conor. That's development pressure, the stabilization dates haven't changed, more the completion dates. So that was comprised between the 2 actually accosted lowered little bit there, so we should see that completed this year and third q
componenttext:
Sure, Craig. It's Conor. That's development pressure, the stabilization dates haven't changed, more the completion dates. So that was comprised between the 2 actually accosted lowered little bit there, so we should see that completed this year and third quarter. Christiana, that site plan has actually changed, you see that the cost came down quite a bit. Regionally, we had thought we were going to be developing a power center with junior box lineups, our large big-box anchor has significant interest now. So we've redesigned the site plan to ground these and get quite a bit of contribution from that tenant for the redesign of the site plan. So that's really what changed that site plan there.
Grand Parkway, we're finalizing the anchor lease there that we should be announcing shortly, but we have to cross the finish line, so that's really why that was pushed out of the quarter. So those are the big moving pieces there on those assets.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The beauty of Mill, is going to be that's why we bought all the pieces. Mall development is a tricky one, especially if you don't control all the pieces. So what we did was we purchased our partners interest, we purchased the Macy's, we purchased the JCPe
componenttext: The beauty of Mill, is going to be that's why we bought all the pieces. Mall development is a tricky one, especially if you don't control all the pieces. So what we did was we purchased our partners interest, we purchased the Macy's, we purchased the JCPenney, which allows us to really start from scratch and take down the mall. And our design is really for a best-in-class opening a shopping center, which includes big-box retailers, junior anchors, restaurants, you name it. So we actually have 4 different site plans that we're working on right now, that we think all will add significant value and create a lot of our shareholders for long-term.

componenttext: It's on forward-looking statements. I'm just wondering if you can give us maybe a little more color on the sales environment today, ignoring the Canada stuff. Just talk about what you see in terms of investor demand? As the buyer pool maybe the composition of interest to buyers changed in recent months? And is financing at all become an issue for sellers or for buyers and in particular some of the secondary market stuff?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ross again. As you've seen from numbers, we've been executing on our plan of dispositions. We really haven't seen any pushback or fallout of deals that we have in the marketplace. We have already closed on a per shopping Center so far this y
componenttext: Sure. This is Ross again. As you've seen from numbers, we've been executing on our plan of dispositions. We really haven't seen any pushback or fallout of deals that we have in the marketplace. We have already closed on a per shopping Center so far this year. So the pace in that pricing is still very competitive. I think that you are right about the depth of the buyer pool is certainly is our maybe a little bit shallower than it was 6 to 9 months ago. But the groups that are active are still very competitive. We haven't seen financing really become an issue on the deals that we're selling in the secondary markets. And we think that we're going to have a very strong year. In fact, we have some assets on the West Coast that we've sold at very aggressive pricing and when you look at the statistics for our fourth quarter sales, our average cap rate was 6.5%, which was the lowest cap rate that we have had on our dispositions that we have tracked since we have started the transformation. So we continue to seek the cap rates become more aggressive, not less aggressive.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the key markets in California, you've been tracking that, really the cap rates now almost some of them 4 and some of them even 15 and lower. So we are very patient there and clearly, we're not going to win many bidding wars today when those type o
componenttext: Yes, in the key markets in California, you've been tracking that, really the cap rates now almost some of them 4 and some of them even 15 and lower. So we are very patient there and clearly, we're not going to win many bidding wars today when those type of assets come to the market.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one quick one, the shop occupancy it's obviously, steadily moving I and you previously mentioned a goal of getting to 90%. I know it's early in the year, but has the disruption in the market or general nervousness about the economy imp
componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick one, the shop occupancy it's obviously, steadily moving I and you previously mentioned a goal of getting to 90%. I know it's early in the year, but has the disruption in the market or general nervousness about the economy impacted any leasing activity at all or demand for shop space and maybe put that in context of the national franchises versus maybe the mom and pops? Thanks.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. Yes, I think we've seen demand continues to improve for small shops. In our pipeline looking forward to continue to see that improving over the year. It's a nice split between the nationals and the mom and pops. We had 55% of our s
componenttext: That's a good question. Yes, I think we've seen demand continues to improve for small shops. In our pipeline looking forward to continue to see that improving over the year. It's a nice split between the nationals and the mom and pops. We had 55% of our small shops return to mom-and-pop this quarter. So the volatility in the market has not really put a governor on the amount of small shop leasing we're able to do. Our occupancy is going to be driving going forward, so we have been pleasantly surprised with the production there and we will continue to push that going forward.

Right now, we see that there is retailers in all categories, whether it's small shop, midsize, junior boxes or the big-box anchors, they all have been very aggressive in growing store count and that continues to lead to bidding wars which will bid up rest and we continue to see that as an opportunity for us going into this year.

componenttext: Yes. We obviously, monitor our tenants health very much closely. Our watch list haven't really watching same for the long time now, and I think it's relatively healthy, when you look out clearly there might be some consolidation or some fallout in the year. But overall, we think we have us sweet spot on retail. We think prices really becoming the darling in the U.S. that we continue to see huge demand for that type of space. And we think that this year will continue along that path of just being a healthy environment.

componenttext: The Puerto Rico is obviously one we're watching closely. It's relatively small in terms of impact on our whole portfolio. It's little less than 3%. So we watch it closely. We have seen activity on the boxes that we have got and think we will be able to lease those up this year. Clearly the headline, the Puerto Rico there has been some serious issues, but trying to restructure their debt. But the shopper is still vibrant down there. We recently hosted a portfolio tour down there and Glenn, you want to talk a little bit about the traffic you saw.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was pretty amazing. I was down there, Kmart in Puerto Rico, lights are on, the shelves are fully stocked, the couple that we went to registers open with 3 or 4 people in them. And the parking lots are filled with people shopping. The discount appr
componenttext: Yes, it was pretty amazing. I was down there, Kmart in Puerto Rico, lights are on, the shelves are fully stocked, the couple that we went to registers open with 3 or 4 people in them. And the parking lots are filled with people shopping. The discount approach down there works really well. While the economy, the Puerto Rican economy has been recessing for a long time, but it's really a very deep, underground economy there and people just shop. So the properties are very, very successful.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Development, we have seen lot of pullback on their size of pipeline. Just holistically, what you guys seeing that gives you confidence to increase it at this point in time?
componenttext: Development, we have seen lot of pullback on their size of pipeline. Just holistically, what you guys seeing that gives you confidence to increase it at this point in time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, most of our strategic development has story to them. And we feel very confident about why we think it's appropriate to add these to the pipeline. If you go asset-by-asset, they each had a reason why -- right across most successful shopping center in
componenttext: Yes, most of our strategic development has story to them. And we feel very confident about why we think it's appropriate to add these to the pipeline. If you go asset-by-asset, they each had a reason why -- right across most successful shopping center in the state of Florida and the demand has been off-the-charts there. If look at the Christiana, Delaware, its around 95, where we have been working to rezone that from a former warehouse to now retail offering, and it's very next to GDP successful Christiana Mall. So each and every one of these projects have a story to it. And there is not going to be significant development in our pipeline looking out, maybe because the land prices have really skyrocketed. A lot of that's due to the multifamily that we have seen pop-up. But we see the demand from all retailers to want to grow store count in the limited supply. So each of these projects has really -- it's within a key market for us. The demand is there, on the one in Houston obviously, where Houston is going through some headwinds, we still see retailers wanting to be there for the void. Clearly the apartments density -- the density around our Grand Parkway project has been there for a long period of time, and I think the retail is the last sector to really catch up to meet the demand. So we haven't seen any falloff in terms of return or demand there and that will actually be one of our first development of projects and we're cautiously optimistic that it will be a big success.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up on same topic. Could you comment on like some of the retailers that you have as anchors for these developments like sports authority or the Target that wasn't anchored listed at Grand Parkway that's not longer there and supplemental this quarter, just curious if you comment on -- I mean, anchor tenants?

componenttext: I think we've reposted the targets back on the so that was probably just a refresh that you need to do on the supplemental. But yes you mentioned a few times that are on our watch list. Those tenants are obviously ones we're watching very closely and monitoring. We're cautiously optimistic that it's not going to be a liquidation. If and when something happens to those retailers, so we're looking to see where exposure is? How we can limit it? And again, the mark-to-market opportunity that we talked about is really ever measure of safety for me get those boxes back. So we think we're trying to be careful about how we manage risk and those junior boxes, you mentioned are the ones that are always be on the watch list.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then second is for Glen. Glen, in the debt summary, it looks like you guys still 2 Canadian unsecured bonds outstanding, exit from Canada related to year end, it would seem like of a mismatch. So just curious especially with the strength of the U.S. dollar, does it make sense to prepay these or your view is to just leave these outstanding to their natural maturities over the next, I guess, 4 years or so?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is very fair and great question. We're very closely monitoring the progress that we make on the sales, because the bonds serve us on natural hedge. So depending on the timing and the quickness of the sales, we are going to need to evaluate how we're
componenttext: This is very fair and great question. We're very closely monitoring the progress that we make on the sales, because the bonds serve us on natural hedge. So depending on the timing and the quickness of the sales, we are going to need to evaluate how we're going to handle the debt. As long as we need caching, it stays naturally hedged, but it comes to the point where it makes sense to either do currencies swap, for the bonds, make hold the bonds, but it's something that very much on the radar screen that we'll have to address as we go forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Vincent of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Vincent of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go to commentary, based that's been a key's driver for overall. We have been hearing about for long time, how you think about saturation of that concept and maybe if you could comment on what percentage of your centers have some form of off
componenttext: Just wanted to go to commentary, based that's been a key's driver for overall. We have been hearing about for long time, how you think about saturation of that concept and maybe if you could comment on what percentage of your centers have some form of off-price in it, whether or not that's traditional are some of the newer players?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to get back to you on the percentage of total portfolio of an off price component, it would be very high. So we will give you the exact percentage. But on your question on saturation, it's one we watch closely. There is a busy lot of new playe
componenttext: We're going to get back to you on the percentage of total portfolio of an off price component, it would be very high. So we will give you the exact percentage. But on your question on saturation, it's one we watch closely. There is a busy lot of new players in the off-price segment. We love the off-price segment. We think TJX has been the phenomenal performer for many, many years now. And if you look back not too long ago, the market cap of TJX and Roth combined was relatively small compared to some of the mall anchors and if you just compare it today, it's really phenomenal, just the growth that they have achieved. The new players we are watching closely. We want to try and pick best-in-class and have the merchandising mix that enhances the shopping center and the amount of traffic it drives. So we're cautiously optimistic that I think that more competition is good for the off-price sector. We clearly favor the ones that have the proven model business model and we're doing it for many, many years. But going forward, it will be an interesting -- it will be an interesting situation to watch to see who really can capture some of that market share TJX has obviously, such a leap. And now Ross is really ramping up their expansion plans. And then if you look at Nordstorm rack and sort of outfit there is lot of players out there that are really trying to gain market share. So it will be interesting to see how competitive they are.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a quick question on Amazon. We've heard that they started in some location, and I'm just wondering if you have had any discussions with them, whether we expect them to be in centers of future and if anything about their long or medium-term orde
componenttext: I just had a quick question on Amazon. We've heard that they started in some location, and I'm just wondering if you have had any discussions with them, whether we expect them to be in centers of future and if anything about their long or medium-term order plan?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: They have one open location in Seattle. And it's done very well for them. They continue to see that as an opportunity. We talked about opportunities with them. I think they're going to be very selective, very strategic on the store opening plan. And so I
componenttext: They have one open location in Seattle. And it's done very well for them. They continue to see that as an opportunity. We talked about opportunities with them. I think they're going to be very selective, very strategic on the store opening plan. And so I think is going to be more of a measured approach to it rather than a full-blown assault on opening a lot of brick-and-mortar stores. But it's clearly, an indication that a lot of pure e-commerce retailers see the value of opening physical stores, which is a real boost for our sector, because there is tethering effect and you see it from a lot of our retailers will come out and display the amount of online sales that's going to opening a new physical location. But also the amount they lose when they close a physical location in terms of the online sales. So it's interesting to watch and Amazon has largest. This has really been a good sign for us in the long haul.

componenttext: Yes, it's both actually. They are looking to try and enter some of our developments as well as new developments. It's nice because, lot of the times when we were looking at most active players, it was the junior boxes. So they were the ones most aggressive on redevelopments as well as the ground up developments we have in our pipeline. And it's nice to see now that the big-box anchors are coming back and looking to grow store count. And again, it's in select locations, where they see opportunity this might be a void for them. But again must merchandisers have been missing for a while in terms of activity, so it's nice to see them back looking for stores.

componenttext: Conor, just to kind of follow-up in terms of the demand side of the equation. There has been a lot of pressure reports recently about some of the major as well as some new grocers expanding into Mid-Atlantic market. and so forth, and just curious whether that's showing up? When you're talking about demand for boxes, I'm assuming you're talking about big-boxes as opposed to grocers, but you might be talking about both. So are we looking at, I don't want to say EBITDA a really strong demand into Mid-Atlantic as a result of those trends? And as a part of that, can you just interest whether they're going into centers, are they looking at freestanding locations?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you're spot on. My comments earlier, very targeted towards big-box players. But you're right on when you talk about the grocery competition in the mid-Atlantic is going to be fierce with all those new entrants into that market. And you're right, it's
componenttext: No, you're spot on. My comments earlier, very targeted towards big-box players. But you're right on when you talk about the grocery competition in the mid-Atlantic is going to be fierce with all those new entrants into that market. And you're right, it's going to be a bidding war. It's going to be interesting to see whole shakes out in terms of winners and losers. But there is going to be a plenty of aggressive entrants into that market in the Mid-Atlantic and you named pretty much the majors that are all coming in So on your question on its an interesting 1. We met with them and talk to them about their plans, most of their plans are self-development. So they actually looking to self-developed standalone grocery stores, where they can be competitors to the traditional grocery stores at a lower price point. So most of what they have been doing is up land and looking to self-develop. So they haven't little bit of different apostolate then say traditional grocery was looking to lease space. That being said, though, there is plenty of bidding going on for a opportunity there. But it's already a very tight market, so it's very difficult to penetrate.

componenttext: And if I could just follow up, in terms of Albertsons and West Coast, with Albertsons buying back some of their stores and its domination in many of the Southwest market is I guess is increased. With respect to the IPO, the S1 remains updated on the third quarter, and the fourth quarter for Albertsons, and I think February 22, 23, so market positions improve, after the fourth quarter, we'll revisit the opportunity the public markets.

componenttext: Conor, any color on the expected yields that the new projects in Owings Mills and Pentagon or more broadly if I look at the active development page and added Pentagon, what's the expected weighted-average yields on these projects?

componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. We are targeting between 7.5 to 8.5, that's really where the expected yields are for the entire portfolio of redevelopment and development projects. So obviously, Owings Mill is just a recent combination of acquisitions there, so we have a few different pipelines depending on the best return, which when we will go with. Pentagon is obviously, the apartment forward that we talked about and 25,000 square feet of new retail there. So the ROI is going to be little lower there, because of the apartments, but the spreads from the cap rate is still well over 200 basis points. So we feel like we have a manageable pipeline that really will deliver significant NAV for the company going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: I guess, two questions. Number one, I guess, maybe Glenn in terms of guidance 2.5 to 3.5 for same-store, I'm just trying to think what you've sort of incorporated in terms of bankruptcies and down time I guess you had some of those in '15 result. I'm just trying to figure out, how conservative you might have been or where do that figure is in relation to where you started the year-ago?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you think about the initial guidance that they put out last year. We're in this 3 to 3.5 range. We brought to the whole year, we came in at 3.1. And as Conor mentioned, and as really us about 50 basis points. So we would have achieved the
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you think about the initial guidance that they put out last year. We're in this 3 to 3.5 range. We brought to the whole year, we came in at 3.1. And as Conor mentioned, and as really us about 50 basis points. So we would have achieved the high end of the range, that just happened. The guidance range does incorporate a modest amount, not a lot of bankruptcies, so if you get to the midpoint, we think there should be a very, very modest amount. If there is a large-scale bankruptcy, probably we have a new and you probably want us towards the lower end of the range, it's stable and lease-up where we think we can get to the mid-to upper end of the range.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And just I guess, kind of follow up on the Albertsons question. To have the IPO and then start to monetize that NU some of that cash to fund. To the extent that the IPO either apposite in the year or maybe doesn't happen at all for the market conditions, just how do you think about your needs of cash and how do you supplement that?

componenttextpreview: On a relative basis, it's fairly modest. Once it's baked into guidance from a cash standpoint, somewhere between $50 million and $100 million stuff late in the year. So for a 2016 impact, it's fairly modest. And they can be supplemented in many different
componenttext: On a relative basis, it's fairly modest. Once it's baked into guidance from a cash standpoint, somewhere between $50 million and $100 million stuff late in the year. So for a 2016 impact, it's fairly modest. And they can be supplemented in many different ways and you might have a little bit more debt. Our treasured the high end of $100 million, it's about net debt-to-EBITDA and we are that supplemented. So in the scheme of things, if he didn't go, we would obviously, have to deal with our headline guidance, because it's baked into that. But other than that, if our current flows there and it's modest to the capital plan.

componenttextpreview: Well, everything that we have sold we actually repatriated so far. So far, so the remaining assets that we will need to sell because they will match up against the Canadian bonds that are outstanding, so we're not going to be repatriating that cash. Balan
componenttext: Well, everything that we have sold we actually repatriated so far. So far, so the remaining assets that we will need to sell because they will match up against the Canadian bonds that are outstanding, so we're not going to be repatriating that cash. Balances with the debt, keep the natural hedge in place.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason White of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason White of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. Same topic, as you look at market rents last year versus this year, what kind of market rent growth your seeing, not re-leasing spread but your on the ground market rent growth?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. Same topic, as you look at market rents last year versus this year, what kind of market rent growth your seeing, not re-leasing spread but your on the ground market rent growth?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Market rent really depends on location and obviously the strength of the site, the surrounding demographics, but the market rents in the top markets continued to pick up nicely. It is a function of supply and demand and we continue to see pretty strong le
componenttext: Market rent really depends on location and obviously the strength of the site, the surrounding demographics, but the market rents in the top markets continued to pick up nicely. It is a function of supply and demand and we continue to see pretty strong leasing spreads. But if you look at the pure tick up in market rents, it's at the high-end of our range where we expected to be and continue to see it improve, as retailers really have focused on making sure to try to penetrate these markets, but also not close stores. I think that's more of a critical component to it retailers that are coming due for renewals are worried about losing store count in the tough markets, where they have significant market share. So you'll probably see the renewal spread actually pick up a little bit this year, as those leases come up for real.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you look at sales growth by tenants and kind of low single digits and e-commerce takes slice of those tenants that you have e-commerce exposure or maybe they even have their own omni-channel presence, where brick-and-mortar really being kind of being l
componenttext: As you look at sales growth by tenants and kind of low single digits and e-commerce takes slice of those tenants that you have e-commerce exposure or maybe they even have their own omni-channel presence, where brick-and-mortar really being kind of being low single-digit sales growth environment, how long can market rent growth continue to outpace that and get OCR's probably increasing higher than potentially long-term averages would assume is correct?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. It's one that I think retailers look at your occupancy cost. They really have be mindful of sales growth as well as how much rent they can pay. The nice thing about our sector is we have some of the lowest occupancy cost across any s
componenttext: It's a good question. It's one that I think retailers look at your occupancy cost. They really have be mindful of sales growth as well as how much rent they can pay. The nice thing about our sector is we have some of the lowest occupancy cost across any sector of REITs. So we think we have significant pricing power still left to go. And it really helps by being in the best markets and having the best assets. Those are was that are very difficult to come by, so retailers don't necessarily want to lose those store count either. So it's one that we think still have a long runway to go. And again, I think that and as long as supply and demand remains in check, we're in good shape there.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our portfolio is a little bit different, because it's older. We have, so many leases that are well below market. So even though you might not have to amount of rent growth per se relative to where leases are today, leases that are 10, 20 years old, you st
componenttext: Our portfolio is a little bit different, because it's older. We have, so many leases that are well below market. So even though you might not have to amount of rent growth per se relative to where leases are today, leases that are 10, 20 years old, you still have a lot of upside when you bring those to market.

componenttext: Yes, the Anna's Linens boxes, we had 21 leases. We have 3 fully secluded leases the deposit 33% spread. I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Bujnicki, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning. And I thank you, all, for joining Kimco's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning are Milton Cooper, our Executive Chairman; Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; Glenn Cohen, our CF
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning. And I thank you, all, for joining Kimco's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning are Milton Cooper, our Executive Chairman; Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; Glenn Cohen, our CFO; as well as other key executives who will be available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking. And it's important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors.
During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures are available on our website. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. First, I'd like to thank Milton and the board for giving me the opportunity to lead this incredible company. At our recent Investor Day, we laid our 2020 vision, underscoring the work we've done over the last several years to position Kimco
componenttext:
Good morning. First, I'd like to thank Milton and the board for giving me the opportunity to lead this incredible company. At our recent Investor Day, we laid our 2020 vision, underscoring the work we've done over the last several years to position Kimco to take full advantage of the evolving landscape of open-air retail and become a leader in our industry. Our team has executed over the past few years dramatically transforming the portfolio from a scattered collection of assets across the U.S., Mexico, South America and Canada to now a tightly concentrated footprint of high-quality asset clusters in the major metro markets in the U.S., where we see the highest growth potential.
The top U.S. markets showcased the highest growth in population, household income, education, both significant barriers to entry and present the most potential to add value for our shareholders. All of our resources are now laser focused on what we do best, owning, managing, leasing and redeveloping assets here in the U.S. to drive net asset value. Our portfolio has 2 distinct advantages: First, we have a 37% mark-to-market opportunity that is unmatched due to the low in place average base rent and the spread to market that we can unlock by recapturing and repurposing assets to meet the need of today's shopper; second, we have more raw material to work with. The large collection of assets we own provides numerous redevelopment opportunities through densification, adding grocery components to our power centers and adding technology to extend the hours of our shopping centers to fulfill the everyday needs of our shoppers, 24/7.
Our 2020 vision provides the roadmap for how we plan to take the company to new heights in the next 5 years. The 3 main pillars of our strategy are simple. First, it starts with management. We have to continue to motivate and empower the best talent in the industry and create a vibrant and rewarding place to work. Second, the balance sheet. We have to be stewards of capital by keeping a watchful eye on our cost of capital, so we can invest wisely and position the balance sheet to weather any storm. Finally, a major focus on NAV per share growth. In the major metro markets in the U.S., asset values are close to peak or even above prior peak pricing, as a healthy balance in supply and demand continues for open-air centers. We believe the best use of our capital is to take full advantage of that demand and redevelop our assets to drive outsized growth by leaning on a tremendous team, fulfilling our redevelopment opportunities and executing on our select strategic developments.
We have planted the seeds to redevelopment and development to bring to life assets that will significantly enhance the value and quality of our overall portfolio. We will continue to remain disciplined. Pre-leasing, phasing and ground leasing are just a few of our risk management tools that are in place to analyze each and every investment opportunity versus our cost of capital and to ensure we generate the highest returns for our shareholders. The future is bright, and we're passionate about delivering for our shareholders. 
Turning to our results for the fourth quarter and the full year, I will give a brief overview of our portfolio metrics, a quick update on acquisitions and dispositions, followed by an update on redevelopments. U.S. occupancy at the end of 2015 was 95.8%, up 20 basis points from last quarter and 10 basis points from the beginning of the year, driven in large part by the small shop recovery. Small shop occupancy is 88.7%, up 70 basis points from last quarter and for the beginning of the year. U.S. leasing spreads continue to display the mark-to-market opportunity at Kimco, with an impressive 31% on new leases and a combined leasing spread of 13.1% in the fourth quarter, the highest combined spread in almost 3 years. U.S. same-site NOI growth was 2.8% for the quarter, primarily driven by minimum rent increases and a 20-basis-point positive impact from redevelopment. 
For the full year, U.S. same-site NOI growth is 3.1%, including a 50-basis-point negative impact from bankruptcies experienced over the year.
The average base rent for the U.S. portfolio continues to improve with a 5.2% gain from the prior year end. Competition continues to be fierce in our top markets of acquisition, with some staggering cap rates recently reported in areas of California. This bodes well for the NAV of our holdings in California, which is our largest state by NOI contribution and continues to direct us to deploy capital towards redevelopment of our existing assets versus acquiring in the open market. 
For the year, our total gross acquisition of $2.1 billion is heavily weighted toward the purchase of our joint venture interest in 57 assets. In contrast, only 2 assets were acquired in the open market for a purchase price of $155 million. The disposition market remains healthy, as we completed a total gross disposition value of $2.2 billion for the year. We completed the exit from Mexico and South America and announced the closing of the RioCan JV transaction in Canada. That will pave the way to achieving our goal of simplifying the company to be strictly U.S. focused by year end.
In the U.S., we completed the sale of 95 properties in 2015, for a gross price of $762 million, at a blended 6.9% cap rate. Pricing expectations for our disposition candidates have not changed, as we continue to see the demand for high-quality anchored open-air shopping centers. Our redevelopment program remains the focal point of our strategy. For the year, we budgeted $189 million of projects, delivering a 10.6% incremental return. We're pleased to announce that due to some cost savings, we came in under-budget on cost of $184 million and above budget on NOI, improving the incremental return to 11.3% for the year. Perhaps the most exciting redevelopment completion this quarter is this [indiscernible] opening in our flagship Long Island asset, Airport Plaza and Farmingdale. Early indications from stus and shoppers are incredible, and from the video footage of the parking lot, we think the benefit of this grocery addition to an existing power center will produce significant NAV and same-site NOI improvement for years to come.
In Florida, we also had successful openings of Publix at our Palm Beach redevelopment and haul-throughs at a redevelopment in Orlando. At last, we signed 2 new leases with Trader Joe's, one in California and one in Washington. These tremendous grocery additions improve the percent of AVR from grocery-anchored centers to 72%, up from 65% at prior year end.
To be the best, we continue to question the status quo and take a deep dive into every aspect of operations to help drive results. Open-air retail continues to evolve and embrace omni-channel, as a physical store has proven to be a driver of online sales. Our retailers know their customer better than anyone inside their 4 walls, and our job is to bring more people to the shopping center and get those consumers to come back time and time again. The open-air retail landscape is healthy, as limited new supply is forecasted and our strongest retailers continue to grow store count. The shadow supply from potential closings or consolidating retailers and future developments supply is what we are monitoring closely. 
Looking ahead, we are starting to see the activity pick up at every category size. Big-box retailers are back looking for space. Junior box players continue to be most aggressive. Traditional and specialty groceries are active and our small shop leasing indicates a healthy trajectory. All of these ingredients indicate we are well positioned to unlock the value of our real estate for our shareholders.
And now, I'll turn the call over to Glenn to revise more granularity on our results.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor, and congratulations on your appointment to CEO. It's going to be a fun go for us all. Good morning to everyone. We finished 2015 with a solid fourth quarter, delivering strong results for the full year, while furthering our transformation
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor, and congratulations on your appointment to CEO. It's going to be a fun go for us all. Good morning to everyone. 
We finished 2015 with a solid fourth quarter, delivering strong results for the full year, while furthering our transformation and simplification efforts. We successfully executed on our TSR strategy plus and delivered a total shareholder return of 9.4% in 2015, in a very tough and volatile market. In December, we unveiled our 2020 vision at our Investor Day, focusing on owning and operating high-quality U.S. properties in the major metro markets where we have deep concentration. We also continue to execute on our redevelopment pipeline and select ground-up development projects. Our 2020 vision includes operating with a more conservative capital structure, with plenty of liquidity and even stronger debt metrics than today. Finally, as an added benefit, we have the upside potential from our PLUS business. Position is clear. The team is focused and aligned. 
Now for some details on our fourth quarter and full year results and further color regarding our 2016 earnings guidance. Our FFO is adjusted per-share or recurring FFO, which excludes nonoperating impairments and transactional income and expense, was $0.37 for the fourth quarter, an increase of 5.7% compared to last year's $0.35. The increase was driven by higher NOI from the operating portfolio of $24.8 million, offset by $4.4 million of decreased management fees related to the significant reduction in joint ventures and higher G&A associated with severance charges, attributable to our anticipated exit of Canada. In addition, interest expense was higher by $5.6 million, primarily from the debt assumptions related to the Kimstone acquisition earlier in the year, the recent JV buyouts of Crown and SEB and the acquisition of the Christiana property in Phoenix.
Our full year 2015 FFO as adjusted per share came in at $1.46, achieving the high end of our revised guidance range and $0.06 above last year's result from $1.40, a 4.3% increase. Headline FFO per share representing the official NAREIT definition was $0.35 for the fourth quarter, in line with first call consensus estimates. Headline FFO per share was $0.02 lower than FFO as adjusted, primarily related to the $5.8 million noncash charge for the redemption of our $175 million, 6.9% series H preferred stock redemption during the quarter and the acquisition-related costs. Our full year 2015 headline FFO per share came in at $1.56, achieving the upper end of our guidance range and a $0.01 ahead of first call consensus. Our 2015 results were $0.11 higher than the 2014 amount of $1.45 per share, a 7.6% increase. The primary drivers of the headline per share increase are the $0.06 increase in recurring FFO and the gain on the sale of our SUPERVALU stock investment, which contributed $40 million or $0.10 per share. Acquisition cost and nonoperating impairments offset these increases. As Conor just articulated, the operating portfolio delivered solid results with improved occupancy, a 23rd consecutive quarter of delivering positive U.S. same-site NOI growth and double-digit leasing spreads. 
Ross Cooper and his team were very active during the quarter on the disposition front. We completed the sale-of-interest in 64 U.S. properties, 23 Canadian properties and our last asset in South America generating proceeds of approximately $600 million, which we used to fund $175 million redemption of preferred stock, pay down debt and fund the acquisitions. We remain focused and committed to operate with a strong capital structure. We finished the fourth quarter with consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA of 6x, the high-end of our 5.5 to 6x range, down from the 6.6x at the end of the first quarter, after acquiring $1.4 billion Kimstone portfolio.
We achieved this level even with the redemption of the preferred stock, which had a 0.2x impact on the metric. As part of our 2020 vision, overtime, we plan to reduce the consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA to a range of 5x to 5.5x, and on a look-through basis, including pro-rata JV debt and preferred stock to a range of 6.4x to 6.9x, with a fixed charge coverage of 3x plus. 
During the fourth quarter, we capped the bond market issuing a $500 million 7-year 3.4% fixed-rate bond. Our liquidity position is in excellent shape, ending the year with 0 outstanding on our $1.75 billion revolving credit facility and over $180 million in cash. We have already begun to address our 2016 maturities, both consolidated and in our JVs, which are anticipated to be funded with sales proceeds, the unsecured bank and bond markets and mortgage financings, all at lower coupons than the maturing debt.
We are reaffirming our guidance for 2016, which was provided at our Investor Day in December. Our FFO is adjusted or recurring FFO per share range is at $1.48 to $1.52, and our headline FFO per share range is $1.54 to $1.62. The guidance range takes into account the significant level of dispositions throughout 2015, and the accelerated exit of Canada during 2016, which has a combined impact of $0.06 to $0.07 per share on the 2016 growth expectations. We anticipate that by the end of 2016, we will be a purely U.S. owner and operator with assets concentrated in our key metro markets. The transactional expense and income included in the headline guidance range, but not in the recurring range, is primarily comprised of acquisition costs and the commencement of monetizing our Albertsons investment. As such, the transactional income portion is heavily weighted toward the fourth quarter of 2016. The guidance range is sensitive to timing of acquisitions, dispositions, redevelopments coming online, lease-up and financing initiatives. Our 2016 plan supports our recently increased common dividend level of $0.255 per quarter, which equates to an FFO payout ratio in the upper 60% range. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Milton.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glenn. Kimco is back to basics, a company focusing on property advantages in the United States. It took a tremendous effort by our exceptional team that executed all the transactions last year. In 2015, we reduced our foreign investments by $1.5
componenttext:
Thanks, Glenn. 
Kimco is back to basics, a company focusing on property advantages in the United States. It took a tremendous effort by our exceptional team that executed all the transactions last year. In 2015, we reduced our foreign investments by $1.5 billion gross, of which $729 million was our share, and we reduced the number of size and joint ventures by another 43%, a 65% decrease since 2010. Now our portfolio is much more streamlined, predominantly self-managed, located in the United States, with 564 properties in all the major markets. We look forward to the opportunities in the years ahead. There were some very exciting redevelopments and developments that our team is working on. We're committed to unlocking the value in our current portfolio and to grow the NAV for our shareholders. And now, we'd be delighted to take any questions.

componenttext: Just with regard to the Canadian assets, it looks like those that are remaining, the assets in the same store for the year end had weaker growth and lower occupancy then those that you sold to RioCan in Q4. Can you just remind us where you are in the sales process, those remaining 35 assets? What portion of the $900 million of dispositions guidance is [indiscernible]? And then what cap rates do you expect on those assets relative to the real RioCan deal?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Christy, it's Ross Cooper. In Canada as of right now, we have 25 assets out of the 35 that are under contracts to be sold. We expect that to happen in next 2 to 3 months, pending the outcome of some of the due diligence that's still remaining. And at
componenttext: Hi, Christy, it's Ross Cooper. In Canada as of right now, we have 25 assets out of the 35 that are under contracts to be sold. We expect that to happen in next 2 to 3 months, pending the outcome of some of the due diligence that's still remaining. And at that point in time, it will be approximately 86% completed from an NOI standpoint. So we feel really good about the pace at which it's going. The pricing is very consistent with where we were on the other assets. So we don't feel that the quality is necessarily lower. And we are in the low 6 cap rate range on those assets as well. The remaining assets at that point in time we're still working on getting into the marketplace, doing a little bit of lease up in some scenarios. But as Glenn mentioned, we're very much on track to be completely out by the end of the year.

componenttext: Christy, I'll just add here. The same-site guidance that we had is just going to be U.S. based, because the balance of these assets really is anticipated to be sold, most of it within the first half of the year and whatever straggles by the end of the year.
