headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Conor. On -- that's the Whole Foods development, actually the stabilization dates haven't changed. It's more than completion dates. So that was actually compressed between the 2. Actually, the cost lowered a little bit there, so we should see t
componenttext:
Sure. It's Conor. On -- that's the Whole Foods development, actually the stabilization dates haven't changed. It's more than completion dates. So that was actually compressed between the 2. Actually, the cost lowered a little bit there, so we should see that completed this year and the third quarter. Christiana, that site plan has actually changed. You see that the cost came down quite a bit. Originally, we had thought we were going to be developing a prototypical power center with junior box lineups. A large big-box anchor has significant interest now. So we've redesigned the site plan to ground these and get quite a bit of contribution from that tenant for the redesign of the site plan. So that's really what changed that site plan there.
Grand Parkway, we're finalizing the anchor lease there that we should be announcing shortly, but we have the [indiscernible] to cross that finish line. So that's really why that was pushed out of the quarter. So those are the big moving pieces there on those assets.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as a follow-up, on Owings Mills, do you have a sense of what you're going to do with this project? I know that there's about a 3.5-year lag between that opening as well.
componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-up, on Owings Mills, do you have a sense of what you're going to do with this project? I know that there's about a 3.5-year lag between that opening as well.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the beauty of Owings Mills is, it's going to be a blank slate. So -- that's why we bought all the different pieces. So mall development is a tricky one, especially if you don't control all the pieces. So what we did was we purchased our partners' int
componenttext: Just the beauty of Owings Mills is, it's going to be a blank slate. So -- that's why we bought all the different pieces. So mall development is a tricky one, especially if you don't control all the pieces. So what we did was we purchased our partners' interest, we purchased the Macy's, we purchased the JCPenney, which allows us to really start from scratch and take down the mall. And our design is really for a best-in-class open-air shopping center, which includes big-box retailers, junior anchors, restaurants, you name it. So we have -- we actually have 4 different site plans that we're working on right now, that we think all will add significant value and really create a lot of value for our shareholders in the long-term.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you can give us maybe a little more color on the sales environment today, ignoring the Canada stuff. Just talk about what you're seeing in terms of investor demand? Has the buyer pool thinned or maybe
componenttext: It's Jeremy Metz on with Ross. I was just wondering if you can give us maybe a little more color on the sales environment today, ignoring the Canada stuff. Just talk about what you're seeing in terms of investor demand? Has the buyer pool thinned or maybe the composition of interest to buyers changed in recent months? And then is financing at all become an issue for sellers or for buyers, in particular -- and some of the secondary market stuff?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ross again. As you've seen from the numbers, we've been executing on our plan on the dispositions. We really haven't seen any pushback or fallout of deals that we have in the marketplace. We have already closed on a couple of shopping center
componenttext: Sure. This is Ross again. As you've seen from the numbers, we've been executing on our plan on the dispositions. We really haven't seen any pushback or fallout of deals that we have in the marketplace. We have already closed on a couple of shopping centers so far this year. So the pace and the pricing is still very competitive. I think that you are right about the depth of the buyer pool. It certainly is maybe a little bit shallower than it was 6 to 9 months ago. But the groups that are active are still very competitive. We haven't seen financing really become an issue on the deals that we're selling in the secondary markets. And we think that we're going to have a very strong year. In fact, we have some assets on the West Coast that we've sold at very aggressive pricing and when you look at just statistics for our fourth quarter sales, we -- our average cap rate was 6.5%, which was the lowest cap rate that we have had on our dispositions that we have tracked since we have started the transformation. So we continue to see the cap rates become more aggressive, not less aggressive.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in the key markets in California, you've been tracking that. Really, the cap rates now almost discovered the floor and some have even dipped even lower. So we are obviously being very patient there and, clearly, we're not going to win many bi
componenttext: Yes, I think in the key markets in California, you've been tracking that. Really, the cap rates now almost discovered the floor and some have even dipped even lower. So we are obviously being very patient there and, clearly, we're not going to win many bidding wars today when those type of assets come to the market.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one quick one on shop occupancy. It's obviously been steadily moving high, and I think you previously mentioned a goal getting to 90% by year end. I know it's early in the year, but has the disruption in the markets or general nervousn
componenttext: Okay. And then just one quick one on shop occupancy. It's obviously been steadily moving high, and I think you previously mentioned a goal getting to 90% by year end. I know it's early in the year, but has the disruption in the markets or general nervousness about the economy impacted any leasing activity at all or demand for shop space and maybe put that in context of the national and franchises versus maybe the mom and pops?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a good question. I think we've seen demand continues to improve for small shops. You see it with our occupancy pickup there. In our pipeline, looking forward, we continue to see that improving over the year. It's a nice split between the natio
componenttext: Yes. That's a good question. I think we've seen demand continues to improve for small shops. You see it with our occupancy pickup there. In our pipeline, looking forward, we continue to see that improving over the year. It's a nice split between the nationals and the mom and pops. We had 55% of our small shops return with mom and pops this quarter. So the volatility in the market has not really put a governor on the amount of small shop leasing we're able to do. And we know that that's really where our occupancy pickup is going to be driving going forward. So we have been pleasantly surprised with the production there, and we will continue to push that going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan of Canaccord.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan of Canaccord.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your lease spreads were, as you noted, stronger in the quarter and you've been talking about your mark-to-market across the portfolio and the upside potential there. I mean, were there any specific catalysts on the newly spreads that you would point to? I
componenttext: Your lease spreads were, as you noted, stronger in the quarter and you've been talking about your mark-to-market across the portfolio and the upside potential there. I mean, were there any specific catalysts on the newly spreads that you would point to? I mean, are these numbers something that you think could be achievable, as we look into 2016?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think combined leasing spreads is really -- the double-digit is really our goal. So if we can continue that, that will be fantastic. Some of the maneuverable ones we did this past quarter, we did 3 deals on former Anna's Linens boxes that were actually
componenttext: I think combined leasing spreads is really -- the double-digit is really our goal. So if we can continue that, that will be fantastic. Some of the maneuverable ones we did this past quarter, we did 3 deals on former Anna's Linens boxes that were actually a positive 33%. So above what our previous range was that we thought we had on that mark-to-market opportunity, and again, it's all about supply and demand. Right now, we just -- we see that there is retailers in all categories, whether it's small shop, midsize, junior boxes or the big-box anchors, they all have been very aggressive in growing store count and that continues to lead to bidding wars, which will bid off rest and we always continue to see that as an opportunity for us going into this year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a follow-up, your credit losses were also really low in the quarter, and it seems like the bankruptcy season has been relatively light so far. I mean, how's your outlook for the first half of the year, especially kind of thinking about
componenttext: Okay. And then just a follow-up, your credit losses were also really low in the quarter, and it seems like the bankruptcy season has been relatively light so far. I mean, how's your outlook for the first half of the year, especially kind of thinking about it from a year-over-year comp perspective? And how that could benefit same store numbers?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We obviously monitor our tenant's health very closely. Our watch list haven't really changed all that much. I mean, you know that we've been watching the same tenants for a long time now, and I think it's relatively healthy when you look out. Clearly
componenttext: Yes. We obviously monitor our tenant's health very closely. Our watch list haven't really changed all that much. I mean, you know that we've been watching the same tenants for a long time now, and I think it's relatively healthy when you look out. Clearly, there might be some consolidation or some fallout in the year. But overall, we think we're in a sweet spot on retail. We think off prices is really becoming the darling in the U.S., and we continue to see huge demand for that type of space. And we think that this year will continue along that path of being just a healthy environment.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from R.J. Milligan of Baird.
componenttext: And our next question comes from R.J. Milligan of Baird.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just curious if you could give an update as to what you've seen on the ground in Puerto Rico? And if any of the macro issues there have trickled down into whether it would be sales or leasing?
componenttext: I was just curious if you could give an update as to what you've seen on the ground in Puerto Rico? And if any of the macro issues there have trickled down into whether it would be sales or leasing?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Puerto Rico is obviously one we're watching closely. It's relatively small in terms of the impact on our whole portfolio. It's a little less than 3%. So we watch it closely. We have seen activity on the Anna's boxes that we've got back and think we'll
componenttext: The Puerto Rico is obviously one we're watching closely. It's relatively small in terms of the impact on our whole portfolio. It's a little less than 3%. So we watch it closely. We have seen activity on the Anna's boxes that we've got back and think we'll be able to lease those up this year. Clearly the headlines, the Puerto Rico was in some serious issues, was trying to restructure their debt. But the shopper is still vibrant down there. We recently hosted a portfolio tour down there, and Glenn, you want to talk a little bit about the traffic you saw?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it is pretty amazing. I mean, I was down there on the [indiscernible]. Going with the Kmart in Puerto Rico, all the lights are on, the shelves are fully stocked. The couple that we went into, there were 7 or 8 registers open with 3 or 4 peopl
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it is pretty amazing. I mean, I was down there on the [indiscernible]. Going with the Kmart in Puerto Rico, all the lights are on, the shelves are fully stocked. The couple that we went into, there were 7 or 8 registers open with 3 or 4 people beeping them. And the parking lots are filled with people shopping. The discounts approach down there works really well. All the economy, the Puerto Rican economy has been recessing for a long time, and really a very deep underground economy there and the people just shop. So the properties are very, very successful.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question.
componenttext: Next question.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In regards to development, we have seen a lot of pullback on their overall size of the pipeline. Just holistically, what are you guys seeing that gives you confidence to increase it at this point in time?
componenttext: In regards to development, we have seen a lot of pullback on their overall size of the pipeline. Just holistically, what are you guys seeing that gives you confidence to increase it at this point in time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Most of our strategic development has a story to them, and we feel very confident about why we think it's appropriate to add these to the pipeline. If you go asset-by-asset, they each have a reason why -- the one in Fort Lauderdale is right across fr
componenttext: Yes. Most of our strategic development has a story to them, and we feel very confident about why we think it's appropriate to add these to the pipeline. If you go asset-by-asset, they each have a reason why -- the one in Fort Lauderdale is right across from our most successful shopping center in the State of Florida, and the demand has been off-the-charts there. If you look at the Christiana, Delaware, its right along 95, where we've been working to rezone that from a former Sears warehouse to now a retail offering, and it's right next to GGP's successful Christiana Mall. So each and every one of these projects have a story to it. And there is not going to be significant more development in our pipeline looking out, mainly because the land prices have really skyrocketed. A lot of that's due to the multifamily that we've seen pop up. But we see the demand from our retailers to want to grow store count and limited supply. So each of these projects has really -- it's within a key market for us. The demand is there. And the one in Houston, obviously, with Houston going through some headwinds, we still see retailers wanting to be there and fill the void. Clearly, the apartments and the density around our Grand Parkway project has been there for a long period of time, and I think the retail is the last sector to really catch up to meet the demand. So we haven't seen any falloff in terms of retailer demand there, and that will actually be one of our first development projects on the ground and we're cautiously optimistic that it will be a big success.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As a follow-up on the same topic. Could you comment on like some of the retailers that you're -- you have as anchors for these developments, like [indiscernible] or Sports Authority or Target that wasn't anchor-listed at Grand Parkway, and that's no
componenttext: Okay. As a follow-up on the same topic. Could you comment on like some of the retailers that you're -- you have as anchors for these developments, like [indiscernible] or Sports Authority or Target that wasn't anchor-listed at Grand Parkway, and that's not longer there in the supplemental of this quarter. Just curious if you could comment on -- I mean, basically the health of these anchor tenants?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've reposted the targets back on the plan, as that was probably just a refresh that you need to do on the supplemental. But yes, you mentioned a few times that are on our watch list. Those tenants are obviously ones we're watching very closely a
componenttext: I think we've reposted the targets back on the plan, as that was probably just a refresh that you need to do on the supplemental. But yes, you mentioned a few times that are on our watch list. Those tenants are obviously ones we're watching very closely and monitoring. We're cautiously optimistic that it's not going to be a liquidation, if and when something happens to those retailers. So we're looking to see where our exposure is? How we can limit it? And again, the mark-to-market opportunity that we talked about is really -- are measure of safety when we get those boxes back. So we think we're trying to be careful about how we manage risk and those junior boxes, you mentioned, are ones that are, obviously, on the watch list.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is just on Albertsons, just given the choppy IPO market. Would you guys consider other monetization alternatives like private sale of your steak or your view is that it's not you will find the whole business as long as necessary to when the
componenttext: First question is just on Albertsons, just given the choppy IPO market. Would you guys consider other monetization alternatives like private sale of your steak or your view is that it's not you will find the whole business as long as necessary to when the IPO market comes back?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think our intent right now [indiscernible] -- our intent right now is just to hold our interest with our partners. At this point, it's a very successful business operation, and we're really optimistic about it.
componenttext: I mean, I think our intent right now [indiscernible] -- our intent right now is just to hold our interest with our partners. At this point, it's a very successful business operation, and we're really optimistic about it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second is for Glenn. Glenn, in the debt summary, it looks like you guys still have 2 Canadian unsecured bonds outstanding. And with the exit from Canada slated for year end, it would seem like a sort of mismatch. So just curious especially
componenttext: Okay. And then second is for Glenn. Glenn, in the debt summary, it looks like you guys still have 2 Canadian unsecured bonds outstanding. And with the exit from Canada slated for year end, it would seem like a sort of mismatch. So just curious especially with the strength of the U.S. dollar, does it make sense to prepay these or your view is to just leave these outstanding to their natural maturities over the next, I guess, 4 years or so?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is very fair and great question. We're very closely monitoring the progress that we make on the sales, because the bonds serve us on natural hedge. So depending on the timing and the quickness of the sales, we are going to need to evaluate how we're
componenttext: This is very fair and great question. We're very closely monitoring the progress that we make on the sales, because the bonds serve us on natural hedge. So depending on the timing and the quickness of the sales, we are going to need to evaluate how we're going to handle the debt. As long as we meet the cash in Canada, it stays naturally hedged, but there may become a point where it makes sense to either do a cross currency swap, tender for the bonds, make hold the bonds, but it's something that's very much on the radar screen that we'll have to address as we go forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the off-price commentary. Obviously, that's been a key driver for the space overall. But I was just wondering that we hear about -- we have been hearing about it for quite a long time. Just wondering how you think about saturatio
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the off-price commentary. Obviously, that's been a key driver for the space overall. But I was just wondering that we hear about -- we have been hearing about it for quite a long time. Just wondering how you think about saturation of that concept and maybe if you could comment on what percentage of your -- group percentage of your centers have some form of off-price in it, whether or not that's traditional TJs or some of the newer players?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We can get back to you on the percentage of the total portfolio of an off-price component. It would be very high. And so we can't give you the exact percentage. But on your question on saturation, it's one we watch closely. There is, obviously, a lot of n
componenttext: We can get back to you on the percentage of the total portfolio of an off-price component. It would be very high. And so we can't give you the exact percentage. But on your question on saturation, it's one we watch closely. There is, obviously, a lot of new players in the off-price segment. We love the off-price segment. We think that TJX has been really the phenomenal performer for many, many years now. And if you look back not too long ago, the market cap of TJX and Ross combined was relatively small compared to some of the mall anchors, and if you just compare it to today, it's really phenomenal, just the growth that they have achieved. The new players were watching closely. We want to try and pick best-in-class and have the merchandising mix that enhances both at the shopping center and the amount of traffic it drives. So we're cautiously optimistic that I think that more competition is good for the off-price sector. We clearly favor the ones that have to prove in business model and we're doing it for many, many years. But going forward, it will be an interesting situation to watch to see who really can capture some of that market share. TJX obviously has such a leap. And now Ross is really ramping up their expansion plans. And then if you look at Nordstrom rack and then sort of the Saks OFF 5TH, Fine from Lord & Taylor, there is a lot of players out there that are trying to really gain market share. So it will be interesting to see how competitive they are.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Any comments on backstage and how they're doing?
componenttext: Okay. Any comments on backstage and how they're doing?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been in talks with Backstage. We have yet to execute a lease with them. So again, it's one of those newer players we're watching closely to see how they perform.
componenttext: We've been in talks with Backstage. We have yet to execute a lease with them. So again, it's one of those newer players we're watching closely to see how they perform.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Caitlin Burrows with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Caitlin Burrows with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have a quick question on Amazon. We've heard that they started opening select brick-and-mortar locations, and I was wondering if you have had any discussions with them, whether we could expect them to be in your centers in the future, and if you kn
componenttext: I just have a quick question on Amazon. We've heard that they started opening select brick-and-mortar locations, and I was wondering if you have had any discussions with them, whether we could expect them to be in your centers in the future, and if you knew anything about their long or medium-term brick-and-mortar plan?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. They have one open brick-and-mortar location in Seattle. And it's done very well for them. They continue to see that as an opportunity. We have met with them. We've talked about opportunities with them. I think they're going to be very selective, ver
componenttext: Yes. They have one open brick-and-mortar location in Seattle. And it's done very well for them. They continue to see that as an opportunity. We have met with them. We've talked about opportunities with them. I think they're going to be very selective, very strategic on their store opening plan. And so I think it's going to be more of a measured approach to it, rather than a full-blown assault on opening a lot of brick-and-mortar stores. But it's clearly an indication that a lot of pure e-commerce retailers see the value of opening physical stores, which is a real boost for our sector, because there is this tethering effect and you see it from a lot of our retailers who come out and display the amount of online sales that's going to opening a new physical location. But also the amount that they lose when they close a physical location in terms of the online sales. So it's interesting to watch and Amazon obviously being the largest is really a good sign for us for the long haul.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mike Mueller of JP Morgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mike Mueller of JP Morgan.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, you talked about seeing more demand from big-box centers. Can you give us a little more color on just how broad-based that is? Is it covering just existing shopping centers, your appetite for new shopping center development, et cetera?
componenttext: Conor, you talked about seeing more demand from big-box centers. Can you give us a little more color on just how broad-based that is? Is it covering just existing shopping centers, your appetite for new shopping center development, et cetera?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's both actually. They are looking to try and enter some of our redevelopments as well as the new developments. So it's nice because a lot of the times when we were looking at the most active players, it was the junior boxes. So they were the ones
componenttext: Yes, it's both actually. They are looking to try and enter some of our redevelopments as well as the new developments. So it's nice because a lot of the times when we were looking at the most active players, it was the junior boxes. So they were the ones most aggressive on redevelopments as well as the ground up developments we have in our pipeline. And it's nice to see now that the big-box anchors are coming back and looking to grow store count. And again, it's in select locations, where they see opportunity or it might be a void for them. But again, the mass merchandisers have been missing for a while in terms of activity. So it's nice to see them back looking for stores.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's not just one category you're seeing and it's fairly broad-based?
componenttext: So it's not just one category you're seeing and it's fairly broad-based?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from James Sullivan of Cowen group.
componenttext: And our next question comes from James Sullivan of Cowen group.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, just to kind of follow up in terms of the demand side of the equation. There has been a lot of pressure reports recently about some of the major as well as some new grocers expanding into the Mid-Atlantic market. And Whiteman, Publix, Lidl, and so
componenttext: Conor, just to kind of follow up in terms of the demand side of the equation. There has been a lot of pressure reports recently about some of the major as well as some new grocers expanding into the Mid-Atlantic market. And Whiteman, Publix, Lidl, and so forth, and just curious whether that's showing up when you're talking about demand for boxes. I'm assuming you're talking about big-boxes as opposed to grocers, but you might be talking about both. So are we looking at, I don't want to say a bidding war, but a really strong demand environment in the Mid-Atlantic as a result of those trends? And as part of that, can you just address in terms of Lidl, whether they're going into centers? Are they looking at freestanding locations?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, you're spot on. My comments earlier were really targeted towards the big-box players. But you're right on when you talk about the grocery competition in the Mid-Atlantic. It is going to be fierce with all those new entrants into that market. And you'r
componenttext: No, you're spot on. My comments earlier were really targeted towards the big-box players. But you're right on when you talk about the grocery competition in the Mid-Atlantic. It is going to be fierce with all those new entrants into that market. And you're right where -- it's going to be a bidding war. It's going to be interesting to see who shakes out in terms of the winners or losers. But there is going to be plenty of aggressive entrants into that market in the Mid-Atlantic and any names, pretty much the majors that are all coming, and coming in droves. So on your question on Lidl, its interesting when we met with them and talk to them about their plans. Most of their plans are self-development. So they actually looking to self-develop standalone grocery stores, where they can be competitors to the traditional grocery stores at a lower price point. So most of what they've been doing is tying up land and looking to self-develop. So they have little bit of a different approach to it than say some of your traditional grocer who is looking to lease space. That being said, though, there is plenty of bidding going on for opportunity there. But it's already a very tight market, so it's very difficult to penetrate.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just follow up, in terms of Albertsons and West Coast. With Albertsons buying back some of their stores and its domination in many of the Northwest markets, I guess, had increased. And I wonder if you can address whether Albertsons has put
componenttext: And if I could just follow up, in terms of Albertsons and West Coast. With Albertsons buying back some of their stores and its domination in many of the Northwest markets, I guess, had increased. And I wonder if you can address whether Albertsons has put any bid in on the, I think, the 33 remaining Haggen stores that go to auction next week, whether Albertsons has put a bid in for any of those as well and perhaps an update on the timing of an IPO?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with respect to Haggen's, I know they're looking at the 30-odd stores that are going -- held as going concern. But again I'm not sure, I'm not into the detail. So I don't know if there's FTC issues about being able to take down all those occasions o
componenttext: Well, with respect to Haggen's, I know they're looking at the 30-odd stores that are going -- held as going concern. But again I'm not sure, I'm not into the detail. So I don't know if there's FTC issues about being able to take down all those occasions or not. Importantly, on that front, Albertsons had a lawsuit with Haggen's that was settled. So that will help get something done there. So it is a big step for them to get that resolved. With respect to the IPO, the S1 remains on fire. It has been updated for the third quarter, and the fourth quarter for Albertsons, and I think February 22 or 23, so market conditions improve, after the fourth quarter, but we'll revisit the opportunity in the public markets.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from George Auerbach of Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from George Auerbach of Crdit Suisse.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, any color on the expected yields that the new projects in Owings Mills and Pentagon or, I guess, more broadly, if I look at the active development page and added in Pentagon, what's the expected weighted-average yields on these projects?
componenttext: Conor, any color on the expected yields that the new projects in Owings Mills and Pentagon or, I guess, more broadly, if I look at the active development page and added in Pentagon, what's the expected weighted-average yields on these projects?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. We are targeting between 7.5 and 8.5. That's really where the -- really the expected yields are for the entire portfolio of redevelopment and development projects. So obviously, Owings Mill is just a recent combination of acquis
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. We are targeting between 7.5 and 8.5. That's really where the -- really the expected yields are for the entire portfolio of redevelopment and development projects. So obviously, Owings Mill is just a recent combination of acquisitions there. So we have a few different pipelines depending on the best return, which when we will go with. Pentagon is, obviously, the apartment towers that we've talked about and this incurrent 25,000 square feet of new retail there. So the ROI is going to be a little bit lower there, because of the apartments, but the spread from the cap rate is still well over 200 basis points. So we feel like we have a manageable pipeline that really will deliver significant NAV for the company going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just one follow-up. Glenn, what are you modeling for noncash revenue in the 2016 guidance? I saw it increased in the fourth quarter, I'm just wondering if it's sort of stays at that kind of a run rate?
componenttext: That's helpful. And just one follow-up. Glenn, what are you modeling for noncash revenue in the 2016 guidance? I saw it increased in the fourth quarter, I'm just wondering if it's sort of stays at that kind of a run rate?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Can you be more specific about that noncash revenue?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. The straight line rent and [indiscernible] was something like $11.5 million and it was running in kind of the $8 million range earlier in the year. I was just wondering if that was ...

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but it pumped up really due to the acquisitions, right? Certainly, when we brought on the Blackstone portfolio, the Christiana assets are very large assets that has it in there. It will probably a little bit higher, but not modestly higher than what
componenttext: Yes, but it pumped up really due to the acquisitions, right? Certainly, when we brought on the Blackstone portfolio, the Christiana assets are very large assets that has it in there. It will probably a little bit higher, but not modestly higher than what we see today.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, two questions. Number one, I guess, maybe Glenn, in terms of guidance of 2.5 to 3.5 for same-store, I'm just trying to think what you've sort of incorporated in terms of bankruptcies and down time. I guess you had some of those in '15 and it clic
componenttext: I guess, two questions. Number one, I guess, maybe Glenn, in terms of guidance of 2.5 to 3.5 for same-store, I'm just trying to think what you've sort of incorporated in terms of bankruptcies and down time. I guess you had some of those in '15 and it clicked the result. I'm just trying to figure out how conservative you might have been or where that figure is in relation to where you started the year ago?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you think about the initial guidance that we put out last year, right. We're in this 3 to 3.5 range. We brought to the whole year, we came in at 3.1. And as Conor mentioned, and as an A&P really gave us about 50 basis points. So we would h
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you think about the initial guidance that we put out last year, right. We're in this 3 to 3.5 range. We brought to the whole year, we came in at 3.1. And as Conor mentioned, and as an A&P really gave us about 50 basis points. So we would have achieved the high end of range, but that has just happened. The guidance range does incorporate a modest amount, not a lot, or bankruptcies, so if you get to the midpoint, we think there should be a very, very modest amount. If there is a large-scale bankruptcy, your probably wouldn't have a new and you probably want us towards the lower end of the range. It's stable and lease-up happen when we think we can get to the mid-to upper end of the range.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then I guess, just to kind of follow up on a couple of the Albertsons questions. I believe the intent, obviously, in 16 was to have the IPO and then start to monetize that and use some of that cash to fund, to the extent that the IPO either happens later in the year or maybe doesn't happen at all for market conditions, just how do you think about your needs of cash and how do you supplement that?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's fairly -- on a relative basis, it's fairly modest. I mean, once it's baked in the guidance from a cash standpoint, somewhere between $50 million and $100 million starts late in the year. So for a 2016 impact, it's fairly modest. And they can be
componenttext: Yes. It's fairly -- on a relative basis, it's fairly modest. I mean, once it's baked in the guidance from a cash standpoint, somewhere between $50 million and $100 million starts late in the year. So for a 2016 impact, it's fairly modest. And they can be supplemented in many different ways, and you might have a little bit more debt. I mean, at the high end of $100 million, it's about one kick of net debt-to-EBITDA and may have more sales than supplemented. So in the scheme of things, if it didn't go, we would obviously have to deal with our headline guidance, because it's baked into that. But other than that, if our current flows there and it's modest to the capital plan.

componenttext: Well, the nice part that what we have is an enormous amount of liquidity, right. We end the year with 0 outstanding on our credit facility. As you see in our guidance, we're still planning to be a net seller during the year, so just more proceeds coming in. And the nice part that where we are today is we do have an ATM in place, and we can use it opportunistically, if it makes sense to do so. So it's another thing that we continually monitor and we'll try to take advantage of improving the balance sheet at any point in time that we can, in measured form.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. Same topic. As you look at market rents over the last year versus this year, what kind of market rent growth you're seeing, not re-leasing spread, but true on the ground market rent growth?
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. Same topic. As you look at market rents over the last year versus this year, what kind of market rent growth you're seeing, not re-leasing spread, but true on the ground market rent growth?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Market rent really depends on location and, obviously, the strength of the site and the surrounding demographics, but the market rents in the top market continued to pick up nicely. It really is a function of supply and demand, and we continue to see pret
componenttext: Market rent really depends on location and, obviously, the strength of the site and the surrounding demographics, but the market rents in the top market continued to pick up nicely. It really is a function of supply and demand, and we continue to see pretty strong leasing spreads. But if you look at the pure tick-up in market rents, it's at the high end of our range, where we expected it to be and continue to see it improve, as retailers really have focused on making sure to try and penetrate these markets, but also not lose stores. I think that's more of a critical component to the retailers that are coming due for renewals are worried about losing store count in these tough markets, where they have significant market share. So you'll probably see the renewal spread actually pick up a little bit this year, as those leases come up for real.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you look at sales growth by the tenants and kind of low single digits and e-commerce takes a slice of that for those tenants that you have e-commerce exposure or maybe they even have their own omni-channel presence, but with brick-and-mortar really bei
componenttext: As you look at sales growth by the tenants and kind of low single digits and e-commerce takes a slice of that for those tenants that you have e-commerce exposure or maybe they even have their own omni-channel presence, but with brick-and-mortar really being kind of low single-digit sales growth environment, how long can market rent growth continue to outpace that and get OCR's there probably increasing higher than potentially long-term averages would assume as correct?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. It's one that I think retailers look at your occupancy cost. They really have to be mindful of sales growth as well as how much rent they can pay. The nice thing about our sector is we have some of the lowest occupancy costs across a
componenttext: It's a good question. It's one that I think retailers look at your occupancy cost. They really have to be mindful of sales growth as well as how much rent they can pay. The nice thing about our sector is we have some of the lowest occupancy costs across any sector of REITs. So we think we have significant pricing power still left to go. And it really helps by being in the best markets and having the best assets. Those are ones that are very difficult to come by. So retailers don't necessarily want to lose those store count either. So it's one that we think still have a long runway to go. And again, I think that as long as supply and demand remain in check, we're in good shape though.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean, [indiscernible] our portfolio is a little bit different, because it's older. We have so many leases, though that are really well below market. So even though you might not have true dramatic amounts of rent growth, per se, relative to where our leases are today, leases that are 10, 15, 20 years old, you still have a lot of upside when you bring those to market.

componenttextpreview: Yes. On the Anna's Linens boxes, probably we had 21 leases. We have 3 fully executed leases at a positive 33% spread. We have 14 active leases in negotiation to fill those boxes. Two of the leases were assigned [indiscernible] and we actually sold too. So
componenttext: Yes. On the Anna's Linens boxes, probably we had 21 leases. We have 3 fully executed leases at a positive 33% spread. We have 14 active leases in negotiation to fill those boxes. Two of the leases were assigned [indiscernible] and we actually sold too. So we actually have very strong interest across the board on Anna's Linens. A&P, the 9 locations, 5 were assigned, 4 to Acme, 1 to indiscernible]. The 4 vacant boxes have significant interest -- I'm sorry, we have -- really when you break it down, it's really -- it's a phenomenal opportunity to really reposition on what was a struggling grocer. And you name it in terms of who the off-price retailers that want to try and take these boxes as well as some of the specialty grocers. And even some of the warehouse clubs that are -- where we have liquidity and lease termination rates for the surrounding retail. We might have some redevelopment potential there. In addition to the [indiscernible] redevelopment, where we plan on keeping that as a strategic vacancy through 2017, when our entitlements come into place and we have a very large redevelopment there.
