headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also avail
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address question at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton Cooper our Executive Chairman; Dave Jamison, Executive Vice President of Asset Management Operations; Ross Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Investment Officer; and Ray Edwards Vice President and overseas our retail services business. 
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking. It's important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the execution of all aspects of our strategy as we focus less on short-term earnings and more on creating long-term net asset value. Our disposition and acquisition activity continues to produce a higher quality portfolio. This higher quality is reflected in our leasing production as we continue to attract premier tenants at higher rents. 
Our redevelopment and development activity continues to create value and opportunity, unlocking the highest and best use of the real estates. And we do all of this with a cautious and watchful eye on our balance sheet and our cost of capital. Now for some details. In the first quarter, we continue to execute on our disposition strategy by closing on $323 million of dispositions in Canada and $114 million of dispositions in the U.S. The blended average cap rate was 6.9% in the first quarter and quality buyers ranging from public REITs, private REITs, local private real estate groups, high net worth individuals, international buyers and trade buyers all continue to call through our disposition portfolio. 
We are in the ninth inning of our transformation, so with the majority of our Canadian portfolio under contracts and the products to date on our U.S. dispositions, we are on pace to hit our target of $400 million to $475 million of dispositions in the U.S. and $425 million to $500 million in Canada by year-end and complete the transformation of the portfolio. Turning to acquisitions. Our first quarter concluded with limited volume, reflecting the competitiveness in our target markets. After quarter-end, we did reach agreements to purchase our JV partner's interest in Oakwood Plaza and the adjacent Dania Pointe development site. These sites combined to offer over 2 miles of frontage to our I-95 in the Fort Lauderdale Miami corridor. Oakwood is 100% occupied, but reflects what we look for in our target markets. 
Irreplaceable real estate with below-market rents, significant sales volumes and future redevelopment opportunity. Dania is the adjacent development site that we now control and are happy to take this opportunity to announce the ground lease with Costco to and anchor the first phase and kick off the pre-leasing. Both Oakwood and Dania are key building blocks to our 2020 Vision, creating value on larger assets in markets with high various entry. Oakwood is now our #2 NOI producer and upon stabilization, Dania will be the #1 NOI contributor in the entire portfolio. 
The strong leasing demand for quality real estate highlights the positive supply and demand in balance that the open-air sector is currently enjoying. Keeping occupancy steady at 95.8% over prior quarter, validates the portfolio of quality and the quality of our leasing team as we typically experience an early year dip due to post-holiday closings. Retailer demand did not change during the stock market correction in the first quarter and we continue to see demand across all square footage categories. The volume of new deals this quarter included big-box retailers, grocery stores and off-price retailers, all enhancing the merchandising mix and improving net asset value. 
Target, Whole Foods, Giant and Trader Joe's are just a few examples of executed leases this quarter that positively impacts NAV. A high number of our new deals this quarter, including the targeted Whole Foods deals are taking currently occupied space. So while we will have a short-term hit in same-site NOI and do not pick up any occupancy, we do pick up a material improvement in NAV. In addition, these quality tenants create a halo effect in our centers, which allow Kimco to achieve outsized growth from the surrounding retail. New leases were signed at an average base rent of $21 a foot reflecting the embedded mark the market opportunities while compared to our current average base rent. Kimco's average base rent is now $14.167 [ph], a 4.8% increase over Q1 2015 and a 27.9% increase over Q1 2010. 
While we are currently enjoying a 38-year low in supply, we are monitoring the shadow supply pipeline closely. Recent bankruptcies and announced store closings, in addition to pending mergers, will be the primary driver of increased supply in the short run for both mall and open-air centers. This is not new to our sector. What is new is that at Kimco today, our transformed high-quality portfolio makes us more ready and better prepared for these situations. That is why we are approaching the Sports Authority liquidation with cautious optimism. 
Preliminary indications suggest that we will be significant demand for our boxes, if and when they revert back to us. redevelopments completed in the first quarter will deliver incremental NOI of $2.3 million with an ROI of 11.5%. Redevelopment remains the best use of our capital and Kimco's billion-dollar pipeline continues to cycle more projects from the entitlement stage to the active pipeline as additional opportunities are constantly being discovered within the existing portfolio. 
The amount of raw material in our portfolio and the focus on value creation has given rise to a shadow pipeline of additional redevelopment projects that account for roughly $2 billion of future projects. Acting upon the embedded opportunity will serve our long-term shareholders by adding value to best-in-class properties. Turning to development. We recently had 2 major milestones, by securing the Target deal at our Grand Parkway development in Texas and today, announcing the Costco ground lease at our Dania development projects in Florida. 
These anchors have just started the pre-leasing for the first phases of both projects. Due to the lack of new supply and a strong demand from open-air retailers, we continue to aggressively pre-lease our strategic development projects. Each development site has a date of plan in-place to better monitor and ensure that our investment remains accretive to our cost of capital and to provide off ramps to keep maximum flexibility. In 
closing, we continue to march toward our 2020 Vision of being a U.S. focus REIT, with large pockets of concentration and high barrier to entry markets. The team is working overtime to unlock value at the property level to lease up and mark-to-market opportunities, continuing to expand and deliver on the redevelopment pipeline and executing on the strategic development pipeline, all while positioning the balance sheet to be in a position of strength now and for the next cycle. 
Glenn will now take you through the details of the first quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients needed to achieve our 2020 Vision. Headline FFO per diluted share, which represents the official NAREIT definition was $0.38, up from $0.37 last year and $0.01 [ph] higher than first call consensus. The improved performance is attributable to a 5.2% increase in U.S. net operating income, which was substantially offset by the reduction in NOI from the Canadian dispositions. 
Lower G&A expense and lower financing costs attributable to the redemption of the 6.9% preferred stock last year also contributed to the growth. Included in the headline result is a profit participation from the sale of our Canadian preferred equity investment of $5.5 million. FFO as adjusted or recurring FFO, which excludes nonoperating impairments and transactional income and expense was $0.37 per diluted share for the first quarter, up from $0.36 last year, a 2.8% increase. We accomplished this growth level despite the $0.03 per share dilutive impact from our portfolio transformation. 
The portfolio transformation includes the substantial disposition of assets in Latin America and Canada totaling $900 million and $600 million of U.S. dispositions in just the last 12 months. The diluted impact was more than offset with the reduced financing costs and $1.4 billion of acquisitions of high-quality assets in our key markets. Many of the acquisitions were sourced from our joint venture programs. Our portfolio operating team delivered solid first quarter results, maintaining our anchored and occupancy at 98.2% and increasing small shop space by 40 basis points from a year-ago to 88.6%. 
We remain on target for small shop occupancy to reach 90% by year-end. We continue to deliver strong leasing spreads, up 19.1% for new leases, up 6.3% for renewals and options and 7.5% combined. U.S. same-site NOI growth is 1.5% and includes a credit loss reserve of $3.2 million or 140 basis points related to the bankruptcy filing by Sports Authority. This reserve amount includes 100% of all prepetition amounts and $811,000 of rent from March which remains unpaid. Even with the short-term impact in Sports Authority, we remain on track and reaffirm our full-year U.S. same-site NOI guidance range of an increase of 2.5% to 3.5%. 
Additionally, in an effort to give the analyst and investor community further information for comparability purposes, we have included in our supplemental package the same-site disclosures of straight line rent adjustments, lease termination fees and amortization of above and below market rents. As Part of our 2020 Vision, we are laser-focused on further improving our debt metrics with a target of 5 to 5.5x for consolidated net debt through occurring EBITDA and a fixed charge coverage of 3x plus. 
In the last 12 months, we have reduced our net debt by $560 million from $5.5 billion to $4.94 billion at March 31. At the end of the first quarter, net debt to recurring EBITDA is 5.9x, down from 6.6x a year ago and fixed charge coverage came in at 3.2x. We repaid over $400 million of maturing debt during the first quarter and we paid an additional $117 million of mortgage debt in April, leaving us with just about $250 million in remaining consolidated maturities for the balance of the year. 
A portion of the debt repayment was accomplished with $138.5 million of proceeds raised from the issuance of 4.96 million shares of common equity through our ATM program and a weighted average offering price of $28.20 per share during March and April. As another data point, at the end of the first quarter, our total debt to total market capitalization was down to 28%, the lowest level in the past 8 years. 
Based on the solid first quarter results, we are reaffirming our headline FFO per share guidance range of $1.54 to $1.62. Please keep in mind that the bulk of the transactional income for 2016 is anticipated to occur late in the fourth quarter. We're also reaffirming our FFO as adjusted per-share of guidance range of $1.58 to $1.52 and a midpoint of $1.50 per share and each of our operating guidance assumptions. 
And with that, we'd be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, I was wondering if you could just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP. But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership?
componenttext: Conor, I was wondering if you could just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP. But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership? And then I get your point in terms of wanting to have high pockets of concentration, but it would seem that between Oakwood and Dania, which would rank 1 and #2, that would be a very large concentration in a very concentrated location. So maybe could just walk through some of the comfort that you got through all that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100%, give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakwood
componenttext: Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100%, give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakwood is where we have an office, so we have physical presence there. And so we realize that with Oakwood and Dania, we have a unique opportunity to really enhance the value of both assets of what we're trying to do, both at Oakwood and at Dania. So we've been proactive with all of our partners and this one was opportunistic for us to strike and really take CPP out of the transaction early on in this stage. So we were able to buy CPP out of the development side at their basis, which we thought was extremely opportunistic. And now that we have Costco fully executed, we think that it's just the beginning of a strong pre-leasing effort for the first phase. And the second phase now that we have complete control, gives us the ability to really take a step back and look at what's the highest and best use for the property if we want to sell off parcel, if we want to self-develop more parcels or if we want to do higher density, we have that luxury now, which before, we probably have the inability to do so because of the partnership. So we feel like it gives us more flexibility, and it continues to allow us to focus on larger assets with significant both development and redevelopment activity. So that's a little bit of the history there. In terms of the concentration, you're right that it's going to be in terms of our size, the #1 and #2 producing properties in the portfolio. But we also have tremendous pockets of concentration in California and New York. And with future redevelopments at Westlake and as well as some of our other larger assets, I think that there will be other larger assets that may challenge the #1 and #2 distinction that were given Dania and Oakwood. And so we always want to look and see and make sure we're diversified accordingly. So if it becomes too concentrated, we'll have, hopefully the luxury of looking at alternative ideas there of what we should do.

componenttext: Craig. It's Conor. I think that when you look at the -- if you talk about half the Sports Authority boxes, it'll obviously, be a case by case situation. But the one that we have really had been heavily marketing, we feel like we have a tremendous amount of interest in those boxes. So we have LOI's already in place in a number of them, so if you just want to take the 25 and cut it in half, it would probably take us -- probably another quarter or 2 to finally finalize the leases and then get half of them fully executed. That being said, we're well aware, the interest levels, other supporting goods, operators in real estate and their lease hold positions. So we anticipate anywhere between -- during the auction process may be 10 to 15 leases that may be sold to their competitors.

componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 AMT boxes left to lease up, 1 of them in Staten Island is a large scale, redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through the regular process right now to add over 100,000 square feet up additional density. We haven't executed a l
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 AMT boxes left to lease up, 1 of them in Staten Island is a large scale, redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through the regular process right now to add over 100,000 square feet up additional density. We haven't executed a lease there with a full line growth, but we can't yet disclose who it is because we're still going through the entire process, so that's not going to be a 2017 redevelopment that's a very large scale so we've been pre-leasing but we have yet to disclose it as we go through the entitlements. Home Dell in New Jersey is another  one where we have LOI's going with 2 potential specialty grocers that are bidding on a portion of; the space as well as the best-in-class off-price retailers to cotenant with them to split that box. A third one is in Staten Island, which is probably the last piece of Richmond redevelopment that's where we did the large target redevelopment and this was the last phase. We have a deal improved at RSC committees with retailers to split the 1/4 [ph] best-in-class of specialty grocer to take half of it and another best-in-class off-price user to just take the other half. So final A&P store is actually under contract to be sold to an end-user. They came and approached us to purchase the asset and because of the end users, they're able to really pay a significant price, so we're under contract there so probably that should be closing next quarter.

componenttext: Just a little bit more on Sports Authority I, guess. Do you have an update on kind of the mark-to-market across the 25 stores on average? And I understand what you said about you nearly met your half of those or just directly sold to competitors, but I'm interested in that number anyway. And then for the ones you do get back, do you envision demising spaces? Or are the people you have kind of lined up preliminary, taking it as is and are there any kind of retail segments that are most interested in that size box right now?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back And obviously, it depends site by site. On the releasing side of it, it's going to be again case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's as far
componenttext: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back And obviously, it depends site by site. On the releasing side of it, it's going to be again case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's as far as users to take the whole box and also users to split. Many of the off-price concepts have multiple flags. So they can take the whole box and do multiple uses in that box as well. We also have the opportunity to add grocery to 15 of our 25 locations. So we've obviously, pinned that down in the priority for us to see if we can create some value there as well and we're working with some of the specialty grocers as well as some traditional grocers to take those boxes. So again, the average base rent for all 25 are under $15 a foot. These are all locations that we think are very much in demand and there's very little supply out there. So whether it's going to be a competitor that just buys the lease, and has to live with the existing used cost or is an off-price user or a grocery store, there's also some interest from some of the home improvement sector as well from some of their smaller boxes. So we think we're -- we're cost optimistic that we're going to be in good shape here for the long haul.

componenttext: No. Only 6 of the 25 are going through that process right now. So again, it's a fluid situation. We obviously, are marketing all the boxes. But those are the only 6 that are going through that, going out of the business sale currently.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe just beyond Sports Authority, in your opening comments, you talked about shadow supply, and just curious, it seems like bankers season, Sports Authority notwithstanding has it been all that bad? Just curious, if you're seeing something d
componenttext: Got it. And maybe just beyond Sports Authority, in your opening comments, you talked about shadow supply, and just curious, it seems like bankers season, Sports Authority notwithstanding has it been all that bad? Just curious, if you're seeing something different in terms of store closure expectation and future bankruptcy expectation for the balance of the year?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would agree. We think it's very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it is very, very low and the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-ye
componenttext: We would agree. We think it's very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it is very, very low and the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-year. And when you look at our sector, we are starting to look at shadows to buy a little bit differently. We're starting to look at some of the ball anchor boxes that are possibly coming back as part of our competitors going forward. So we're being cognizant to be aware of it, but overall, it's a very healthy environment. The new leases that are getting done today are really the best-in-class operator. The off-price retailers continue to add store accounts for this brand-new competition coming into that sector. The specialty growth continue to want to add unit count. So we think that we continue to be in this retail. And it's a good time to get boxes back. There's no question about it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. I had 2 questions. The first is around the same-store NOI in the U.S. excluding the redevelopments. You guys reported 0.2% even if I add back the Sports Authority adjustment, it gets up to 1.6. I guess, the question is
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. I had 2 questions. The first is around the same-store NOI in the U.S. excluding the redevelopments. You guys reported 0.2% even if I add back the Sports Authority adjustment, it gets up to 1.6. I guess, the question is, what was going on in the quarter that made that U.S.x read of numbers so low? I would've thought just contractual rent growth and that preleasing spreads would've gotten that number to at least 2.5%?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really dealing with the A&P of the NS -- that we're still - that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for ANS, and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, so they won't start to flow until the second ha
componenttext: It's really dealing with the A&P of the NS -- that we're still - that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for ANS, and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, so they won't start to flow until the second half of the year. So that's where really we start to see the uptick in the same-site NOI. So that's really what we're still dealing with, but we have plenty of opportunity there, plenty of demand. So we think we'll be able to pick that back up so that's why we reinforced our guidance in the same-site NOI.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that and divide your TI spend per year of lease, compared to the new rents that your you're getting the $20 rent, it looks like your TI's ar
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that and divide your TI spend per year of lease, compared to the new rents that your you're getting the $20 rent, it looks like your TI's are running at about 13% of the new annual rent. And I'm just curious, how do you guys think about that number? It seems -- it smells -- I haven't gone back and looked to where it was 5, 10 years ago. It feels a little bit higher than it would've been historically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the tack of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, their ground leases, which will negatively impact our a
componenttext: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the tack of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, their ground leases, which will negatively impact our average base rent, but we think for the long-term it's the best economic deal. So we try and make the retailer investment side of space, and we do the improvements on to the shopping center. So that's an attack that we've taken for a long period of time and we continue to look at that going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Honda with Don Mizuho.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Honda with Don Mizuho.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the asset that you're selling. Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? And
componenttext: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the asset that you're selling. Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? And is there more interest or better pricing on a oneoff or portfolio -- many portfolio basis?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core products. Anything that has a value add o
componenttext: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core products. Anything that has a value add or achievable redevelopment or growth story, there's still an immense amount of capital chasing those deals. When we look at our transactions on the disposition side, I'd say that the biggest challenge that we're finding is generating a deep buyer pool on some of the secondary market assets. The ones that are really stable income streams with no growth and no grocer, I would say that we are seeing a little bit of a more shallow buyer pool. But I think that's sort of where the private REITs are really controlling and being aggressive in that market. So to a certain extent, I think we're missing those buyers, but that being said, we are still getting enough of an auction going where we're able to achieve our cap rates and our objectives. So I think when you compare the cap rates this quarter as Conor mentioned sort of blended, we're still in the very high 6s, may be low 7s in some cases on the dispositions, but we still feel very good about our ability to get that sold. We're not seeing any real material retrading obviously, oneoff opportunities, you'll see them here and there. But I don't think there's any major general trends. So we're optimistic that we'll continue to hit our targets for the rest of the year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any portfolio demand and then any kind of change in cap rates in some of those secondary or tertiary market locations?
componenttext: Any portfolio demand and then any kind of change in cap rates in some of those secondary or tertiary market locations?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We still believe that selling them oneoff is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific typ
componenttext: We still believe that selling them oneoff is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific type of asset or return threshold, whether it's the location, geographies or the tenant profile. Buyers are looking for something very specific. So we've actually seen a bit of a discount for the portfolios that have been in the market. It obviously, takes a little bit longer and there's a lot of blocking and tackling on the oneoffs, but that's how we felt that the tackling has been best for us. So we'll continue with that strategy.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you could just talk a little bit more about equity assurance. Obviously, it's been several years since you guys last issued. And if we should expect more this year? Especially given Milton's focus on getting the company to an A-,  it would seem like gi
componenttext: If you could just talk a little bit more about equity assurance. Obviously, it's been several years since you guys last issued. And if we should expect more this year? Especially given Milton's focus on getting the company to an A-,  it would seem like given where you are relative to NAV that we're likely to see more equity issuance out of you guys to improve the credit standard.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter and the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watch wha
componenttext: Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter and the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watch what's happening with our disposition pipeline, watching the acquisitions side of it. And again, we're very much monitoring very closely what happens with Albertson's because Albertsons is a -- could be a very major component of capital that comes to us without causing any dilution at all. As a matter of fact, it's becoming a very accretive transaction to us. So we are very focused as I mentioned, on continuing to improve balance sheet metrics and bringing leverage down over time. But we're going to do it methodically and opportunistically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then Glenn, as a follow-up, on the transactional income where you guys had -- at the front of the call, that it's late 2016, is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertson's that it will be late '16? That
componenttext: So then Glenn, as a follow-up, on the transactional income where you guys had -- at the front of the call, that it's late 2016, is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertson's that it will be late '16? That's the best -- I'm trying to understand, the best guess versus your confidence that it's going to be late '16?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware of in terms of Albertsons at this time?
componenttext: Well, again, Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware of in terms of Albertsons at this time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Glenn, we're aware of Albertsons as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when -- on our financials for fiscal year and which was the end of February done. So the investors
componenttext: Yes. Glenn, we're aware of Albertsons as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when -- on our financials for fiscal year and which was the end of February done. So the investors and the company's and the management feel that leverages that company its future growth is to be a public company. You have to time it correctly. But your markets are in the right place. It's consideration. Nothing's definite now but we're still focused on moving forward. The company's doing very well, beating our plans on the business, very excited about the future. Obviously, it's something -- whether we want to do it or not, as we saw in October is not necessarily going to be the placeholder if it will happen or not. But they're moving in the right direction, going forward. That's what we're basing our views on.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to finish then, Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity? That's the take away?
componenttext: Okay. So just to finish then, Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity? That's the take away?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as I said Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now again, just to clarify the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period on day 1
componenttext: Again, as I said Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now again, just to clarify the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period on day 1 of an IPO. So you're already in the fourth quarter, and we know it's not happening for a little while longer. That's why my comment there, it wouldn't be any earlier than late in the fourth quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlement to get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO and CFO have held conference calls to see
componenttext: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlement to get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO and CFO have held conference calls to see what their plan was. But fortunately, they missed their plan. And they were part of a redevelopment plan that included, we're doing a brand-new Whole Foods that's one. We're doing Ross, TJX and others on those other 2. So we feel like there's plenty of demand for that box going forward in those redevelopments. And we have not given them any tenant approval in any of those sites. So we have the flexibility to go back and release those boxes if and when they're rejected and they revert back to us. So at the time, they were in Florida, which was their primary market where they were the dominant player at that time. When we spoke, they were the appropriate cotenant. But luckily because of the strength of the other cotenants of our redevelopments, we think that we'll be able to do potentially even better.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let's say, you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there's full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe a comes in and reconfigures the space?
componenttext: And let's say, you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there's full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe a comes in and reconfigures the space?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy by the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the  one that, that'll be rejected, those are the ones that will take some time in terms of
componenttext: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy by the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the  one that, that'll be rejected, those are the ones that will take some time in terms of lease up and build-out -- filling out of the space and it all depends on what you do with a box. If it's a single-tenant user, you probably could get your rent commencement date sooner than when you were to split the box and do a potential multi-tenant type lineup. So it will really depend on what the high best use of that real estate, some of it might be grocery components, some of them might be redevelopment, some of them might be single-tenant users, and it just has to come down to what the best use that we can find.

componenttextpreview: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money from the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunistic
componenttext: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money from the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunistic. And with retail being so challenging these days, we do think that there may be future opportunities. So clearly, we're focused on the Albertsons that we currently have and one create value there before we probably do anything more.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a longer-term our medium-term goal continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be manageable. But if you look at the mortgage debt that we will retain this year, that's close to 6% to take the lever
componenttext: We have a longer-term our medium-term goal continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be manageable. But if you look at the mortgage debt that we will retain this year, that's close to 6% to take the leverage down with the some equity made some sense for us. So I would say we kind of year markets the words debt reduction, leverage reduction less than about the acquisitions. Because most of the acquisition activity is being fueled by proceeds coming from this position activity.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also avail
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton Cooper our Executive Chairman; Dave Jamison, Executive Vice President of Asset Management and Operations; Ross Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Investment Officer; and Ray Edwards, Vice President, overseas, Retail Services business.
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking. It is important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the e
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the execution of all aspects of our strategy as we focus less on short-term earnings and more on creating long-term net asset value. Our disposition and acquisition activity continues to produce a higher-quality portfolio. This higher quality is reflected in our leasing production as we continue to attract premier tenants at higher rents.
Our redevelopment and development activity continues to create value and opportunity, unlocking the highest and best use of the real estates. And we do all of this with a cautious and watchful eye on our balance sheet and our cost of capital.
Now for some details. In the first quarter, we continued to execute on our disposition strategy by closing on $323 million of dispositions in Canada and $114 million of dispositions in the U.S. The blended average cap rate was 6.9% in the first quarter and quality buyers ranging from public REITs, private REITs, local private real estate groups, high-net-worth individuals, international buyers and trade buyers all continue to call through our disposition portfolio.
We are in the ninth inning of our transformation. And with the majority of our Canadian portfolio under contracts and the products to date on our U.S. dispositions, we are on pace to hit our target of $400 million to $475 million of dispositions in the U.S. and $425 million to $500 million in Canada by year-end and complete the transformation of the portfolio.
Turning to acquisitions. Our first quarter concluded with limited volume, reflecting the competitiveness in our target markets. After quarter-end, we did reach agreements to purchase our JV partner's interest in Oakwood Plaza and the adjacent Dania Pointe development site. These sites combined to offer over 2 miles of frontage along I-95 in the Fort Lauderdale-Miami corridor. Oakwood is 100% occupied, but reflects what we look for in our target markets, irreplaceable real estate with below-market rents, significant sales volumes and future redevelopment opportunity. Dania is the adjacent development site that we now control and are happy to take this opportunity to announce the ground lease with Costco to anchor the first phase and kick off the pre-leasing. Both Oakwood and Dania are key building blocks to our 2020 Vision, creating value on larger assets in markets with high barriers to entry. Oakwood is now our #2 NOI producer. And upon stabilization, Dania will be the #1 NOI contributor in the entire portfolio.
The strong leasing demand for quality real estate highlights the positive supply and demand imbalance that the open-air sector is currently enjoying. Keeping occupancy steady at 95.8% over prior quarter validates the portfolio of quality and the quality of our leasing team as we typically experience an early year dip due to post-holiday closings. Retailer demands did not change during the stock market correction in the first quarter, and we continue to see demand across all square footage categories. The volume of new deals this quarter included big-box retailers, grocery stores and off-price retailers, all enhancing the merchandising mix and improving net asset value.
Target, Whole Foods, Giant and Trader Joe's are just a few examples of executed leases this quarter that positively impacts NAV. A high number of our new deals this quarter, including the Target/Whole Foods deals, are taking currently occupied space. So while we will have a short-term hit in same-site NOI and do not pick up any occupancy, we do pick up a material improvement in NAV. In addition, these quality tenants create a halo effect in our centers, which allow Kimco to achieve outsized growth from the surrounding retail.
New leases were signed at an average base rent of $21 a foot, reflecting the embedded mark-to-market opportunities while compared to our current average base rent. Kimco's average base rent is now $14.67, a 4.8% increase over Q1 2015 and a 27.9% increase over Q1 in 2010.
While we are currently enjoying a 38-year low in supply, we are monitoring the shadow supply pipeline closely. Recent bankruptcies and announced store closings, in addition to pending mergers, will be the primary driver of increased supply in the short run for both mall and open-air centers. This is not new to our sector. What is new is that at Kimco today, our transformed high-quality portfolio makes us more ready and better prepared for these situations. That is why we are approaching the Sports Authority liquidation with cautious optimism.
Preliminary indications suggest that there will be significant demand for our boxes, if and when they revert back to us. Redevelopments completed in the first quarter will deliver incremental NOI of $2.3 million with an ROI of 11.5%. Redevelopment remains the best use of our capital, and Kimco's billion-dollar pipeline continues to cycle more projects from the entitlement stage to the active pipeline as additional opportunities are constantly being discovered within the existing portfolio.
The amount of raw material in our portfolio and the focus on value creation has given rise to a shadow pipeline of additional redevelopment projects that account for roughly $2 billion of future projects. Acting upon the embedded opportunity will serve our long-term shareholders by adding value to best-in-class properties.
Turning to development. We recently hit 2 major milestones by securing the Target deal at our Grand Parkway development in Texas, and today, announcing the Costco ground lease at our Dania development project in Florida. These anchors have jump-started the pre-leasing for the first phases of both projects. Due to the lack of new supply and the strong demand from open-air retailers, we continue to aggressively pre-lease our strategic development projects. Each development sites has a phasing plan in place to better monitor and ensure that our investment remains accretive to our cost of capital and to provide off-ramps to keep maximum flexibility.
In closing, we continue to march toward our 2020 vision of being a U.S. focus REIT with large pockets of concentration and high barrier to entry markets. The team is working overtime to unlock value at the property level through lease up and mark-to-market opportunities, continuing to expand and deliver on the redevelopment pipeline and executing on the strategic development pipeline, all while positioning the balance sheet to be in a position of strength now and for the next cycle.
Glenn will now take you through the detail of the first quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients needed to achieve our 2020 Vision. Headline FFO per diluted share, which represents the official NAREIT definition, was $0.38, up from $0.37 last year and $0.01 higher than first call consensus. The improved performance is attributable to a 5.2% increase in U.S. net operating income, which was substantially offset by the reduction in NOI from the Canadian dispositions.
Lower G&A expense and lower financing costs attributable to the redemption of the 6.9% preferred stock last year also contributed to the growth. Included in the headline result is a profit participation from the sale of our Canadian preferred equity investment of $5.5 million. FFO as adjusted or recurring FFO, which excludes nonoperating impairments and transactional income and expense, was $0.37 per diluted share for the first quarter, up from $0.36 last year, a 2.8% increase. We accomplished this growth level despite the $0.03 per share dilutive impact from our portfolio transformation.
The portfolio transformation includes the substantial disposition of assets in Latin America and Canada totaling $900 million and $600 million of U.S. dispositions in just the last 12 months. The diluted impact was more than offset with the reduced financing costs and $1.4 billion of acquisitions of high-quality assets in our key markets. Many of the acquisitions were sourced from our joint venture programs.
Our portfolio operating team delivered solid first quarter results, maintaining our anchored tenant occupancy at 98.2% and increasing small shop space by 40 basis points from 1 year ago to 88.6%.
We remain on target for small shop occupancy to reach 90% by year-end. We continue to deliver strong leasing spreads, up 19.1% for new leases, up 6.3% for renewals and options and 7.5% combined. U.S. same-site NOI growth is 1.5% and includes a credit loss reserve of $3.2 million or 140 basis points related to the bankruptcy filing by Sports Authority. This reserve amount includes 100% of all prepetition amounts and $811,000 of rent from March, which remains unpaid. Even with the short-term impact from Sports Authority, we remain on track and reaffirm our full-year U.S. same-site NOI guidance range of an increase of 2.5% to 3.5%.
Additionally, in an effort to give the analyst and investor community further information for comparability purposes, we have included in our supplemental package the same-site disclosures of straight line rent adjustments, lease termination fees and amortization of above and below market rents.
As part of our 2020 vision, we are laser-focused on further improving our debt metrics with a target of 5 to 5.5x for consolidated net debt through recurring EBITDA and a fixed charge coverage of 3x plus.
In the last 12 months, we have reduced our net debt by $560 million from $5.5 billion to $4.94 billion at March 31. At the end of the first quarter, net debt to recurring EBITDA is 5.9x, down from 6.6x a year ago, and fixed charge coverage came in at 3.2x. We repaid over $400 million of maturing debt during the first quarter, and we paid an additional $117 million of mortgage debt in April, leaving us with just about $250 million in remaining consolidated maturities for the balance of the year.
A portion of the debt repayment was accomplished with $138.5 million of proceeds raised from the issuance of 4.96 million shares of common equity through our ATM program at a weighted average offering price of $28.20 per share during March and April. As another data point, at the end of the first quarter, our total debt to total market capitalization was down to 28%, the lowest level in the past 8 years.
Based on the solid first quarter results, we are reaffirming our headline FFO per share guidance range of $1.54 to $1.62. Please keep in mind that the bulk of the transactional income for 2016 is anticipated to occur late in the fourth quarter. We're also reaffirming our FFO as adjusted per-share guidance range of $1.58 to $1.52 with a midpoint of $1.50 per share in each of our operating guidance assumptions.
And with that, we'd be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, I was wondering if you can just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP? But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership? An
componenttext: Conor, I was wondering if you can just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP? But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership? And then I get your point in terms of wanting to have high pockets of concentration, but it would seem that between Oakwood and Dania, which would rank #1 and #2, that would be a very large concentration in a very concentrated location. So maybe you can just walk through some of the comfort that you got through all that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100% and give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakw
componenttext: Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100% and give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakwood is where we have an office, so we have a physical presence there. And we realize that with Oakwood and Dania, we have a unique opportunity to truly enhance the value of both assets of what we're trying to do, both at Oakwood and at Dania. So we've been proactive with all of our partners, and this one was opportunistic for us to strike and really take CPP out of the transaction early on in this stage. So we were able to buy CPP out of the development side at their basis, which we thought was extremely opportunistic. And now that we have Costco fully executed, we think that it's just the beginning of a strong pre-leasing effort for the first phase. And the second phase, now that we have complete control, gives us the ability to really take a step back and look at what's the highest and best use for the property if we want to sell off parcel, if we want to self-develop more parcels or if we want to do higher density. We have that luxury now, which before, we probably had the inability to do so because of the partnership. So we feel like it gives us more flexibility, and it continues to allow us to focus on larger assets with significant, both, development and redevelopment activity. So that was a little bit of a history there. And in terms of the concentration, you're right that it's going to be in terms of our size, the #1 and #2 producing properties in the portfolio. But we also have tremendous pockets of concentration in California and New York. And with future redevelopments at Westlake and as well as some of our other larger assets, I think that there will be other larger assets that may challenge the #1 and #2 distinction that we've given Dania and Oakwood. So -- and we always want to look to see and make sure we're diversified accordingly. So if it becomes too concentrated, we'll have, hopefully, the luxury of looking at alternative ideas there of what we should do.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Craig, it's Conor. I think that when you look at the -- if you talk about half the Sports Authority boxes, it'll obviously be a case by case situation. But the ones that we have really been heavily marketing, we feel like we have a tremendous amount o
componenttext: Hi, Craig, it's Conor. I think that when you look at the -- if you talk about half the Sports Authority boxes, it'll obviously be a case by case situation. But the ones that we have really been heavily marketing, we feel like we have a tremendous amount of interest on those boxes. So we have LOI's already in place on a number of them. So if you want to just take the 25 and cut it in half, it would probably take us -- probably another quarter or 2 to probably finalize the leases and get half of them fully executed. That being said, we're well aware of the interest levels, other sporting goods operators in the real estate and their lease hold positions. So we anticipate anywhere between, during the auction process, maybe 10 to 15 leases that may be sold to their competitors.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And the next question comes from Jason White with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on your non-cash rents. It looks like those jumped up quite a bit in 1Q. I mean, incrementally, they're up in 4Q as well, but just year-over-year, they're up quite a bit. Is there anything special in there?
componenttext: Just a quick question on your non-cash rents. It looks like those jumped up quite a bit in 1Q. I mean, incrementally, they're up in 4Q as well, but just year-over-year, they're up quite a bit. Is there anything special in there?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing special. What happens is when a tenant leaves that had a below-market rent, and they leave early, you have to take the full amount into occupancy, and we had that in one particular case, so there's several million dollars. It's really what it is,
componenttext: Nothing special. What happens is when a tenant leaves that had a below-market rent, and they leave early, you have to take the full amount into occupancy, and we had that in one particular case, so there's several million dollars. It's really what it is, nothing more than that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then can you just walk through the -- an AMT update in terms of the boxes that you got back and where you're at in releasing those, and actually, turning the keys back over to the tenants to pay rent?
componenttext: Got you. And then can you just walk through the -- an AMT update in terms of the boxes that you got back and where you're at in releasing those, and actually, turning the keys back over to the tenants to pay rent?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 AMT boxes left to lease up, one of them in Staten Island is a large-scale redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through regular process right now to add over 100,000 square feet of additional density. We haven't executed a leas
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 AMT boxes left to lease up, one of them in Staten Island is a large-scale redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through regular process right now to add over 100,000 square feet of additional density. We haven't executed a lease there with the full-line grocer, but we can't yet disclose who it is because we're still going through the entitlement process. So that's going to be a 2017 redevelopment, that's very in large scale. So we've been pre-leasing that, but we have yet to disclose it as we go through the entitlements. Holmdel in New Jersey is another one where we have LOI's going with 2 potential specialty grocers that are bidding on a portion of the space as well as the best-in-class off-price retailers to cotenant with them to split that box. A third one in Staten Island, which is only the last piece of Richmond redevelopment, that's where we did the large Target redevelopment, and this was the last phase. We have deals approved at RAC committees with retailers to split the profits, 1/4 of best-in-class specialty grocer to take half of it and another best-in-class off-price user to just take the other half. So final A&P store is actually under contract to be sold to an end-user. They came and approached us to purchase the asset and because of the end user, he was able to really pay a significant price, so we're under contract there and probably, it should be closing next quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more on Sports Authority, I guess. Do you have an update on kind of the mark-to-market across the 25 stores on average? And I understand what you said about the -- half of those are just directly sold to competitors, but I'm kind of inte
componenttext: Just a little bit more on Sports Authority, I guess. Do you have an update on kind of the mark-to-market across the 25 stores on average? And I understand what you said about the -- half of those are just directly sold to competitors, but I'm kind of interested in that number anyway. And then for the ones you do get back, do you -- would you envision demising spaces? Or are the people you have kind of lined up preliminary taking it as is? And are there any kind of retail segments that are sort of most interested in that size box for you guys right now?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back. And obviously, it depends site by site. On the releasing side of it, it's going to be, again, case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's for
componenttext: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back. And obviously, it depends site by site. On the releasing side of it, it's going to be, again, case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's for our users to take the whole box and also users to split. Many of the off-price concepts have multiple flags. So they can take the whole box and do multiple uses in that box as well. We also have the opportunity to add grocery to 15 of our 25 locations. So we've obviously pinned that down as a priority for us to see that we can create some value there as well, and we're working with some of the specialty grocers as well as traditional grocers to take those boxes. So again, the average base rent for all 25 is under $15 a foot. These are all locations that we think are very much in demand, and there's very little supply out there. So whether it's going to be a competitor that just buys the lease and has to live with the existing used cost or is an off-price user or a grocery store, there's also some interest from some of the home improvement sector, as well from some of their smaller boxes. So we think we're cost optimistic that we're going to be in good shape here for the long haul.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And you mentioned, you reiterated your same-store numbers despite the -- kind of the Q1 impact there. Was there -- I mean, was this type of scenario incorporated maybe in the low end of the range already? Or are there other things that have been, i
componenttext: Great. And you mentioned, you reiterated your same-store numbers despite the -- kind of the Q1 impact there. Was there -- I mean, was this type of scenario incorporated maybe in the low end of the range already? Or are there other things that have been, in the first 4 months, kind of running ahead of plan that kind of led you to that decision?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did have a portion of it in our budget for the first quarter. So we knew our first quarter was going to be challenged in terms of same-site NOI because we are dealing with the A&P, Indiana's as well as the reserve taken for Sports Authority. The lease-
componenttext: We did have a portion of it in our budget for the first quarter. So we knew our first quarter was going to be challenged in terms of same-site NOI because we are dealing with the A&P, Indiana's as well as the reserve taken for Sports Authority. The lease-up continues to be robust, the portfolio, when we look at our pipeline going out, not only in the future, but also looking back. The second half of the year is definitely heavily weighted towards our same-site NOI talk. So that's really what gives us the optimism to keep the guidance unchanged.
