componenttext: Got it. And then maybe just beyond Sports Authority, in your opening comments, you talked about shadow supply. I was just curious, it seems like the bankruptcy season, Sports Authority notwithstanding, has it been all that bad? Just curious, if you're seeing something different in terms of store closure expectations and future bankruptcy expectations with the balance of the year?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would agree. We think it's a very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it's very, very low. And the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-
componenttext: We would agree. We think it's a very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it's very, very low. And the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-year. And when you look at our sector, we are starting to look at shadows to buy a little bit differently. We're starting to look at some of the mall anchor boxes that are possibly coming back as part of our competitors set going forward. So we're being cognizant to be aware of it, but overall, it's a very healthy environment. The new leases that are getting done today are really the best-in-class operators. The off-price retailers continue to add store accounts. There is brand-new competition coming into that sector. The specialty grocers continue to want to add unit count. So we think that we continue to be in the sweet spot of retail, and it's a good time to get boxes back. There's no question about it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. I had 2 questions. The first is around the same-store NOI in the U.S. excluding the redevelopments. You guys reported 0.2%. Even if I add back the Sports Authority adjustment, it gets up to 1.6. I guess, the question i
componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. I had 2 questions. The first is around the same-store NOI in the U.S. excluding the redevelopments. You guys reported 0.2%. Even if I add back the Sports Authority adjustment, it gets up to 1.6. I guess, the question is what was going on in the quarter that made that U.S. x read of number so low? I would've thought just contractual rent growth and pre-leasing spreads would've gotten that number to at least 2.5%.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really dealing with the A&P and the ANS, that we're still -- that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for ANS and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, they won't start to flow until the second half
componenttext: It's really dealing with the A&P and the ANS, that we're still -- that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for ANS and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, they won't start to flow until the second half of the year. So that's where really we start to see the uptick in the same-site NOI. So that's really what we're still dealing with, but we have plenty of opportunity there, plenty of demand. So we think we'll be able to pick that back up, and that's why we reinforced our guidance in same-site NOI.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that, I divide your TI spend per year of lease compared to the new rents that your you're getting, they were the $20 rent, it looks like you
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that, I divide your TI spend per year of lease compared to the new rents that your you're getting, they were the $20 rent, it looks like your TI's are running at about 13% of the new annual rent. And I'm just curious, how do you guys think about that number? It seems -- it smells -- I haven't gone back and looked to where it was 5, 10 years ago, it feels a little higher than where it would have been historically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the task of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, they're ground leases, which will negatively impact our
componenttext: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the task of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, they're ground leases, which will negatively impact our average base rent, but we think, for the long-term, it's the best economic deal. So we try and make the retailer invest inside the base, and we do the improvements on -- to the shopping center. So that's the task that we've taken for a long period of time, and we continue to look at that going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Haendel St. Juste with Mizuho.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Haendel St. Juste with Mizuho.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious, if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the asset that you're selling? Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? And
componenttext: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious, if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the asset that you're selling? Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? And is there more interest or better pricing on a one-off portfolio -- many portfolio basis?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core product. Anything that has a value add or
componenttext: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core product. Anything that has a value add or achievable redevelopment or growth story, there's still an immense amount of capital chasing those deals. When we look at our transactions on the disposition side, I'd say that the biggest challenge that we're finding is generating a deep buyer pool on some of the secondary market assets. The ones that are really stable income streams with no growth and no grocer, I would say that we are seeing a little bit of a more shallow buyer pool. But I think that's sort of where the private REITs were really controlling and being aggressive in that market. So to a certain extent, I think we're missing those buyers, but that being said, we are still getting enough of an auction going where we're able to achieve our cap rates and our objectives. So I think when you compare the cap rates this quarter, as Conor mentioned, sort of blended. We're still in the very high 6s, may be low 7s in some cases on the dispositions, but we still feel very good about our ability to get that sold. We're not seeing any real material re-trading. Obviously, oneoff opportunities, you'll see them here and there. But I don't think there's any major general trends. So we're optimistic that we'll continue to hit our targets for the rest of the year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seeing any portfolio demand, and then any comment on change in cap rates in some of those secondary, tertiary market locations?
componenttext: Seeing any portfolio demand, and then any comment on change in cap rates in some of those secondary, tertiary market locations?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We still believe that selling them one-off is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific ty
componenttext: We still believe that selling them one-off is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific type of asset or return threshold, whether it's the location, geographies or the tenant profile. Buyers were looking for something very specific. So we've actually seen a bit of a discount for the portfolios that have been in the market. It obviously takes a little bit longer, and there's a lot of blocking and tackling on the one-offs, but that's how we felt that tackling has been best for us. So we'll continue with that strategy.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you could just talk a little bit more about equity assurance. Obviously, it's been several years since you guys last issued. And if we should expect more this year, especially given Milton's focus on getting the company to an A-, it would seem like giv
componenttext: If you could just talk a little bit more about equity assurance. Obviously, it's been several years since you guys last issued. And if we should expect more this year, especially given Milton's focus on getting the company to an A-, it would seem like given where you guys are relative to NAV, that we're likely to see more equity issuance out of you guys to improve the credit standard?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter, in the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watch
componenttext: Hi, Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter, in the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watch what's happening with our disposition pipeline, watching the acquisitions side of it. And again, we're very much monitoring very closely what happens with Albertsons, because Albertsons is a -- could be a very major component of capital that comes to us without causing any dilution at all. As a matter of fact, it would become a very accretive transaction to us. So we are very focused, as I mentioned, on continuing to improve balance sheet metrics and bringing leverage down over time. But we're going to do it methodically and opportunistically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then, Glenn, as a -- then as a follow-up on the transactional income where you guys said, on the front of the call, that it's late 2016. Is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertsons that it will be lat
componenttext: So then, Glenn, as a -- then as a follow-up on the transactional income where you guys said, on the front of the call, that it's late 2016. Is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertsons that it will be late '16? That's the best. So trying to understand best guess versus your confidence that it's going to be late '16?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again -- Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware in terms of Albertsons at this time?
componenttext: Well, again -- Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware in terms of Albertsons at this time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, Glenn. [indiscernible] with Albertsons, as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when [indiscernible] financials for fiscal year and which was the end of February done.
componenttext: Yes. Hi, Glenn. [indiscernible] with Albertsons, as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when [indiscernible] financials for fiscal year and which was the end of February done. So the investors and the company's management feel that obviously the best direction for the company's future growth is to be a public company. You have to time it correctly. But markets are in the right place. It's consideration. Nothing's definite now, but we're still focused on moving forward. The company's doing very well, beating their plans on the business, very excited about the future. Obviously, it's something -- whether we want to do it or not, as we saw in October, is not necessarily going to be the placeholder if it will happen or not. But they're moving in the right direction going forward. That's what we're basing our views on.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to finish then. Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity. That's the take away?
componenttext: Okay. So just to finish then. Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity. That's the take away?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as I said, Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan, and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now -- again, just to clarifying the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period o
componenttext: Again, as I said, Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan, and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now -- again, just to clarifying the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period on day 1 of an IPO. So you're already in the fourth quarter, and we know it's not happening for a little while longer. That's why my comment that it wouldn't be any earlier than late in the fourth quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's one more question on Sports Authority, if you don't mind. Your company with low on profits has the Sports Authority's and the other one has hhgregg. But just curious, how did those projects -- those bad tenants end up in your projects? Was it just
componenttext: There's one more question on Sports Authority, if you don't mind. Your company with low on profits has the Sports Authority's and the other one has hhgregg. But just curious, how did those projects -- those bad tenants end up in your projects? Was it just the high renter they were going to pay? Or was it an assumptions that may be they were healthier than they seem to be at that time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlements and get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO, their CFO and held the conference call
componenttext: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlements and get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO, their CFO and held the conference calls to see what their plan was. Unfortunately, they missed their plan. And they were part of a redevelopment plan that included -- we're doing a brand-new Whole Foods at one. We're doing Ross, TJX and others on those other 2. So we feel like there's plenty of demand for that box going forward in those redevelopments. And we have not given them any tenant approval, Alex, on any of those sites. So we have the flexibility to go back and release those boxes if and when they're rejected and they revert back to us. So at the time, they were in Florida, which was their primary market, where they were the dominant player at that time. When we spoke, they were the appropriate cotenant. But luckily, because of the strength of the other cotenants of our redevelopments, we think that we'll be able to do potentially even better.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And let's say you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there is full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe as DICK's comes in and reconfigures the space?
componenttext: Okay. And let's say you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there is full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe as DICK's comes in and reconfigures the space?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then -- and we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the ones that, that'll be rejected, those are the ones that'll take some time in terms o
componenttext: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then -- and we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the ones that, that'll be rejected, those are the ones that'll take some time in terms of lease-up and build-out, filling out of the space, and it all depends on what you do with the box. If it's a single-tenant user, you probably can get your rent commencement date sooner than if you were to split the box and do a potential multi-tenant-type lineup. So it will really depend on what the highest and best use for that real estate. Some of them might be grocery components, some of them might be redevelopment, some of them might be single-tenant users, and it just has to come down to what the best use that we can find.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does this look right now, [indiscernible]? [indiscernible] said might be reassigned or bought? Will they really buy the lease or is there more incentive for like the retailer like DICK's to just wait it out?
componenttext: And how does this look right now, [indiscernible]? [indiscernible] said might be reassigned or bought? Will they really buy the lease or is there more incentive for like the retailer like DICK's to just wait it out?

componenttext: Conor, it's Ray. I mean, the thing is that there are -- the 2 big sporting goods stores that are both circling the company. So the way to get the store is might be to be buying them through the bankruptcy versus [indiscernible], then we can decide which one we want to [indiscernible], for example. So since there is lively bidding between 2 major sporting goods stores, they have to keep the hat in the game and not wait to see who comes back and cut a deal with us.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Vineet Khanna with Capital One.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Vineet Khanna with Capital One.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a role for the PLUS business in the current retail landscape specifically as it pertains to bankruptcy resolution?
componenttext: Is there a role for the PLUS business in the current retail landscape specifically as it pertains to bankruptcy resolution?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ray?
componenttext: Ray?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money through the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunis
componenttext: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money through the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunistic. And with retail being so challenging these days, we do think that there may be future opportunities. But clearly, we're focused on the Albertsons that we currently have and want to create value there before we probably do anything more.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then just following up on that -- on the prior comments about some of the bidders for the Sports Authority's. Would Kimco sort of consider playing a role in the liquidation of Sports Authority via the PLUS business?
componenttext: Sure. And then just following up on that -- on the prior comments about some of the bidders for the Sports Authority's. Would Kimco sort of consider playing a role in the liquidation of Sports Authority via the PLUS business?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, probably not. I mean, Ray, you can talk a little bit more.
componenttext: At this point in time, probably not. I mean, Ray, you can talk a little bit more.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the PLUS business bankruptcy is -- a lot of times the retailers own a lot of the real estate and in Sports Authority, they own like in 1 property actually in Pennsylvania, and I am looking at that one. But this is a purely really a lease port
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the PLUS business bankruptcy is -- a lot of times the retailers own a lot of the real estate and in Sports Authority, they own like in 1 property actually in Pennsylvania, and I am looking at that one. But this is a purely really a lease portfolio. You have the [indiscernible] the highest bidders for that. For us, what this play out? We don't want to chase every deal just to say we're in the PLUS business to make sure it's very profitable.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I just want to confirm that partner buyouts, they are included in the acquisition guidance. And if so, we are looking to the balance of the year, do you expect more buyouts or to be more skewed toward third-party acquisitions?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are included in our guidance, the JV partner buyouts. It'll probably be a mix. We'd like to say that we have other may be potential JV portfolio buyout, but it will probably be more likely where it's just one-off situations where similar to an Oakwoo
componenttext: They are included in our guidance, the JV partner buyouts. It'll probably be a mix. We'd like to say that we have other may be potential JV portfolio buyout, but it will probably be more likely where it's just one-off situations where similar to an Oakwood and Dania, where we go case-by-case and try and buy individual assets that we can create a lot of value on.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Rich Moore with RBC.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that you've essentially got everything under contract in Canada venture out of it already, have you had any further thoughts on the bonds -- the 2 bonds that you have up there? And whether it's time to do something to get rid of those?
componenttext: Now that you've essentially got everything under contract in Canada venture out of it already, have you had any further thoughts on the bonds -- the 2 bonds that you have up there? And whether it's time to do something to get rid of those?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, Rich, it's Glenn. We continue to evaluate the bonds themselves. Although we do have a lot of things under contract, we really wouldn't want the capital in hand before we start to make decisions about pulling those bonds. So we have to play it out
componenttext: Yes. Hi, Rich, it's Glenn. We continue to evaluate the bonds themselves. Although we do have a lot of things under contract, we really wouldn't want the capital in hand before we start to make decisions about pulling those bonds. So we have to play it out for another quarter or so, but it's definitely on the table, it's something we're evaluating.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is it safe, Glenn, to say if you do get out of Canada entirely, there's no sense for those bonds to stay on. Is that right?
componenttext: Okay. Is it safe, Glenn, to say if you do get out of Canada entirely, there's no sense for those bonds to stay on. Is that right?

componenttextpreview: I would agree with that, yes. I think everyone would agree with that.
componenttext: I would agree with that, yes. I think everyone would agree with that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And the next question is a follow-up from Michael Bilerman with Citi.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. Glenn, just on the equity. The guidance, if you just take your gross FFO divided by your per share FFO, it's about 419 million average shares. I think you're effectively with the late 1Q and 2Q issuance, call it, about 418 million. So m
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. Glenn, just on the equity. The guidance, if you just take your gross FFO divided by your per share FFO, it's about 419 million average shares. I think you're effectively with the late 1Q and 2Q issuance, call it, about 418 million. So maybe to get to the average, you may have like $15 million left in your guidance of issuance. Is that sort of right? And so we should think about anything above that level as having some potential impact accretive or dilutive of how you use the proceeds?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, first of all, you have to remember, we do have option exercises still from when we were still doing that. So some of that money continues to come in. You have issuances that come from our drift as well. So there's a very -- to your point, the
componenttext: Yes. I mean, first of all, you have to remember, we do have option exercises still from when we were still doing that. So some of that money continues to come in. You have issuances that come from our drift as well. So there's a very -- to your point, there's a very, very modest amount that would remain, but it's tiny at this point.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the goal in terms of capping the ATM in the quarter was -- even though you have all this disposition activity, was to sort of keep some leverage neutrality as you sort of did Oakwood and Dania. I mean, what really drove the $115 million? Was it levera
componenttext: And the goal in terms of capping the ATM in the quarter was -- even though you have all this disposition activity, was to sort of keep some leverage neutrality as you sort of did Oakwood and Dania. I mean, what really drove the $115 million? Was it leverage-driven? Was its stock price driven in terms of the fact that you were above 28? How should we think about the rationale for capping the ATM?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a longer-term or medium-term goal of continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be fungible. But if you look at the amount of mortgage debt that we will retain this year at close to 6% to take the
componenttext: We have a longer-term or medium-term goal of continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be fungible. But if you look at the amount of mortgage debt that we will retain this year at close to 6% to take the leverage down with the some equity made some sense for us. So I would say we kind of earmarked towards debt reduction, leverage reduction less than about the acquisitions, because most of the acquisition activity is being fueled by proceeds coming from disposition activity.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And just last one, Conor, and I may have missed this, but the releasing spreads softened a little bit in the first quarter from recent trends. headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first quarter definitely has more renewals and options in terms of the total pie when you look at the combined leasing spreads. So it does weigh on the combined leasing spreads. But overall, we still feel very confident that we can deliver a high sing
componenttext: The first quarter definitely has more renewals and options in terms of the total pie when you look at the combined leasing spreads. So it does weigh on the combined leasing spreads. But overall, we still feel very confident that we can deliver a high single-digit, low double-digit combined leasing spread going forward. We still think there's lots of opportunities to unlock value in mark-to-market opportunities there.

Good morning, and welcome to the Kimco First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.
I now would like to turn the conference over to David Bujnicki. Mr. Bujnicki, please go ahead.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also avail
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Glenn Cohen, CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton Cooper our Executive Chairman; Dave Jamison, Executive Vice President of Asset Management and Operations; Ross Cooper, Executive Vice President and Chief Investment Officer; and Ray Edwards, Vice President, overseas, Retail Services business.
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking. It is important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the e
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we plan to keep our prepared remarks short and sweet. We are firing on all cylinders as we drive toward achieving our 2020 vision and focus on long-term shareholder value. The first quarter highlights the execution of all aspects of our strategy as we focus less on short-term earnings and more on creating long-term net asset value. Our disposition and acquisition activity continues to produce a higher-quality portfolio. This higher quality is reflected in our leasing production as we continue to attract premier tenants at higher rents.
Our redevelopment and development activity continues to create value and opportunity, unlocking the highest and best use of the real estate. And we do all of this with a cautious and watchful eye on our balance sheet and our cost of capital.
Now for some details. In the first quarter, we continued to execute on our disposition strategy by closing on $323 million of dispositions in Canada and $114 million of dispositions in the U.S. The blended average cap rate was 6.9% in the first quarter and quality buyers ranging from public REITs, private REITs, local private real estate groups, high-net-worth individuals, international buyers and trade buyers all continue to cull through our disposition portfolio.
We are in the ninth inning of our transformation. And with the majority of our Canadian portfolio under contract and the progress to date on our U.S. dispositions, we are on pace to hit our target of $400 million to $475 million of dispositions in the U.S. and $425 million to $500 million in Canada by year-end and complete the transformation of the portfolio.
Turning to acquisitions. Our first quarter concluded with limited volume, reflecting the competitiveness in our target markets. After quarter-end, we did reach agreements to purchase our JV partner's interest in Oakwood Plaza and the adjacent Dania Pointe development site. These sites combine to offer over 2 miles of frontage along I-95 in the Fort Lauderdale-Miami corridor. Oakwood is 100% occupied, but reflects what we look for in our target markets, irreplaceable real estate with below-market rents, significant sales volumes and future redevelopment opportunity. Dania is the adjacent development site that we now control and are happy to take this opportunity to announce the ground lease with Costco to anchor the first phase and kick off the pre-leasing. Both Oakwood and Dania are key building blocks to our 2020 Vision, creating value on larger assets in markets with high barriers to entry. Oakwood is now our #2 NOI producer. And upon stabilization, Dania will be the #1 NOI contributor in the entire portfolio.
The strong leasing demand for quality real estate highlights the positive supply and demand imbalance that the open-air sector is currently enjoying. Keeping occupancy steady at 95.8% over prior quarter validates the portfolio quality and the quality of our leasing team as we typically experience an early year dip due to post-holiday closings. Retailer demands did not change during the stock market correction in the first quarter, and we continue to see demand across all square footage categories. The volume of new deals this quarter included big-box retailers, grocery stores and off-price retailers, all enhancing the merchandising mix and improving net asset value.
Target, Whole Foods, Giant and Trader Joe's are just a few examples of executed leases this quarter that positively impact NAV. A high number of our new deals this quarter, including the Target and Whole Foods deals, are taking currently occupied space. So while we will have a short-term hit in same-site NOI and do not pick up any occupancy, we do pick up a material improvement in NAV. In addition, these quality tenants create a halo effect at our centers, which allow Kimco to achieve outsized growth from the surrounding retail.
New leases were signed at an average base rent of $21 a foot, reflecting the embedded mark-to-market opportunities when compared to our current average base rent. Kimco's average base rent is now $14.67, a 4.8% increase over Q1 2015 and a 27.9% increase over Q1 in 2010.
While we are currently enjoying a 38-year low in supply, we are monitoring the shadow supply pipeline closely. Recent bankruptcies and announced store closings, in addition to pending mergers, will be the primary driver of increased supply in the short run for both malls and open-air centers. This is not new to our sector. What is new is that at Kimco today, our transformed high-quality portfolio makes us more ready and better prepared for these situations. That is why we are approaching the Sports Authority liquidation with cautious optimism.
Preliminary indications suggest that we will be significant demand for our boxes if and when they revert back to us. Redevelopments completed in the first quarter will deliver incremental NOI of $2.3 million with an ROI of 11.5%. Redevelopment remains the best use of our capital, and Kimco's billion-dollar pipeline continues to cycle more projects from the entitlement stage to the active pipeline as additional opportunities are constantly being discovered within the existing portfolio.
The amount of raw material in our portfolio and the focus on value creation has given rise to a shadow pipeline of additional redevelopment projects that account for roughly $2 billion of future projects. Acting upon the embedded opportunity will serve our long-term shareholders by adding value to best-in-class properties.
Turning to development. We recently hit 2 major milestones by securing the Target deal at our Grand Parkway development in Texas, and today, announcing the Costco ground lease at our Dania development project in Florida. These anchors have jump-started the pre-leasing for the first phases of both projects. Due to the lack of new supply and the strong demand from open-air retailers, we continue to aggressively pre-lease our strategic development projects. Each development site has a phasing plan in place to better monitor and ensure that our investment remains accretive to our cost of capital and to provide off-ramps to keep maximum flexibility.
In closing, we continue to march toward our 2020 vision of being a U.S.-focused REIT with large pockets of concentration in high barrier to entry markets. The team is working overtime to unlock value at the property level through lease up and mark-to-market opportunities, continuing to expand and deliver on the redevelopment pipeline and executing on the strategic development pipeline, all while positioning the balance sheet to be in a position of strength now and for the next cycle.
Glenn will now take you through the detail of the first quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor, and good morning. 2016 is off to a solid start. We continue to execute on all fronts: leasing, dispositions, redevelopment and development activity and further strengthening of our balance sheet metrics. These are the primary ingredients needed to achieve our 2020 Vision. Headline FFO per diluted share, which represents the official NAREIT definition, was $0.38, up from $0.37 last year and $0.01 higher than first call consensus. The improved performance is attributable to a 5.2% increase in U.S. net operating income, which was substantially offset by the reduction in NOI from the Canadian dispositions.
Lower G&A expense and lower financing costs attributable to the redemption of the 6.9% preferred stock last year also contributed to the growth. Included in the headline result is a profit participation from the sale of a Canadian preferred equity investment of $5.5 million. FFO as adjusted or recurring FFO, which excludes nonoperating impairments and transactional income and expense, was $0.37 per diluted share for the first quarter, up from $0.36 last year, a 2.8% increase. We accomplished this growth level despite the $0.03 per share dilutive impact from our portfolio transformation.
The portfolio transformation includes the substantial disposition of assets in Latin America and Canada totaling $900 million and $600 million of U.S. dispositions in just the last 12 months. The diluted impact was more than offset with the reduced financing costs and $1.4 billion of acquisitions of high-quality assets in our key markets. Many of the acquisitions were sourced from our joint venture programs.
Our portfolio operating team delivered solid first quarter results, maintaining our anchor tenant occupancy at 98.2% and increasing small shop space by 40 basis points from 1 year ago to 88.6%.
We remain on target for small shop occupancy to reach 90% by year-end. We continue to deliver strong leasing spreads, up 19.1% for new leases, up 6.3% for renewals and options and 7.5% combined. U.S. same-site NOI growth is 1.5% and includes a credit loss reserve of $3.2 million or 140 basis points related to the bankruptcy filing by Sports Authority. This reserve amount includes 100% of all pre-petition amounts and $811,000 of rent from March, which remains unpaid. Even with the short-term impact from Sports Authority, we remain on track and reaffirm our full-year U.S. same-site NOI guidance range of an increase of 2.5% to 3.5%.
Additionally, in an effort to give the analyst and investor community further information for comparability purposes, we have included in our supplemental package the same-site disclosures of straight line rent adjustments, lease termination fees and amortization of above and below market rents.
As part of our 2020 vision, we are laser-focused on further improving our debt metrics with a target of 5 to 5.5x for consolidated net debt through recurring EBITDA and a fixed charge coverage of 3x plus.
In the last 12 months, we have reduced our net debt by $560 million from $5.5 billion to $4.94 billion at March 31. At the end of the first quarter, net debt to recurring EBITDA is 5.9x, down from 6.6x a year ago, and fixed charge coverage came in at 3.2x. We repaid over $400 million of maturing debt during the first quarter, and we paid an additional $117 million of mortgage debt in April, leaving us with just about $250 million in remaining consolidated maturities for the balance of the year.
A portion of the debt repayment was accomplished with $138.5 million of proceeds raised from the issuance of 4.96 million shares of common equity through our ATM program at a weighted average offering price of $28.20 per share during March and April. As another data point, at the end of the first quarter, our total debt to total market capitalization was down to 28%, the lowest level in the past 8 years.
Based on the solid first quarter results, we are reaffirming our headline FFO per share guidance range of $1.54 to $1.62. Please keep in mind that the bulk of the transactional income for 2016 is anticipated to occur late in the fourth quarter. We're also reaffirming our FFO as adjusted per-share guidance range of $1.48 to $1.52 with a midpoint of $1.50 per share in each of our operating guidance assumptions.
And with that, we'd be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, I was wondering if you can just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP? But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership? An
componenttext: Conor, I was wondering if you can just spend some time on Oakwood and Dania, just from the perspective of who approached who. Whether it was you or CPP? But also, how the development was effectively valued versus going forward with it as a partnership? And then I get your point in terms of wanting to have high pockets of concentration, but it would seem that between Oakwood and Dania, which would rank #1 and #2, that would be a very large concentration in a very concentrated location. So maybe you can just walk through some of the comfort that you got through all that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100% and give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakw
componenttext:
Sure, happy to. Oakwood and Dania, we've been very proactive with our partners. As you know, one of our strategies is to really own more of our assets 100% and give us total control of our destiny. And this especially was true with Oakwood and Dania. Oakwood is where we have an office, so we have a physical presence there. And we realize that with Oakwood and Dania, we have a unique opportunity to truly enhance the value of both assets with what we're trying to do, both at Oakwood and at Dania. So we've been proactive with all of our partners, and this one was opportunistic for us to strike and really take CPP out of the transaction early on in this stage. So we were able to buy CPP out of the development side at their basis, which we thought was extremely opportunistic. And now that we have Costco fully executed, we think that it's just the beginning of a strong pre-leasing effort for the first phase. And the second phase, now that we have complete control, gives us the ability to really take a step back and look at what's the highest and best use for the property if we want to sell off parcels, if we want to self-develop more parcels or if we want to do higher density. We have that luxury now, which before, we probably had the inability to do so because of the partnership. So we feel like it gives us more flexibility, and it continues to allow us to focus on larger assets with significant, both development and redevelopment activity. So that was a little bit of a history there. 
And in terms of the concentration, you're right that it's going to be in terms of our size, the #1 and #2 producing properties in the portfolio. But we also have tremendous pockets of concentration in California and New York. And with future redevelopments at Westlake and as well as some of our other larger assets, I think that there will be other larger assets that may challenge the #1 and #2 distinction that we've given Dania and Oakwood. So -- and we always want to look to see and make sure we're diversified accordingly. So if it becomes too concentrated, we'll have, hopefully, the luxury of looking at alternative ideas there of what we should do.

componenttext: Hi, Craig, it's Conor. I think that when you look at the -- if you talk about half the Sports Authority boxes, it'll obviously be a case by case situation. But the ones that we have really been heavily marketing we feel like we have a tremendous amount of interest on those boxes. So we have LOI's already in place on a number of them. So if you want to just take the 25 and cut it in half, it would probably take us -- probably another quarter or 2 to probably finalize the leases and get half of them fully executed. That being said, we're well aware of the interest levels of other sporting goods operators in the real estate and their leasehold positions. So we anticipate anywhere between, during the auction process, maybe 10 to 15 leases that may be sold to their competitors.

componenttext: Nothing special. What happens is when a tenant leaves that had a below-market rent, and they leave early, you have to take the full amount into occupancy, and we had that in one particular case, so it was several million dollars. It's really what it is, nothing more than that.

componenttext: Got you. And then can you just walk through the -- an A&P update in terms of the boxes that you got back and where you're at in releasing those, and actually, turning the keys back over to the tenants to pay rent?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 A&P boxes left to lease up, one of them in Staten Island is a large-scale redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through u-layer [ph] process right now to add over 100,000 square feet of additional density. We have an executed a
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. We have 4 A&P boxes left to lease up, one of them in Staten Island is a large-scale redevelopment Hylan Plaza. We're going through u-layer [ph] process right now to add over 100,000 square feet of additional density. We have an executed a lease there with the full-line grocer, but we can't yet disclose who it is because we're still going through the entitlement process. So that's going to be a 2017 redevelopment, that's very large in scale. So we've been pre-leasing that, but we have yet to disclose it as we go through the entitlements. Holmdel in New Jersey is another one where we have LOI's going with 2 potential specialty grocers that are bidding on a portion of the space as well as the best-in-class off-price retailers to co-tenant with them to split that box. A third one in Staten Island, which is only the last piece of Richmond redevelopment, that's where we did the large Target redevelopment, and this was the last phase. We have deals approved at REC committees with retailers to split the box, 1 for a best-in-class specialty grocer to take half of it and another best-in-class off-price user to take the other half. The final A&P store is actually under contract to be sold to an end-user. They came and approached us to purchase the asset and because of the end user is able to really pay a significant price, so we're under contract there and probably should be closing next quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And the next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more on Sports Authority, I guess. Do you have an update on kind of the mark-to-market across the 25 stores on average? And I understand what you said about the -- half of those are just directly sold to competitors, but I'm kind of inte
componenttext: Just a little bit more on Sports Authority, I guess. Do you have an update on kind of the mark-to-market across the 25 stores on average? And I understand what you said about the -- half of those are just directly sold to competitors, but I'm kind of interested in that number anyway. And then for the ones you do get back, do you -- would you envision demising spaces? Or are the people you have kind of lined up preliminary taking it as is? And are there any kind of retail segments that are sort of most interested in that size box for you guys right now?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back. And obviously, it depends site by site. On the re-leasing side of it, it's going to be, again, case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's fo
componenttext: Yes. The mark-to-market overall is around 5% to 10%, so we do have some upside depending on which stores we get back. And obviously, it depends site by site. On the re-leasing side of it, it's going to be, again, case-by-case scenario. We do have LOI's for our users to take the whole box and also users to split. Many of the off-price concepts have multiple flags. So they can take the whole box and do multiple uses in that box as well. We also have the opportunity to add grocery to 15 of our 25 locations. So we've obviously pinned that down as a priority for us to see that we can create some value there as well, and we're working with some of the specialty grocers as well as traditional grocers to take those boxes. So again, the average base rent for all 25 is under $15 a foot. These are all locations that we think are very much in demand, and there's very little supply out there. So whether it's going to be a competitor that just buys the lease and has to live with the existing use clause or is an off-price user or a grocery store, there's also some interest from some of the home improvement sector, as well from some of their smaller boxes. So we think we're -- we have cautious optimism that we're going to be in good shape here for the long haul.

The second half of the year is definitely heavily weighted towards our same-site NOI top. So that's really what gives us the optimism to keep the guidance unchanged.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would agree. We think it's a very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it's very, very low. And the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-
componenttext: We would agree. We think it's a very healthy environment right now. If you look at the overall supply, it's very, very low. And the bankruptcy filings that you've seen and the store closings are relatively modest, especially when you compare it year-over-year. And when you look at our sector, we are starting to look at shadow supply a little bit differently. We're starting to look at some of the mall anchor boxes that are possibly coming back as part of our competitive set going forward. So we're being cognizant to be aware of it, but overall, it's a very healthy environment. The new leases that are getting done today are with really the best-in-class operators. The off-price retailers continue to add store counts. There is brand-new competition coming into that sector. The specialty grocers continue to want to add unit count. So we think that we continue to be in the sweet spot of retail, and it's a good time to get boxes back. There's no question about it.

componenttext: It's Ross Nussbaum here with Jeremy. I had 2 questions. The first is around the same-store NOI in the U.S. excluding the redevelopments. You guys reported 0.2%. And even if I add back the Sports Authority adjustment, it gets up to 1.6%. I guess, the question is what was going on in the quarter that made that U.S. x redev number so low? I would've thought just contractual rent growth and re-leasing spreads would've gotten that number to at least 2.5%.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really dealing with the A&P and the Anna's, that we're still -- that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for Anna's and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, they won't start to flow until the second
componenttext: It's really dealing with the A&P and the Anna's, that we're still -- that have not yet hit the flow. So if you look at the executed leases that we have for Anna's and the pending deals we have working on the A&Ps, they won't start to flow until the second half of the year. So that's where really we start to see the uptick in the same-site NOI. So that's really what we're still dealing with, but we have plenty of opportunity there, plenty of demand. So we think we'll be able to pick that back up, and that's why we reinforced our guidance in same-site NOI.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that, I divide your TI spend per year of lease compare it to the new rents that your you're getting, the -- really the $20 rent, it looks li
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then related question. I was looking at your tenant improvement, your TI spend, and if I look at that, I divide your TI spend per year of lease compare it to the new rents that your you're getting, the -- really the $20 rent, it looks like your TI's are running at about 13% of the new annual rent. And I'm just curious, how do you guys think about that number? It seems -- it smells -- I haven't gone back and looked to where it was 5, 10 years ago, it feels a little higher than where it would have been historically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the tack of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, they're ground leases, they're -- which will negatively
componenttext: It's actually lower if you look at it sequentially. I mean, we always tend to take the tack of trying to invest less in the retailer and more in the real estate. So if you look at a lot of our deals, they're ground leases, they're -- which will negatively impact our average base rent, but we think for the long-term it's the best economic deal. So we try and make the retailer invest inside of the space, and we do the improvements on -- to the shopping center. So that's the tack that we've taken for a long period of time, and we continue to look at that going forward.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Haendel St. Juste with Mizuho.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Haendel St. Juste with Mizuho.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious, if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the assets that you're selling? Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? An
componenttext: A question on the asset sales. Given your year-to-date activity there, just curious, if you're seeing any impact of widening CMBS spreads on pricing or demand for the assets that you're selling? Are we getting any pushback on pricing getting re-traded? And is there more interest or better pricing on a one-off or portfolio, mini portfolio basis?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core product. Anything that has a value add or
componenttext: Sure. This is Ross. I'm happy to jump in. I think that when you look at sort of a transactional environment in general, we're definitely seeing continued strength in competition and aggressive pricing for the core product. Anything that has a value add or achievable redevelopment or growth story, there's still an immense amount of capital chasing those deals. When we look at our transactions on the disposition side, I'd say that the biggest challenge that we're finding is generating a deep buyer pool on some of the secondary market assets. The ones that are really stable income streams with no growth and no grocer, I would say that we are seeing a little bit of a more shallow buyer pool. But I think that's sort of where the private REITs were really controlling and being aggressive in that market. So to a certain extent, I think we're missing those buyers, but that being said, we are still getting enough of an auction going where we're able to achieve our cap rates and our objectives. So I think when you compare the cap rates this quarter, as Conor mentioned, sort of blended. We're still in the very high 6s, maybe low 7s in some cases on the dispositions, but we still feel very good about our ability to get that sold. We're not seeing any real material re-trading. Obviously, one-off opportunities, you'll see them here and there. But I don't think there's any major general trends. So we're optimistic that we'll continue to hit our targets for the rest of the year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seeing any portfolio demand, and then any comment on change in cap rates in some of those secondary, tertiary market locations?
componenttext: Seeing any portfolio demand, and then any comment on change in cap rates in some of those secondary, tertiary market locations?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We still believe that selling them one-off is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific ty
componenttext: We still believe that selling them one-off is the best way to achieve our pricing. We have not seen any real premium for portfolios that have been out in the marketplace. I think when you look at the buyer pool, everybody is looking for a very specific type of asset or return threshold, whether it's the location, geographics or the tenant profile. Buyers were looking for something very specific. So we've actually seen a bit of a discount for the portfolios that have been in the market. It obviously takes a little bit longer, and there's a lot of blocking and tackling on the one-offs, but that's how we felt that tackling it has been best for us. So we'll continue with that strategy.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: If you could just talk a little bit more about equity assurance. Obviously, it's been several years since you guys last issued. And if we should expect more this year, especially given Milton's focus on getting the company to an A-, it would seem like given where you guys are relative to NAV, that we're likely to see more equity issuance out of you guys to improve the credit standing?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter, in the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now, we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watc
componenttext: Hi, Alex, its Glenn. The equity that we raised in the first quarter, in the beginning part of the second quarter was really in line with what we had budgeted in terms of our overall capital plan. Now, we continue to monitor the market. We continue to watch what's happening with our disposition pipeline, watching the acquisitions side of it. And again, we're very much monitoring very closely what happens with Albertsons, because Albertsons is a -- could be a very major component of capital that comes to us without causing any dilution at all. As a matter of fact, it would become a very accretive transaction to us. So we are very focused, as I mentioned, on continuing to improve balance sheet metrics and bringing leverage down over time. But we're going to do it methodically and opportunistically.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then, Glenn, as a -- then as a follow-up on the transactional income where you guys said that, on the front of the call, that it's late 2016. Is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertsons that it will b
componenttext: So then, Glenn, as a -- then as a follow-up on the transactional income where you guys said that, on the front of the call, that it's late 2016. Is that just sort of a placeholder? Or do you have certainty as far as the timing of Albertsons that it will be late '16? Or that's the best -- so trying to understand best guess versus your confidence that it's going to be late '16?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again -- Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware in terms of Albertsons at this time?
componenttext: Well, again -- Ray, do you want to talk a little bit about just what you're aware in terms of Albertsons at this time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Hi, everyone. What's going on with Albertsons, as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when our audit of our financials for our fiscal year, which was the end of February,
componenttext: Yes. Hi, everyone. What's going on with Albertsons, as you know, the S1 that was filed back in -- last summer has -- was updated in January and will be updated next month when our audit of our financials for our fiscal year, which was the end of February, are done. So the investors and the company, and the management feel that obviously the best direction for the company's future growth is to be a public company. You have to time it correctly. But if your markets are in the right place, there's consideration. Nothing's definite now, but we're still focused on moving forward. The company's doing very well, beating their plans on the business, very excited about the future. Obviously, it's something -- whether we want to do it or not, as we saw in October, is not necessarily going to be the placeholder if it will happen or not. But they're moving in the right direction going forward. That's what we're basing our views on.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just to finish then. Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity. That's the take away?
componenttext: Okay. So just to finish then. Glenn, so you guys may do more equity if you don't do Albertsons. But if you do Albertsons, then no need for equity. That's the take away?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, as I said, Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan, and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now -- again, just to clarifying the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period o
componenttext: Again, as I said, Alex, we are monitoring the overall capital plan, and we'll do it methodically and opportunistically. Now -- again, just to clarifying the last point of the timing. We're already in the middle of April. There's a 180-day lockout period on day 1 of an IPO. So you're already in the fourth quarter, and we know it's not happening for a little while longer. That's why my comment that it wouldn't be any earlier than late in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: There's one more question on Sports Authority, if you don't mind. You know your -- a couple of your redevelopment projects has the Sports Authority's and the other one has h.h. gregg. But just curious, how did those projects -- those bad tenants end up in your projects? Was it just the high renter they were willing to pay? Or was it an assumptions that may be they were healthier than they seem to be at that time?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlements and get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO, their CFO and held conference calls to
componenttext: The leases were signed over a year ago. So redevelopments usually take a long time to get entitlements and get going. So these were done at a time where we did a thorough review of their business plan with their CEO, their CFO and held conference calls to see what their plan was. Unfortunately, they missed their plan. And they were part of a redevelopment plan that included -- we're doing a brand-new Whole Foods at one. We're doing Ross, TJX and others on those other 2. So we feel like there's plenty of demand for that box going forward in those redevelopments. And we have not given them any tenant improvement allowance on any of those sites. So we have the flexibility to go back and re-lease those boxes if and when they're rejected and they revert back to us. So at the time, they were in Florida, which was their primary market, where they were the dominant player at that time. When we spoke, they were the appropriate cotenant. But luckily, because of the strength of the other cotenants of our redevelopments, we think that we'll be able to do potentially even better.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And let's say you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there is full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe as DICK's comes in and reconfigures the space?
componenttext: Okay. And let's say you do get to reassign half of those boxes. From a practical standpoint, even if there is full assignment for those half boxes, how much downtime is there as maybe as DICK's comes in and reconfigures the space?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then -- and we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the ones that'll be rejected, those are the ones that'll take some time in terms of leas
componenttext: It really depends. It depends if they buy the lease. If they buy the lease, then there's 0 downtime, then -- and we get all the rents back that we reserved for. So on the ones that'll be rejected, those are the ones that'll take some time in terms of lease-up and build-out, building-out of the space, and it all depends on what you do with the box. If it's a single-tenant user, you probably can get your rent commencement date sooner than if you were to split the box and do a potential multi-tenant-type lineup. So it will really depend on what the highest and best use for that real estate. Some of them might be grocery components, some of them might be redevelopment, some of them might be single-tenant users, and it'll just have to come down to what the best use that we can find.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And how does this look right now, are they sort of ones that you've said might be reassigned or bought? Will they really buy the lease or is there more incentive for like the retailer like DICK's to just wait it out?

componenttext: Right now, it looks like there's going to be plenty of bidders to buy a number of leases from them, so they might do a couple of big transactions.

componenttext: Conor, it's Ray. I mean, the thing is that there are -- the 2 big sporting goods stores are both circling the company. So since there is lively bidding between 2 major sporting goods stores, they have to keep their hat in the game and not wait to see who comes back and cut a deal with us.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money through the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunis
componenttext: Well, we've always thought the PLUS business was part of a differentiation of our REIT versus others. It gives us opportunities through different cycles. We've made a lot of money through the PLUS business over the years, and it continues to be opportunistic. And with retail being so challenging these days, we do think that there may be future opportunities. But clearly, we're focused on the Albertsons that we currently have and want to create value there before we probably do anything more.

componenttext: Sure. And then just following up on that -- on the prior comments about some of the bidders for the Sports Authority's. Would Kimco sort of consider playing a role in the liquidation of Sports Authority via the PLUS business?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, the PLUS business bankruptcy is where -- a lot of times the retailers own a lot of the real estate and in Sports Authority, they own like in 1 property actually in Pennsylvania, and I am looking at that one. But this is a purely really a leas
componenttext: Yes. I mean, the PLUS business bankruptcy is where -- a lot of times the retailers own a lot of the real estate and in Sports Authority, they own like in 1 property actually in Pennsylvania, and I am looking at that one. But this is a purely really a lease portfolio. You have the users that are the highest bidders for that. For us, let's let this play out? We don't want to chase every deal just to say we're still in the PLUS business. You have to make sure it's very profitable.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a longer-term or medium-term goal of continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be fungible. But if you look at the amount of mortgage debt that we will retain this year at close to 6% to take the
componenttext: We have a longer-term or medium-term goal of continuing to reduce leverage and improve those balance sheet metrics. As you know, cash can be fungible. But if you look at the amount of mortgage debt that we will retain this year at close to 6% to take the leverage down with the some equity made some sense for us. So I would say we kind of earmarked it towards debt reduction, leverage reduction less than about the acquisitions, because most of the acquisition activity is being fueled by proceeds coming from disposition activity.

componenttext: The first quarter definitely has more renewals and options in terms of the total pie when you look at the combined leasing spreads. So it does weigh on the combined leasing spreads. headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
