componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Kimco Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to David Bujnicki. Please go ahead.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's second quarter earnings call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, the President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, our Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO. In a
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's second quarter earnings call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, the President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, our Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton, our Executive Chairman; David Jamieson, our EVP of Asset Management Operations; and Ray Edwards, our Executive Vice President Of Retailer Services. 
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking, and it is important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. 
During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures are available on our website. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we will report on major milestones that encompass our 2020 vision. I will give a quick update on the execution of our strategic goals, quarterly metrics and development and redevelopment pipelines before tu
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we will report on major milestones that encompass our 2020 vision. I will give a quick update on the execution of our strategic goals, quarterly metrics and development and redevelopment pipelines before turning it over to Ross to cover acquisitions and dispositions, followed by Glenn to discuss our financial results. 
We are making great strides in creating long-term shareholder value as we continue to simplify and strengthen our business. With our recent Canadian dispositions, our strategic exit from Canada is over 90% complete, and we have further reduced our joint venture investment. More specifically, the number of properties in our JV portfolio now stands at 152 as compared to 551 sites in 2010, a decrease of 72%. And the overall value of the joint venture portfolio is currently $5.4 billion gross as compared to $12.3 billion gross in 2010, a decrease of 56%. 
We are further simplifying our capital structure by redeeming our Canadian bonds to coincide with our exit of Canada. We will also prepay unsecured bond and a portion of our U.S. mortgages that come due in 2017, to take full advantage of the all-time low rate environment and further extend our maturity profile. 
We continue to monitor and evaluate opportunities in the capital markets, including the use of our ATM to improve the balance sheet as we strive to achieve our publicly stated goal of achieving an A- A3 credit rating. All of these efforts will put Kimco in a position of strength for the next cycle and move us closer to our 2020 vision. 
Internally, we will be merging our primary taxable REIT subsidiary into the parent company, thus transferring long-term hold assets into the REIT structure to simplify and make our holdings more efficient. 
Overall, the strong fundamentals of high-quality open-air centers continue to demonstrate why we believe we are, to use Milton's words, in the sweet spot of retail. 
Supply and demand remain in check, with limited new development on the horizon. Retailers with new formats and off-price specialty and traditional grocers, pet stores, home improvement, fitness, wellness and beauty are all looking to grow store count. Our occupancy is up to 96%, with our anchor boxes at 98.3% and our small shop occupancy improving to 89.2%. Achieving an 8-year high in occupancy could not have been accomplished without the incredible effort of our entire team. 
New deal spreads improved to 29.8%, demonstrating the portfolio's mark-to-market opportunity. Renewals and options also improved 10.7% to produce an impressive combined leasing spread of 16.2%, our highest in 3 years. Same-site NOI increased 3.1%, which included 30 basis points from redevelopment. 
Notwithstanding the success, the Sports Authority liquidation will create some near-term headwinds, but will result in long-term positives. Our exposure to Sports Authority has been reduced, with retailers acquiring 2 leases at auction, reducing our exposure to 1.1% of ABR. We also see the opportunity to buy back the lease at our Farmington, Connecticut property, which has 52 years of term remaining at a $4 rent, which was dramatically below market. 
The numerous auction delays and false starts resulted in a shallow pool of retailers that were willing to pay the unpaid prepetition rent and live by the existing lease terms. Throughout the auction process, we've been proactively marketing to 23 remaining boxes and have won fully executed lease and LOIs working on all remaining locations. 
We see further opportunity to add a grocery component in certain locations and the ability to mark-to-market undervalued leases. Based upon the interest we are receiving, we are optimistic the absorption of these spaces will be swift over the next 6 to 12 months. We are maintaining our full year guidance for same-site NOI growth and occupancy based on our reforecast that incorporate the impact from the Sports Authority liquidation and demand for our high-quality real estate. 
Progress continues on our strategic development and redevelopment pipeline, especially in our larger projects that we are calling the signature series. Whole Foods in Wynnewood, PA is now installing fixtures in their new store and is set to open in September. The Grand Parkway in Houston is on schedule and is now 89% preleased. The Target pad was turned over on June 10 and all 7 junior anchor leases are fully executed. Ground Parkway Phase 2 is also moving forward, with 2 of the 3 anchor boxes fully executed with the Academy Sports and Hobby Lobby. Dania Pointe in the Fort Lauderdale MSA is also on schedule. The Costco pad is being prepped with turnover set for second quarter of 2017. Phase 2 of Dania has kicked off pre-leasing, and we are happy to announce the fully executed anchor lease with H&M. 
Our major redevelopments are also gaining traction, highlighted by the new parking garage at Pentagon, which is nearing completion. This will allow us to move forward with the Phase 1 specification. Our redevelopment for the quarter are projected to produce 9.9% return on invested capital, and we continue to believe this growing pipeline is a major differentiator for Kimco as we are just getting started with the repositioning of our top assets. 
As you can see, our 2020 vision is coming more and more into focus as we create a portfolio of assets that is both resilient to economic downturns and at the same time, able to attractive the best tenets to generate quality earnings growth and expand our overall net asset value. Our portfolio is focused and concentrated in the best U.S. markets with the best demographics. Our shopping center strike a wonderful balance with off-price and grocery anchors and just the right mix of small-shop tenants. These are the types of centers that consumers return to again and again in good times and bad, whether they are looking to restock their refrigerator at Albertsons, treasure hunt at TJX or get a haircut or manicure. When you add our signature series of development and redevelopment projects to this solid defensive foundation, the portfolios changing profile is dramatic, both in quality and value. 
Ross will now walk you through our transactions for the quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor. With the execution of our second quarter transaction activity completed, we took another big step towards our goals of reducing leverage, joint ventures and noncore market ownership. The largest driver of our progress was the continued and
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor. With the execution of our second quarter transaction activity completed, we took another big step towards our goals of reducing leverage, joint ventures and noncore market ownership. The largest driver of our progress was the continued and accelerated pace of our Canadian exit, highlighted by the Anthem transaction, which closed last month. Coupled with the sale of several additional Canadian assets, we have now sold over 90% of our Canadian LOI with the remainder to be sold by year-end. 
In the U.S., we took advantage of the strong investor demand for shopping centers, with a disposition of 12 assets for $220 million. This included the sale of our last remaining asset in Mississippi as well as other noncore assets in markets such as Council Bluffs, Iowa and Overland Park, Kansas. The blended cap rate on the dispositions for the quarter was 6.6%, which was in line with our expectations. We will continue to selectively prune the portfolio to enhance the overall quality on a go-forward basis. 
On the acquisition side, we remain laser-focused on high-quality assets, with both long and short-term growth, located within strong demographic areas. As previously announced, the acquisition of our partner's share in Oakwood Plaza and Dania not only provides Kimco with 100% ownership of 2 of the largest and highest-quality projects in the portfolio, but also further achieves the goal of JV reduction. 
Additionally, we are excited to announce the planned acquisition of the Kimco marketplace, a 250,000 square-foot Whole Foods-anchored center in Gaithersburg, Maryland. This Metro DC asset provides a unique opportunity to own a highly coveted infill asset, with excellent grocery sales of almost $1,300 a square foot and also have significantly near-term upside and redevelopment potential. Closing as anticipated in the next couple of weeks, and we look forward to sharing our plans for this asset. 
Our transactional activity for the year has been front-loaded with asset sales as we have sold $821 million Kim share, which bumped against the low end of our initial 2016 disposition range of $825 million to $975 million. With over 20 assets either under contract, with accepted offers or in the market, we are increasing our full year 2016 disposition range to $1 billion to $1.15 billion. Our 2016 estimate for acquisitions remains intact at $450 million to $550 million, as we will have purchased approximately $250 million of shopping centers, including the pending acquisition. 
The environment for quality real estate remains hypercompetitive, but we continue to evaluate unique opportunities and pick our spots. Capital is abundant, with significant equity being placed by foreign investors, pension funds, life companies, private equity and REITs. Debt is readily available from CMBS and life companies with historically low rates, and yields are expected to stay low for the near future. Recent sub-5% cap rates on open-air shopping center transactions have closed in New York, New Jersey Metro, Los Angeles, San Diego, San Francisco, Austin, Texas, Washington, D.C. and South Florida. These are all primary markets for Kimco, where we have a strong established presence. 
Single tenant ground leases with strong credit rating are trading in the low 4% range and even sub-4% in some cases, which bodes well for the value of our long-term ground leases with the likes of Walmart, Costco, Home Depot and others. 
With that, I'm happy to pass it over to Glenn to provide detail on the financials.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ross, and good morning. We continue to execute on the key components of our 2020 vision that Conor and Ross describes. Our 2020 vision is focused on both the left side of the balance sheet as well as the right side as we continue to further improv
componenttext:
Thanks, Ross, and good morning. We continue to execute on the key components of our 2020 vision that Conor and Ross describes. Our 2020 vision is focused on both the left side of the balance sheet as well as the right side as we continue to further improve our debt metrics and balance sheet position. 
Now for some color on the quarter and further detail regarding the 3 strategic initiatives we announced last night, which we believe will further improve our capital structure as well as our recurring growth profile and tax efficiency in both the short term and long term. Headline FFO per share, which represents the official NAREIT definition, was $0.38 for the second quarter, meeting first call consensus. As a reminder, our consensus estimate is based on NAREIT-defined FFO. Included in the headline result is $0.01 per share attributable to profit participation from the sale of a preferred equity investment. Headline FFO per share for the second quarter last year was $0.44, which included $0.08 per share attributable to the gain on the sale of our marketable security investment in SUPERVALU. FFO is adjusted or recurring FFO, which excludes transactional income and expense and nonoperating impairments was $0.37 per diluted share for the second quarter, the same level as last year. We achieved this level despite a $17 million decrease in net operating income, primarily attributable to the significant Canadian and U.S. property dispositions over the past year. This was largely offset by a $15 million reduction in financing costs related to lower debt levels, lower interest rates on debt refinancing and the redemption of our 6.9% preferred stock last year. 
For the 6 months, FFO as adjusted per share is $0.74, up from $0.73 for the comparable period last year and on target with our recurring forecast and guidance expectations. We ended the second quarter with consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA of 5.7x, down from 6.3x a year ago. In addition, our net debt-to-EBITDA on a look-through basis is 6.9x, which includes our $800 million of preferred stock, which is all callable next year, and our program of sharing venture debt, which, by the way, is down to $843 million from a peak of $3 billion. The 6.9x level is at the high end of our target range of 6.4x to 6.9x that we announced at our 2020 vision Investor Day. 
We improved our debt maturity profile with the addition of $150 million to our 4 1/4% [ph] 30-year bond, and we also issued $38.9 million of common equity through our ATM program in the early part of the quarter. 
Now for some additional color on the 3 strategic initiatives announced last night. Initiative one, redeeming our outstanding Canadian bonds. As Ross mentioned with the completed sale of Canadian assets, representing over 90% of our Canadian NOI, it's no longer necessary to have the Canadian-denominated bonds outstanding. This is clearly an opportunity for us to further delever the balance sheet. As such, we will be redeeming the Canadian-denominated $350 million of bonds at the end of August, using the proceeds from the Canadian sales, which have also produced over $111 million of non-FFO gains year-to-date. We expect to incur a prepayment charge of approximately $26 million or $0.06 per share, which will impact net income and headline FFO in the third quarter. 
Initiative two, the prepayment of U.S. debt that's due in 2017. As part of reaching our stated goal of increasing our unsecured credit ratings to A- and A3, we want to further extend our debt maturity profile, further improve our fixed charge and debt service coverage ratios and increase our unencumbered asset pool. To this end, we'll be redeeming our $290.9 million, 5.7% bond due in 2017 and prepaying $137 million of 6.32% mortgage debt that's due in December of 2017. The funding of the aggregate principal amount of $427.9 million and the prepayment charge of $22 million or $0.05 per share, which will impact net income and headline FFO, will be made with the combination of proceeds from asset sales, availability under our revolving credit facility and depending on market conditions, issuance of an unsecured bond. 
Initiative three, merging our primary taxable REIT subsidiary Kimco Realty Services into Kimco Realty Corporation. This tax-free merger will effectively transfer the ownership of our Albertson's investment in over 30 shopping center assets, many of which were developed in our former merchant-building business but retained and today, are considered long-term hold properties. This transaction will provide us greater tax efficiency as well as reduce our administrative costs. In conjunction with the merger, which is expected to be completed in the third quarter, generally accepted accounting principles require the establishment of evaluation reserve when it is more likely than not that deferred tax assets will not be realized. As such, a noncash charge against net income of $66 million or $0.16 per share and headline FFO of $41 million or $0.10 a share, respectively, will be recorded. The difference between the net income charge and the FFO charge is related to the tax impact from impairments previously taken on operating properties, which were excluded from FFO. Now subsequent to the merger, a portion of this evaluation reserve may no longer be required in the event certain taxable transactions related to these assets occur. This will include a monetization of our Albertson's investment. 
In total, the 3 initiatives just discussed are expected to have a total impact on net income of approximately $114 million or $0.27 per share and on headline FFO of $89 million with $0.21 per share. As a result of the charges, we are revising our headline FFO per share guidance range to $1.34 to $1.42 with a midpoint of $1.38 from the previous headline FFO per share guidance range of $1.54 to $1.62 with a midpoint of $1.58. We continue to anticipate that the bulk of our transactions will occur in the fourth quarter. We are reaffirming our FFO as adjusted recurring FFO per share guidance range of $1.48 to $1.52 with a midpoint of $1.50, which builds upon our solid first half performance and the expected benefits from the 3 initiatives, along with the impact from the Sports Authority liquidation and our increased disposition range. 
And with that, we'd be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: Well, when you think about what we did, it was more about bringing the properties that this shopping center assets back into the REIT structure. These are assets that were developed by us years ago that were originally part of our merchant development business. We lease them up, fully developed them. Most of them are long-term assets. They really belong in the REIT structure. So as a matter of time to find the most tax-efficient way to bring them back in their appropriate space. With that, though, the Albertson's transaction and the investment in Albertson's comes along with it because we own less than 10% of the investment there and allowed us to bring it back into the REIT. So there's some benefit, potentially, that can come from it from a tax structuring standpoint. But as it relates to the PLUS business, we do have still have a separate TRS, where if there were things that were appropriate for that, we would house them there. This is more about the property stuff.

componenttext: Just a follow up on that. So you mentioned that the transactional income you're expecting is still back-end loaded. But I guess, I sort of understood that when you said that last quarter, that was referring to Albertson's, at least largely. Is that -- can you help kind of me understand that probably not going to happen at least the way may be anticipated earlier in the year kind of how do I think about Albertson's and then the transactional kind of back-end-loaded number?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The transactional income is still premised on a some level of monetization of our Albertson's investment. That's what they are, right?
componenttext: The transactional income is still premised on a some level of monetization of our Albertson's investment. That's what they are, right?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, in 2015, October, when they tried the IPO and didn't work out, we've kept the, as I said before, the S-1 updated on file to do that. But as markets are fickle, gone together in looking at other opportunities as to monetize part of our investment.
componenttext: I mean, in 2015, October, when they tried the IPO and didn't work out, we've kept the, as I said before, the S-1 updated on file to do that. But as markets are fickle, gone together in looking at other opportunities as to monetize part of our investment. And concerning during that, that may be a vehicle for us to monetize, and we're optimistic will happen this year, so we're still on track for it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just real quick. You mentioned the cap rate compression for kind of major metro assets. How widespread do you think you might see that? Is it something that's kind of trickling into secondary markets or the assets? Or is this kind of instit
componenttext: Okay. And then just real quick. You mentioned the cap rate compression for kind of major metro assets. How widespread do you think you might see that? Is it something that's kind of trickling into secondary markets or the assets? Or is this kind of institutional quality to mine and what's driving it and so kind of more restricted?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly, on the institutional assets, they continue to compress. In the secondary markets, we're still seeing very strong pricing. Our dispositions in the U.S. are still in the high 6s, low 7s, particularly the assets that have a grocer that is the domi
componenttext: Certainly, on the institutional assets, they continue to compress. In the secondary markets, we're still seeing very strong pricing. Our dispositions in the U.S. are still in the high 6s, low 7s, particularly the assets that have a grocer that is the dominant grocer within the market. We're still seeing very strong pricing, even in the secondary and tertiary markets. Where there's a little bit of softness is more in the commodity-type retail, where there is no true value-add and our relatively flat assets with no grocer is starting to see a little bit of trickle upwards in cap rates, but still well within the range of expectation and within pricing that we're comfortable selling.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, just to clarify on the guidance, you -- it sounded on one hand like you're including a bond offering just because you're going to get $9.5 million of benefit this year from the TRS and the bond takeouts, and yet sounded like you weren't including u
componenttext: Glenn, just to clarify on the guidance, you -- it sounded on one hand like you're including a bond offering just because you're going to get $9.5 million of benefit this year from the TRS and the bond takeouts, and yet sounded like you weren't including unsecured deal in your numbers this year. So can you just verify what's in it? And then maybe it's just that the bond you may be so late in the year that it doesn't impact this year's numbers.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the guidance does contemplate refinancing what we're calling on the U.S. side with a bond. So that is part of the guidance.
componenttext: No, I mean, the guidance does contemplate refinancing what we're calling on the U.S. side with a bond. So that is part of the guidance.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then because you guys traditionally give your next year's guidance with the third quarter. You mentioned at the start about all the preferreds being callable next year and maybe the 1s and the 5s are still attractive. But certainly, you go
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then because you guys traditionally give your next year's guidance with the third quarter. You mentioned at the start about all the preferreds being callable next year and maybe the 1s and the 5s are still attractive. But certainly, you got a 6% one [ph] out there. Should -- as we think about our 2017 numbers, we're obviously adjusting for the TRS and the bond takeouts. Should we also be thinking about the preferreds coming out? Or is that a decision that you just mentioned callable, but we shouldn't read anything into that?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, first of all, as far as guidance, we don't do guidance in the third quarter. We do it later. And second, I mentioned it because it is another opportunity for us to further reduce our overall cost of capital. Again, but it's going to be subjec
componenttext: Well, again, first of all, as far as guidance, we don't do guidance in the third quarter. We do it later. And second, I mentioned it because it is another opportunity for us to further reduce our overall cost of capital. Again, but it's going to be subject to market conditions at the time and where rates are, so I'd throw it out there because it's something that is near term. It's on our radar screen.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Vincent Chao afflicted on.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Vincent Chao afflicted on.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the commentary about the strong pricing environment that caused you to increase your dispo guidance for the year. And then also thinking about the comment about a more normalized level of 2017. I guess, if we still -- if we continue to
componenttext: Just going back to the commentary about the strong pricing environment that caused you to increase your dispo guidance for the year. And then also thinking about the comment about a more normalized level of 2017. I guess, if we still -- if we continue to see pricing hold up and maybe even improve over the back half of this year I need to be be thinking about something more than $150 million just as you look to take advantage of that pricing?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really feel like we're at the end of our transformation. So we'll continue to be opportunistic. But we're very happy with the level of the portfolio, the quality of the assets that we have once this year is completed. So we'll always evaluate the
componenttext: Well, we really feel like we're at the end of our transformation. So we'll continue to be opportunistic. But we're very happy with the level of the portfolio, the quality of the assets that we have once this year is completed. So we'll always evaluate the quality of the properties, where the risk levels are, if markets are moving and things of that nature. But we don't anticipate any larger-scale disposition program beyond this year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And didn't just mean situation with Puerto Rico securities provide some commentary what you're seeing there.
componenttext: Okay. And didn't just mean situation with Puerto Rico securities provide some commentary what you're seeing there.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The Puerto Rican portfolio is holding up nicely. The occupancy is still above 95%. Same-site was positive, but obviously, relatively muted. So it's one that with the recent announcement of the PROMESA, I think that the optimism is taking hold on the
componenttext: Sure. The Puerto Rican portfolio is holding up nicely. The occupancy is still above 95%. Same-site was positive, but obviously, relatively muted. So it's one that with the recent announcement of the PROMESA, I think that the optimism is taking hold on the island. Clearly, they have some issues to work through on the debt levels. But we think from the shopping center standpoint, that the traffic volume is still very, very high. The sale is a strong so we think overall, they often has gotten a bit brighter recently.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just comment on the Dania project in Pentagon? It seems like numbers have changed a little bit. I'm just wondering if it's a cosmetic choice in terms of to take out the Phase 2 disclosure or is there actually a change in the scope of the project
componenttext: Could you just comment on the Dania project in Pentagon? It seems like numbers have changed a little bit. I'm just wondering if it's a cosmetic choice in terms of to take out the Phase 2 disclosure or is there actually a change in the scope of the project?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We actually broke out the projects in phases. like we talked about earlier, most of our projects have what we are calling off-ramps and phases that we can actually see if the want to go or no go on the projects. So on Pentagon, the Phase 1, as I men
componenttext: Sure. We actually broke out the projects in phases. like we talked about earlier, most of our projects have what we are calling off-ramps and phases that we can actually see if the want to go or no go on the projects. So on Pentagon, the Phase 1, as I mentioned, is really the parking desk that's really nearing completion and then first tower that's entitled and is ready to go vertical as soon as the parking deck is complete. The second phase on Pentagon is the second tower. So again, we'll monitor the absorption rate and the rents and where they're coming in and then make the determination on the second tower if and when it's appropriate. Dania, same thing. First phase, we broke out that costs, so you can see exactly what goes into the first phase and that's Costco portion as well as some junior anchors that we're moving along nicely. The second phase there is going to be more of a higher-density play, so we broke that out as well, as I mentioned, the H&M lease is fully executed preleasing is starting to move forward on that as well. So we wanted to give you bit more granularity on the phasing opportunities as we have some of these larger-scale projects.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to follow up on a previous question on Albertson's. You mentioned you might partially monetize it before IPO, if I heard that correctly. How do you think about that? Is I am guessing there's probably a pretty decent liquidity discount that
componenttext: Okay. And just to follow up on a previous question on Albertson's. You mentioned you might partially monetize it before IPO, if I heard that correctly. How do you think about that? Is I am guessing there's probably a pretty decent liquidity discount that you would have to take if you monetize it before this year for publicly traded. So what's behind -- what goes on behind that process there?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for us and our partners, we don't think that the discount will be accurate, first of all. And we wouldn't be selling that large of a piece of the investment. Is so what we feel it will do for us is put money in our market but also validate t
componenttext: Well, I think for us and our partners, we don't think that the discount will be accurate, first of all. And we wouldn't be selling that large of a piece of the investment. Is so what we feel it will do for us is put money in our market but also validate the valuation that we have an Albertson's. And hopefully, you will add 15% to 20% evaluation after we announce the transaction.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Mueller from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Mueller from JPMorgan.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about Sports Authority's 6 to 12 months I think to address the remaining boxes. When -- what time period do you see most of the boxes actually occupied and renting by like how far down the road?
componenttext: You talked about Sports Authority's 6 to 12 months I think to address the remaining boxes. When -- what time period do you see most of the boxes actually occupied and renting by like how far down the road?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have pretty clear visibility into the absorption that we think it's going to occur. We have LOIs working on 18 of the boxes right now that are pretty close to fully executed. So we actually think we have a chance to be cautiously optimistic that a lot
componenttext: We have pretty clear visibility into the absorption that we think it's going to occur. We have LOIs working on 18 of the boxes right now that are pretty close to fully executed. So we actually think we have a chance to be cautiously optimistic that a lot of them will be done before the end of the year. But again, we want to -- it's probably going to take 6 to 12 months because all of them are fully occupied and the rents start to come in. So we do have one lease that's fully executed with a grocery store that's 33% above prior rent. And we continue to see what other opportunities exist to add grocery components going forward to the opportunity set that we have.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that 6 to 12 was actually occupied rent paying not just adjust leased.
componenttext: Okay. So that 6 to 12 was actually occupied rent paying not just adjust leased.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Richard Hill of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is from Richard Hill of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a quick question about the rental rate releasing spreads. First of all, congrats on getting those 2 [ph] highest level in 3 years. I had a question, though. It looks like there were some absolute increases between the leases and renewals. But maybe
componenttext: I had a quick question about the rental rate releasing spreads. First of all, congrats on getting those 2 [ph] highest level in 3 years. I had a question, though. It looks like there were some absolute increases between the leases and renewals. But maybe also an additional weighting towards new leases over renewals. Am I thinking about that correctly? And if so, is there anything there? Are you seeing more leasing velocity on the space. What drove that?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly you're seeing that the occupancy is hitting near all-time high. Is so when spaces, available, there's usually a bidding war to get high-quality real estate in this market. So that's clearly what's driving the rental spread, both in the new l
componenttext: Well, clearly you're seeing that the occupancy is hitting near all-time high. Is so when spaces, available, there's usually a bidding war to get high-quality real estate in this market. So that's clearly what's driving the rental spread, both in the new leases. And typically now, when you see renewals come up, it's more option notices coming in rather than say pure renewals because people are worried about giving up their high-quality real estate because they know there's a chance they might prove the visit if they don't exercise that option.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Collin Mings of Raymond James.
componenttext: The next question comes from Collin Mings of Raymond James.

componenttext: Just going back to Alex's question. Where are you going to keep your price preferreds today?

componenttextpreview: Preferreds today we're probably in the low 5s. I mean, in the low 5s.
componenttext: Preferreds today we're probably in the low 5s. I mean, in the low 5s.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, as you guys have moved very far down the line of simplification, I was curious as to what your thoughts are on the remaining TDs and whether there's been any additional conversations with your partners in terms of how those may be either dissolve
componenttext: I guess, as you guys have moved very far down the line of simplification, I was curious as to what your thoughts are on the remaining TDs and whether there's been any additional conversations with your partners in terms of how those may be either dissolved or whatever.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really have 3 large remaining JV partners and that's really Prudential, CPP and the New York Common Funds. So they're all great partners. They're all long-standing relationships that we've had over the years. And typically, they're long-term holders, s
componenttext: We really have 3 large remaining JV partners and that's really Prudential, CPP and the New York Common Funds. So they're all great partners. They're all long-standing relationships that we've had over the years. And typically, they're long-term holders, so I don't see any sort of large transaction in the near term. But there's always bites of the apple that we think we can get on the margin, whether it's a smaller portfolio, properties or a few here and there that we can -- that we're able to acquire, similar to the Dania and Oakwood transaction that we announced this quarter. So again, we'll take the opportunities when they present themselves. But again, we're really down to 3 large major partners that are all great partners and long-term holders of high-quality real estate.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And 2 of those ventures, the common fund venture that we have, we own almost 50% of it. And with CPP, we own 55% of it. So we are a major stakeholder in those.
componenttext: And 2 of those ventures, the common fund venture that we have, we own almost 50% of it. And with CPP, we own 55% of it. So we are a major stakeholder in those.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Glenn, just a quick follow-up on sort of the guidance adjustment as it related to the transactional income expense line. Can you just sort of walk -- prior guidance was $25 million to $42 million of gains. Now it's $40 million to $59 million of l
componenttext: And then Glenn, just a quick follow-up on sort of the guidance adjustment as it related to the transactional income expense line. Can you just sort of walk -- prior guidance was $25 million to $42 million of gains. Now it's $40 million to $59 million of lost. You've given us the one number, the $89 million, for some of the strategic investments. I guess, I'm curious as to what the other delta might be.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really it. It to the same as what we had before. The difference is our expectation of some monetization on Albertson's in the number. So the only change to the guidance that occurred really relates around the $89 [ph] million, which is maybe a $0.0
componenttext: That's really it. It to the same as what we had before. The difference is our expectation of some monetization on Albertson's in the number. So the only change to the guidance that occurred really relates around the $89 [ph] million, which is maybe a $0.01 difference because we actually had some transactional income that's already done. So the preferred equity investment that were sold at this quarter and the one from last quarter gave us $0.01 of headline FFO.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the 24th Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: The next question is from the 24th Green Street Advisors.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For just going back to cap rates. You talked about some of the high-quality properties trading in lower cap rates. What do you see kind of the middle and higher end some of the properties your selling those cap rates compressing as well?
componenttext: For just going back to cap rates. You talked about some of the high-quality properties trading in lower cap rates. What do you see kind of the middle and higher end some of the properties your selling those cap rates compressing as well?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they really maintained the level that we've seen for the last 9 to 12 months, so in the U.S. and some of the secondary markets, we're in high 6s into the low 7s. And if there's a grocery anchor, even if it's outside the core markets, we've sold a cou
componenttext: Yes, they really maintained the level that we've seen for the last 9 to 12 months, so in the U.S. and some of the secondary markets, we're in high 6s into the low 7s. And if there's a grocery anchor, even if it's outside the core markets, we've sold a couple of assets in the high 5s and the low 6s. So we still feel really good about their cap rates are. We have not seen them change materially, and the buyer pulls have been a bit shallow for the last 12 months compared to the beginning stages into the middle of 2015. But those groups are still very serious. They're able to get financing when they need it. And we haven't really seen any hiccups in the deals that we've put under contract and getting it across the finish line.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one on your same-store NOI guidance. If you look at a top end of your range, on the table kind of implies a pretty high growth rate the back half of the year, with a Sports Authority headwind. Is there any way of achieving that high e
componenttext: Great. And then just one on your same-store NOI guidance. If you look at a top end of your range, on the table kind of implies a pretty high growth rate the back half of the year, with a Sports Authority headwind. Is there any way of achieving that high end at this point?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's always a way, depending on how quickly [indiscernible] happens and cash butts flowing. Again, we've been guiding more towards the middle, somewhere in the 3 to [ph] 3 1 range. But it's a range, so we don't control everything that happens,
componenttext: I mean, there's always a way, depending on how quickly [indiscernible] happens and cash butts flowing. Again, we've been guiding more towards the middle, somewhere in the 3 to [ph] 3 1 range. But it's a range, so we don't control everything that happens, but we do feel comfortable towards that middle end of that range.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rich Moore of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Rich Moore of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, have you seen any change at Kmart recently? Any difference in that retailer? Or maybe any difference in your discussions with them?
componenttext: I'm curious, have you seen any change at Kmart recently? Any difference in that retailer? Or maybe any difference in your discussions with them?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't. I think there was some new stories that came out recently about the employee sentiment and that I think was taken maybe out of context on certain stores. The 2 leases that we have coming due this quarter, both of them exercised options.
componenttext: We really haven't. I think there was some new stories that came out recently about the employee sentiment and that I think was taken maybe out of context on certain stores. The 2 leases that we have coming due this quarter, both of them exercised options. So I think that gets you some insight still very much a trying to make do with what they can. But we continue to monitor it. We only have 21 sites left, a little less than 1% of ABR. We have 4 coming due in 2017 without any auctions that are all redevelopments. So we're still continuing to monitor the situation look to try to redevelop that state.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ray. I mean, Kmart has a lot of flexibility because they haven't signed a lease in 20 years. So every one of the leases is probably last 5 years of the term, but their period. So they have a lot of flexibility to renew leases making money do with
componenttext: This is Ray. I mean, Kmart has a lot of flexibility because they haven't signed a lease in 20 years. So every one of the leases is probably last 5 years of the term, but their period. So they have a lot of flexibility to renew leases making money do with a couple of hours and not making money get out of them without having to pay at least disposition program so a lot flexibility on the Kmart side to wind down stores in the short period of time.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Kimco Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to David Bujnicki. Please go ahead.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's second quarter earnings call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, the President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, our Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO. In
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's second quarter earnings call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, the President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, our Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO. 
In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton, our Executive Chairman; Dave Jamieson, our EVP of Asset Management Operations; and Ray Edwards, our Executive Vice President Of Retailer Services. 
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking, and it is important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. 
During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures are available on our website. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we will report on major milestones that encompass our 2020 vision. I will give a quick update on the execution of our strategic goals, quarterly metrics and development and redevelopment pipelines before tu
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. Today, we will report on major milestones that encompass our 2020 vision. I will give a quick update on the execution of our strategic goals, quarterly metrics and development and redevelopment pipelines before turning it over to Ross to cover acquisitions and dispositions, followed by Glenn to discuss our financial results. 
We are making great strides in creating long-term shareholder value as we continue to simplify and strengthen our business. With our recent Canadian dispositions, our strategic exit from Canada is over 90% complete, and we have further reduced our joint venture investment. 
More specifically, the number of properties in our JV portfolio now stands at 152 as compared to 551 sites in 2010, a decrease of 72%. And the overall value of the joint venture portfolio is currently $5.4 billion gross as compared to $12.3 billion gross in 2010, a decrease of 56%. 
We are further simplifying our capital structure by redeeming our Canadian bonds to coincide with our exit of Canada. We will also prepay an unsecured bond and a portion of our U.S. mortgages that come due in 2017, to take full advantage of the all-time low rate environment and further extend our maturity profile. 
We continue to monitor and evaluate opportunities in the capital markets, including the use of our ATM to improve the balance sheet as we strive to achieve our publicly-stated goal of achieving an A- A3 credit rating. All of these efforts will put Kimco in a position of strength for the next cycle and move us closer to our 2020 vision. 
Internally, we will be merging our primary taxable REIT subsidiary into the parent company, thus transferring long-term hold assets into the REIT structure to simplify and make our holdings more efficient. 
Overall, the strong fundamentals of high-quality open-air centers continue to demonstrate why we believe we are, to use Milton's words, in the sweet spot of retail. 
Supply and demand remain in check, with limited new development on the horizon. Retailers with new formats and off-price specialty and traditional grocers, pet stores, home improvement, fitness, wellness and beauty are all looking to grow store count. 
Our occupancy is up to 96%, with our anchor boxes at 98.3% and our small shop occupancy improving to 89.2%. Achieving an 8-year high in occupancy could not have been accomplished without the incredible effort of our entire team. 
New deal spreads improved to 29.8%, demonstrating the portfolio's mark-to-market opportunity. Renewals and options also improved 10.7% to produce an impressive combined leasing spread of 16.2%, our highest in 3 years. Same-site NOI increased 3.1%, which included 30 basis points from redevelopment. 
Notwithstanding the success, the Sports Authority liquidation will create some near-term headwinds, but will result in long-term positives. Our exposure to Sports Authority has been reduced, with retailers acquiring 2 leases at auction, reducing our exposure to 1.1% of ABR. 
We also seized the opportunity to buy back the lease at our Farmington, Connecticut property, which has 52 years of term remaining at a $4 rent, which was dramatically below market. 
The numerous auction delays and false starts resulted in a shallow pool of retailers that were willing to pay the unpaid pre-petition rent and live by the existing lease terms. Throughout the auction process, we've been proactively marketing the 23 remaining boxes and have 1 fully executed lease and LOIs working on all remaining locations. 
We see further opportunity to add a grocery component in certain locations and the ability to mark-to-market undervalued leases. Based upon the interest we are receiving, we are optimistic the absorption of these spaces will be swift over the next 6 to 12 months. 
We are maintaining our full year guidance for same-site NOI growth and occupancy based on our re-forecast that incorporate the impact from the Sports Authority liquidation and demand for our high-quality real estate. 
Progress continues on our strategic development and redevelopment pipeline, especially on our larger projects that we are calling the Signature Series. Whole Foods in Wynnewood, PA is now installing fixtures in their new store and is set to open in September. 
Grand Parkway in Houston is on schedule and is now 89% pre-leased. The Target pad was turned over on June 10, and all 7 junior anchor leases are fully executed. Ground Parkway Phase 2 is also moving forward, with 2 of the 3 anchor boxes fully executed with the Academy Sports and Hobby Lobby. 
Dania Pointe in the Fort Lauderdale MSA is also on schedule. The Costco pad is being prepped with turnover set for second quarter of 2017. Phase 2 of Dania has kicked off pre-leasing, and we are happy to announce the fully executed anchor lease with H&M. 
Our major redevelopments are also gaining traction, highlighted by the new parking garage at Pentagon, which is nearing completion. This will allow us to move forward with the Phase 1 densifications. Our redevelopment for the quarter are projected to produce 9.9% return on invested capital, and we continue to believe this growing pipeline is a major differentiator for Kimco as we are just getting started with the repositioning of our top assets. 
As you can see, our 2020 vision is coming more and more into focus as we create a portfolio of assets that is both resilient to economic downturns, and at the same time, able to attract the best tenants to generate quality earnings growth and expand our overall net asset value. 
Our portfolio is focused and concentrated in the best U.S. markets with the best demographics. Our shopping centers strike a wonderful balance with off-price and grocery anchors and just the right mix of small-shop tenants. These are the types of centers that consumers return to again and again in good times and bad, whether they are looking to restock their refrigerator at Albertsons, treasure hunt at TJX or get a haircut or manicure. 
When you add our Signature Series of development and redevelopment projects to this solid defensive foundation, the portfolio's changing profile is dramatic, both in quality and value. 
Ross will now walk you through our transactions for the quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Conor. With the execution of our second quarter transaction activity completed, we took another big step towards our goals of reducing leverage, joint ventures and non-core market ownership. The largest driver of our progress was the continued and
componenttext:
Thanks, Conor. With the execution of our second quarter transaction activity completed, we took another big step towards our goals of reducing leverage, joint ventures and non-core market ownership. The largest driver of our progress was the continued and accelerated pace of our Canadian exit, highlighted by the Anthem transaction, which closed last month. Coupled with the sale of several additional Canadian assets, we have now sold over 90% of our Canadian LOI with the remainder to be sold by year-end. 
In the U.S., we took advantage of the strong investor demand for shopping centers, with the disposition of 12 assets for $220 million. This included the sale of our last remaining asset in Mississippi as well as other non-core assets in markets such as Council Bluffs, Iowa and Overland Park, Kansas. 
The blended cap rate on the dispositions for the quarter was 6.6%, which was in line with our expectations. We will continue to selectively prune the portfolio to enhance the overall quality on a go-forward basis. 
On the acquisition side, we remain laser-focused on high-quality assets, with both long- and short-term growth, located within strong demographic areas. As previously announced, the acquisition of our partner share in Oakwood Plaza and Dania not only provides Kimco with the 100% ownership of 2 of the largest and highest-quality projects in the portfolio, but also further achieves the goal of JV reduction. 
Additionally, we are excited to announce the planned acquisition of the Kentlands marketplace, a 250,000 square-foot Whole Foods-anchored center in Gaithersburg, Maryland. This Metro DC asset provides a unique opportunity to own a highly coveted infill asset, with excellent grocery sales of almost $1,300 a square foot and also has significant near-term upside and redevelopment potential. Closing is anticipated in the next couple of weeks, and we look forward to sharing our plans for this asset. 
Our transactional activity for the year has been front-loaded with asset sales as we have sold $821 million KIM share, which bumped against the low end of our initial 2016 disposition range of $825 million to $975 million. 
With over 20 assets either under contract, with accepted offers or in the market, we are increasing our full year 2016 disposition range to $1 billion to $1.15 billion. Our 2016 estimate for acquisitions remains intact at $450 million to $550 million, as we will have purchased approximately $250 million of shopping centers, including the pending Kentlands acquisition. 
The environment for quality real estate remains hypercompetitive, but we continue to evaluate unique opportunities and pick our spots. Capital is abundant, with significant equity being placed by foreign investors, pension funds, life companies, private equity and REITs. Debt is readily available from CMBS and life companies with historically low rates and yields are expected to stay low for the near future. 
Recent sub-5% cap rates on open-air shopping center transactions have closed in New York; New Jersey Metro; Los Angeles; San Diego; San Francisco; Austin, Texas; Washington, D.C.; and South Florida. These are all primary markets for Kimco, where we have a strong established presence. 
Single tenant ground leases with strong credit are trading in the low 4% range and even sub-4% in some cases, which bodes well for the value of our long-term ground leases with the likes of Walmart, Costco, Home Depot and others. 
With that, I'm happy to pass it over to Glenn to provide detail on the financials.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ross, and good morning. We continue to execute on the key components of our 2020 vision that Conor and Ross described. Our 2020 vision is focused on both the left side of the balance sheet as well as the right side as we continue to further improv
componenttext:
Thanks, Ross, and good morning. We continue to execute on the key components of our 2020 vision that Conor and Ross described. Our 2020 vision is focused on both the left side of the balance sheet as well as the right side as we continue to further improve our debt metrics and balance sheet position. 
Now for some color on the quarter and further details regarding the 3 strategic initiatives we announced last night, which we believe will further improve our capital structure as well as our recurring growth profile and tax efficiency in both the short term and long term. 
Headline FFO per share, which represents the official NAREIT definition, was $0.38 for the second quarter, meeting first call consensus. As a reminder, our consensus estimate is based on NAREIT-defined FFO. 
Included in the headline result is $0.01 per share attributable to profit participation from the sale of a preferred equity investment. Headline FFO per share for the second quarter last year was $0.44, which included $0.08 per share attributable to the gain on the sale of our marketable security investment in SUPERVALU. 
FFO is adjusted or recurring FFO, which excludes transactional income and expense and nonoperating impairments, was $0.37 per diluted share for the second quarter, the same level as last year. We achieved this level despite a $17 million decrease in net operating income, primarily attributable to the significant Canadian and U.S. property dispositions over the past year. 
This was largely offset by a $15 million reduction in financing costs related to lower debt levels, lower interest rates on debt refinancing and the redemption of our 6.9% preferred stock last year. 
For the 6 months, FFO as adjusted per share is $0.74, up from $0.73 for the comparable period last year and on target with our recurring forecast and guidance expectations. We ended the second quarter with consolidated net debt to recurring EBITDA of 5.7x, down from 6.3x a year ago. 
In addition, our net debt to EBITDA on a look-through basis is 6.9x, which includes our $800 million of preferred stock, which is all callable next year, and our pro-rata share of joint venture debt, which, by the way, is down to $843 million from a peak of $3 billion. The 6.9x level is at the high end of our target range of 6.4x to 6.9x that we announced at our 2020 vision Investor Day. 
We improved our debt maturity profile with the addition of $150 million to our 4.25% 30-year bond, and we also issued $38.9 million of common equity through our ATM program in the early part of the quarter. 
Now for some additional color on the 3 strategic initiatives announced last night. Initiative one, redeeming our outstanding Canadian bonds. As Ross mentioned, with the completed sale of Canadian assets representing over 90% of our Canadian NOI, it's no longer necessary to have the Canadian-denominated bonds outstanding. 
This is clearly an opportunity for us to further delever the balance sheet. As such, we will be redeeming the Canadian-denominated $350 million of bonds at the end of August using the proceeds from the Canadian sales, which have also produced over $111 million of non-FFO gains year-to-date. We expect to incur a prepayment charge of approximately $26 million or $0.06 per share, which will impact net income and headline FFO in the third quarter. 
Initiative two, the prepayment of U.S. debt that's due in 2017. As part of reaching our stated goal of increasing our unsecured credit ratings to A- and A3, we want to further extend our debt maturity profile, further improve our fixed charge and debt service coverage ratios and increase our unencumbered asset pool. 
To this end, we'll be redeeming our $290.9 million, 5.7% bond due in 2017 and prepaying $137 million of 6.32% mortgage debt that's due in December of 2017. The funding of the aggregate principal amount of $427.9 million and the prepayment charge of $22 million or $0.05 per share, which will impact net income and headline FFO, will be made with the combination of proceeds from asset sales, availability under our revolving credit facility and depending on market conditions, issuance of an unsecured bond. 
Initiative three, merging our primary taxable REIT subsidiary, Kimco Realty Services, into Kimco Realty Corporation. This tax-free merger will effectively transfer the ownership of our Albertsons investment in over 30 shopping center assets. Many of which were developed in our former merchant building business but retained and today are considered long-term hold properties. 
This transaction will provide us greater tax efficiency as well as reduce our administrative costs. In conjunction with the merger, which is expected to be completed in the third quarter, generally accepted accounting principles require the establishment of evaluation reserve when it is more likely than not that deferred tax assets will not be realized. 
As such, a noncash charge against net income of $66 million or $0.16 per share and headline FFO of $41 million or $0.10 a share, respectively, will be recorded. The difference between the net income charge and the FFO charge is related to the tax impact from impairments previously taken on operating properties, which were excluded from FFO. 
Now subsequent to the merger, a portion of this valuation reserve may no longer be required in the event certain taxable transactions related to these assets occur. This would include a monetization of our Albertsons investment. 
In total, the 3 initiatives just discussed are expected to have a total impact on net income of approximately $114 million or $0.27 per share and on headline FFO of $89 million or $0.21 per share. 
As a result of the charges, we are revising our headline FFO per share guidance range to $1.34 to $1.42 with the midpoint of $1.38 from the previous headline FFO per share guidance range of $1.54 to $1.62 with the midpoint of $1.58. We continue to anticipate that the bulk of our transactions will occur in the fourth quarter. 
We are reaffirming our FFO as adjusted or recurring FFO per share guidance range of $1.48 to $1.52 with the midpoint of $1.50, which builds upon our solid first half performance and the expected benefits from the 3 initiatives, along with the impact from the Sports Authority liquidation and our increased disposition range. 
And with that, we'd be happy to take your questions.

componenttext: Okay. So we ended in really good shape. I'll take it in pieces. The line of credit, we ended with about $100 million on. So we had plenty of capacity on our $1.75 billion credit facility. As it relates to the mortgages that we will be prepaying, that will probably happen on September 1. Notices are -- have been sent to them, and then the bonds will be paid at the end of the month. So added roughly -- it's 30 days, 35 days, and we will monitor the bond market closely and probably be active sooner than later, I would guess. As it relates to the asset sales, again, there's a fair amount. I think Ross mentioned that there's 20 assets that are either under contract or that we have offers on. So the second part of the year, you'll see another few hundred million dollars of sales that will help fund all these transactions that we're doing. As it relates to Canadian bonds, the cash -- most of the cash is already sitting on the balance sheet.

componenttext: Yes, it's Glenn. So we looked at our forecast and it was always anticipated that the back end of it, the third and the fourth quarters, had stronger same-site NOI growth because you have more assets -- more leases that are actually coming online starting to pay rent from lease up that was done previously. In terms of the Sports Authority reserve, where we are is probably where it's going to end at this point because what we've reversed is what we think we're going to collect. Now that they're going to close the rest of the stores, I think the reserve is where it is. So you'll just see further growth come in second -- the third and fourth quarters from really organic things happening at the portfolio level.

componenttext: Yes, it's really the latter. We've seen extreme interests and strong pricing of what we've been selling, so we've taken that opportunity to push more out into the market than what was initially contemplated. So as long as we continue to execute and get the pricing, we think it's a great opportunity to enhance the quality of the portfolio through the end of this year. And then on a go-forward basis starting in the beginning of 2017, we'll be a much more selective and opportunistic disposition program, somewhere in the $150 million range, plus or minus.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when you think about what we did, it was more about bringing the properties, the shopping center assets back into the REIT structure. These are assets that were developed by us years ago that were originally part of our merchant development business
componenttext: Well, when you think about what we did, it was more about bringing the properties, the shopping center assets back into the REIT structure. These are assets that were developed by us years ago that were originally part of our merchant development business. We've leased them up, fully developed them. Most of them are long-term hold assets. They really belong in the REIT structure. So it's a matter of trying to find the most tax-efficient way to bring them back in their appropriate space. With that, though, the Albertsons transaction and the investment in Albertsons comes along with it because we own less than 10% of the investment there and allowed us to bring it back into the REIT. So there's some benefit, potentially, that could come from it from a tax structuring standpoint. But as it relates to the PLUS business, we do have -- still have a separate TRS, where if there were things that were appropriate for that, we would house them there. This is more about the properties, though.
