componenttext: Got it. Got it. Okay. And then  [indiscernible] just curious, what does the internalization of the TRS mean for the Kimco PLUS business going forward?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, when you think about what we did, it was more about bringing the properties, the shopping center assets back into the REIT structure. These are assets that were developed by us years ago that were originally part of our merchant development business
componenttext: Well, when you think about what we did, it was more about bringing the properties, the shopping center assets back into the REIT structure. These are assets that were developed by us years ago that were originally part of our merchant development business. We've leased them up, fully developed them. Most of them are long-term hold assets. They really belong in the REIT structure. So it's a matter of trying to find the most tax-efficient way to bring them back in their appropriate space. With that, though, the Albertsons transaction and the investment in Albertsons comes along with it because we own less than 10% of the investment there and allowed us to bring it back into the REIT. So there's some benefit, potentially, that could come from it from a tax structuring standpoint. But as it relates to the PLUS business, we do have -- still have a separate TRS, where if there were things that were appropriate for that, we would house them there. This is more about the properties though.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Got you. And since you mentioned Albertsons, any update there on potential thoughts for the IPO?
componenttext: Got you. Got you. And since you mentioned Albertsons, any update there on potential thoughts for the IPO?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Ray Edwards. Well, the company is still pursuing the IPO option and the S-1 is kept updated and I think it will be updated again next week on that. The company is also looking at other opportunity for us to monetize part of our investment whi
componenttext: Yes, this is Ray Edwards. Well, the company is still pursuing the IPO option and the S-1 is kept updated and I think it will be updated again next week on that. The company is also looking at other opportunity for us to monetize part of our investment while we're waiting for the IPO market to come around.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Paul Morgan of Canaccord.
componenttext: The next question is from Paul Morgan of Canaccord.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on that. So you mentioned that the transactional income you're expecting is still back-end loaded. But I guess, I sort of understood that when you said that last quarter, that was referring to Albertsons, at least largely. Is that -- can
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that. So you mentioned that the transactional income you're expecting is still back-end loaded. But I guess, I sort of understood that when you said that last quarter, that was referring to Albertsons, at least largely. Is that -- can you help kind of me understand that since that's probably not going to happen at least the way maybe you anticipated earlier in the year kind of how do I think about Albertsons and then the transactional kind of back-end-loaded number?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The transactional income is still premised on some level of monetization of our Albertsons investment. That's what's there, Ray?
componenttext: The transactional income is still premised on some level of monetization of our Albertsons investment. That's what's there, Ray?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, in 2013, October, when they tried the IPO, it didn't work out. We've kept the, as I said before, the S-1 updated on file to do that. But as markets are fickle, the partners have gotten together and looking at other opportunities as a path to
componenttext: Yes, I mean, in 2013, October, when they tried the IPO, it didn't work out. We've kept the, as I said before, the S-1 updated on file to do that. But as markets are fickle, the partners have gotten together and looking at other opportunities as a path to monetize part of our investment and we're considering to doing that. And that may be a vehicle for us to monetize, and we're optimistic it will happen this year. So we're still on track for it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just real quick. You mentioned the cap rate compression for kind of major metro assets. How widespread do you think you might see that? Is it something that's kind of trickling into secondary markets or B assets? Or is this kind of institut
componenttext: Okay. And then just real quick. You mentioned the cap rate compression for kind of major metro assets. How widespread do you think you might see that? Is it something that's kind of trickling into secondary markets or B assets? Or is this kind of institutional quality demand that's driving it, and so kind of more restrictive?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, on the institutional assets, they continue to compress. In the secondary markets, we're still seeing very strong pricing. Our dispositions in the U.S. are still in the high 6s, low 7s, particularly with assets that have a grocer, that is
componenttext: Well, certainly, on the institutional assets, they continue to compress. In the secondary markets, we're still seeing very strong pricing. Our dispositions in the U.S. are still in the high 6s, low 7s, particularly with assets that have a grocer, that is the dominant grocer within that market. We're still seeing very strong pricing even in the secondary and tertiary markets. Where there's a little bit of softness is more in the commodity-type retail, where there is no true value-add, and our relatively flat asset with no grocer is starting to see a little bit of trickle upwards in cap rates, but still well within the range of expectation and within pricing that we're comfortable selling.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: The next question is from Alexander Goldfarb of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, just to clarify on the guidance, you -- it sounded on one hand like you're including a bond offering just because you're going to get $9.5 million of benefit this year from the TRS and the bond takeouts, and yet -- then it sounded like you weren't
componenttext: Glenn, just to clarify on the guidance, you -- it sounded on one hand like you're including a bond offering just because you're going to get $9.5 million of benefit this year from the TRS and the bond takeouts, and yet -- then it sounded like you weren't including an unsecured deal in your numbers this year. So can you just clarify what's in it? And then maybe it's just that the bond deal may be so late in the year that it doesn't impact this year's numbers.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the guidance does contemplate refinancing what we're calling on the U.S. side with a bond. So that is part of guidance.
componenttext: No, I mean, the guidance does contemplate refinancing what we're calling on the U.S. side with a bond. So that is part of guidance.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then because you guys traditionally give your next year's guidance with the third quarter, you mentioned at the start about all the preferreds being callable next year and maybe the 1s and the 5s are still attractive. But certainly, you go
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then because you guys traditionally give your next year's guidance with the third quarter, you mentioned at the start about all the preferreds being callable next year and maybe the 1s and the 5s are still attractive. But certainly, you got a 6% one out there. Should -- as we think about our '17 numbers, we're obviously adjusting for the TRS and the bond takeouts. Should we also be thinking about the preferreds coming out? Or is that a decision that you just mentioned they're callable, but we shouldn't read anything into that?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, as we get in -- first of all, as far as guidance, we don't do guidance in the third quarter. We do it later. And second, I mentioned it because it is another opportunity for us to further reduce our overall cost of capital. Again, but it's go
componenttext: Well, again, as we get in -- first of all, as far as guidance, we don't do guidance in the third quarter. We do it later. And second, I mentioned it because it is another opportunity for us to further reduce our overall cost of capital. Again, but it's going to be subject to market conditions at the time and where rates are, so I'd throw it out there because it's something that is near term. It's on our radar screen.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the commentary about the strong pricing environment that caused you to increase your dispo guidance for the year, and then also thinking about the comment about a more normalized level of 2017. I guess, if we still -- if we continue to
componenttext: Just going back to the commentary about the strong pricing environment that caused you to increase your dispo guidance for the year, and then also thinking about the comment about a more normalized level of 2017. I guess, if we still -- if we continue to see pricing hold up and maybe even improve over the back half of this year, I mean, should we be thinking about something more than $150 million just as you look to take advantage of that pricing?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we really feel like we're at the end of our transformation. So we'll continue to be opportunistic, but we're very happy with the level of the portfolio, the quality of the assets that we have once this year is completed. So we'll always evaluate the
componenttext: Well, we really feel like we're at the end of our transformation. So we'll continue to be opportunistic, but we're very happy with the level of the portfolio, the quality of the assets that we have once this year is completed. So we'll always evaluate the quality of the properties, where the risk levels are, if markets are moving and things of that nature. But we don't anticipate any larger-scale disposition program beyond this year.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just maybe the situation in Puerto Rico for a second. I'm just curious if you can provide some commentary on what you're seeing there.
componenttext: Okay. And then just maybe the situation in Puerto Rico for a second. I'm just curious if you can provide some commentary on what you're seeing there.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. The Puerto Rico portfolio is holding up nicely. The occupancy is still above 95%. Same-site was positive, but obviously, relatively muted. So it's one that, with the recent announcement of the PROMESA, I think that the optimism is taking hold on the
componenttext: Sure. The Puerto Rico portfolio is holding up nicely. The occupancy is still above 95%. Same-site was positive, but obviously, relatively muted. So it's one that, with the recent announcement of the PROMESA, I think that the optimism is taking hold on the island. Clearly, they have some issues to work through on the debt levels. But we think from the shopping center standpoint that the traffic volume is still very, very high. The sales are strong. So we think overall, the outlook has gotten a bit brighter recently.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just comment on the Dania project and Pentagon? It seems like the -- that some of the numbers have changed a little bit. I'm just wondering if it's a cosmetic choice in terms of to take out a Phase 2 disclosure? Or is there actually a change in
componenttext: Could you just comment on the Dania project and Pentagon? It seems like the -- that some of the numbers have changed a little bit. I'm just wondering if it's a cosmetic choice in terms of to take out a Phase 2 disclosure? Or is there actually a change in the scope of the project?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We actually broke out the -- both projects in phases. So like we've talked about earlier, most of our projects have what we are calling off-ramps and phases that we can actually see if they want to go or no go on the projects. So on Pentagon, the Ph
componenttext: Sure. We actually broke out the -- both projects in phases. So like we've talked about earlier, most of our projects have what we are calling off-ramps and phases that we can actually see if they want to go or no go on the projects. So on Pentagon, the Phase 1, as I mentioned, is really the parking deck that's nearing completion and then the first tower that's in titles and is ready to go vertical as soon as the parking deck is complete. The second phase on Pentagon is the second tower. So again, we'll monitor the absorption rate and the rents and where they're coming in and then make the determination on the second tower if and when it's appropriate. Dania, same thing. First phase, we broke out that costs, so you can see exactly what goes into the first phase and that's the Costco portion as well as some junior anchors that we're moving along nicely. The second phase there is going to be more of a higher-density play, so we broke that out as well, as I mentioned, the H&M lease is fully executed so the pre-leasing is starting to move forward on that as well. So we wanted to give you a bit more granularity on the phasing opportunities we have on some of these larger-scale projects.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to follow-up on a previous question on Albertsons. You mentioned that you might partially monetize it before the IPO, if I heard that correctly. How do you think about that? Because I'm guessing there's probably a pretty decent liquidity di
componenttext: Okay. And just to follow-up on a previous question on Albertsons. You mentioned that you might partially monetize it before the IPO, if I heard that correctly. How do you think about that? Because I'm guessing there's probably a pretty decent liquidity discount that you would have to take if you wanted to monetize it before the shares are publicly traded. So what's behind -- what goes on behind that thought process there?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for us and our partners, we don't think that the discount would be that great, first of all. And we wouldn't be selling that large of a piece of the investment. So what we feel that'll do for us is, one, put a little money in our market, but
componenttext: Well, I think for us and our partners, we don't think that the discount would be that great, first of all. And we wouldn't be selling that large of a piece of the investment. So what we feel that'll do for us is, one, put a little money in our market, but also validate the valuation that we have in Albertsons. And hopefully, you will add 15% or 20% to the valuation after we announce that transaction.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael Mueller of JPMorgan.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about Sports Authority's 6 to 12 months, I think, to address the remaining boxes. When -- what time period do you see most of the boxes actually occupied and renting by? Like how far down the road?
componenttext: You talked about Sports Authority's 6 to 12 months, I think, to address the remaining boxes. When -- what time period do you see most of the boxes actually occupied and renting by? Like how far down the road?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have pretty clear visibility into the absorption that we think is going to occur. We have LOIs working on 18 of the boxes right now that are pretty close to fully executed. So we actually think we have a chance to be cautiously optimistic that a lot of
componenttext: We have pretty clear visibility into the absorption that we think is going to occur. We have LOIs working on 18 of the boxes right now that are pretty close to fully executed. So we actually think we have a chance to be cautiously optimistic that a lot of them will be done before the end of the year. But again, we want to -- it's probably going to take 6 to 12 months before all of them are fully occupied and the rent starts to come in. So we do have one lease that's fully executed with a grocery store that's 33% above prior rent. And we continue to see what other opportunities exist to add grocery components going forward to the opportunity set that we have.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that 6 to 12 was actually occupied and rent paying not just addressed and leased?
componenttext: Okay. So that 6 to 12 was actually occupied and rent paying not just addressed and leased?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Richard Hill of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is from Richard Hill of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a quick question about the rental rate releasing spreads. First of all, congrats on getting those to highest level in 3 years. I had a question, though. It looks like there were some absolute increases between new leases and renewals, but maybe also
componenttext: I had a quick question about the rental rate releasing spreads. First of all, congrats on getting those to highest level in 3 years. I had a question, though. It looks like there were some absolute increases between new leases and renewals, but maybe also an additional weighting towards new leases over renewals. Am I thinking about that correctly? And if so, is there anything there? Are you seeing more leasing velocity on the space? What drove that?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly you're seeing that the occupancy is hitting near an all-time high. So when spaces come available, there's usually a bidding war to get high-quality real estate in this market. So that's clearly what's driving the rental spread, both in the n
componenttext: Well, clearly you're seeing that the occupancy is hitting near an all-time high. So when spaces come available, there's usually a bidding war to get high-quality real estate in this market. So that's clearly what's driving the rental spread, both in the new leases. And typically now, when you see renewals come up, it's more option notices that are coming in rather than, say, pure renewals because people are worried about giving up their high-quality real estate because they know there's a chance that they might lose it if they don't exercise that option.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Collin Mings of Raymond James.
componenttext: The next question comes from Collin Mings of Raymond James.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to Alex's question. Where do you think you could price preferreds today?
componenttext: Just going back to Alex's question. Where do you think you could price preferreds today?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Preferreds today were probably in the low 5s. I mean, in the low 5s.
componenttext: Preferreds today were probably in the low 5s. I mean, in the low 5s.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Chris Lucas of Capital One Securities.
componenttext: The next question comes from Chris Lucas of Capital One Securities.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, as you guys have moved very far down the line on simplification, I was curious as to what your thoughts are on the remaining JVs and whether there's been any additional conversations with your partners in terms of how those may be either dissolve
componenttext: I guess, as you guys have moved very far down the line on simplification, I was curious as to what your thoughts are on the remaining JVs and whether there's been any additional conversations with your partners in terms of how those may be either dissolved or whatever.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really have 3 large remaining JV partners and -- left and that's really Prudential, CPP and the New York Common Fund. So they're all great partners, and they're all long-standing relationships that we've had over the years. And typically, they're long-
componenttext: We really have 3 large remaining JV partners and -- left and that's really Prudential, CPP and the New York Common Fund. So they're all great partners, and they're all long-standing relationships that we've had over the years. And typically, they're long-term holders. So I don't see any sort of large transaction in the near term. But there's always bites of the apple that we think we can get on the margin, whether it's a smaller portfolio of properties, or a few here and there that we can -- that we're able to acquire, similar to the Dania and Oakwood transaction that we announced this quarter. So again, we'll take the opportunities when they present themselves. But again, we're really down to 3 large major partners that are all great partners and long-term holders of high-quality real estate.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And also 2 of those ventures, the common fund venture that we have, we own almost 50% of it. And with CPP, we own 55% of it. So we are a major stakeholder in those.
componenttext: Right. And also 2 of those ventures, the common fund venture that we have, we own almost 50% of it. And with CPP, we own 55% of it. So we are a major stakeholder in those.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then -- and Glenn, just a quick follow-up on the sort of the guidance adjustment as it related to the transactional income expense line. Can you just sort of walk -- prior guidance was $25 million to $42 million of gains. Now it's $40 million to $59 m
componenttext: And then -- and Glenn, just a quick follow-up on the sort of the guidance adjustment as it related to the transactional income expense line. Can you just sort of walk -- prior guidance was $25 million to $42 million of gains. Now it's $40 million to $59 million of loss. You've given us the 1 number, the $89 million, for some of these strategic investments. I guess I'm curious as to what the other delta might be.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really it. It's the same as what we had before. The difference is our expectation of some monetization on Albertsons in the number. So the only change to the guidance that occurred really relates around the $89 million, which is maybe $0.01 differe
componenttext: That's really it. It's the same as what we had before. The difference is our expectation of some monetization on Albertsons in the number. So the only change to the guidance that occurred really relates around the $89 million, which is maybe $0.01 difference because we actually had some transactional income that's already done. So the preferred equity investment that was sold this quarter and the one from last quarter gave us $0.01 of headline FFO.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason White of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason White of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to cap rates for a minute. You talked about some of the higher-quality properties trading at lower cap rates. What are you seeing in kind of the middle, the higher end, like some of the properties you're selling? Are those cap rates compre
componenttext: Just going back to cap rates for a minute. You talked about some of the higher-quality properties trading at lower cap rates. What are you seeing in kind of the middle, the higher end, like some of the properties you're selling? Are those cap rates compressing as well?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they've really maintained the level that we've seen for the last 9 to 12 months, so in the U.S. and some of the secondary markets, we're in the high 6s into the low 7s. And if there's a grocery anchor, even if it's outside of the core markets, we've
componenttext: Yes, they've really maintained the level that we've seen for the last 9 to 12 months, so in the U.S. and some of the secondary markets, we're in the high 6s into the low 7s. And if there's a grocery anchor, even if it's outside of the core markets, we've sold a couple of assets in the high 5s and the low 6s. So we still feel really good about where cap rates are. We have not seen them change materially, and the buyer pools have been a bit shallow for the last 12 months compared to the beginning stages into the middle of 2015. But those groups are still very serious. They're able to get financing when they need it, and we haven't really seen any hiccups in the deals that we've put under contract in getting it across the finish line.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just one on your same-store NOI guidance. If you look at the top end of your range, is that still on the table? It kind of implies a pretty high growth rate in the back half of the year with the Sports Authority headwind. Is there any way
componenttext: Great. And then just one on your same-store NOI guidance. If you look at the top end of your range, is that still on the table? It kind of implies a pretty high growth rate in the back half of the year with the Sports Authority headwind. Is there any way of achieving that high end at this point?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's always a way, depending on how quickly certain lease up happens and cash starts flowing. Again, we've been guiding more towards the middle, somewhere in the 3% to 3.1% range, but it's a range, so we don't control everything that happens. B
componenttext: I mean, there's always a way, depending on how quickly certain lease up happens and cash starts flowing. Again, we've been guiding more towards the middle, somewhere in the 3% to 3.1% range, but it's a range, so we don't control everything that happens. But we do feel comfortable towards that middle end of that range.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rich Moore of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Rich Moore of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, have you seen any change at Kmart recently? Any difference in that retailer? Or maybe any difference in your discussions with them?
componenttext: I'm curious, have you seen any change at Kmart recently? Any difference in that retailer? Or maybe any difference in your discussions with them?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really haven't. I think there was some news stories that came out recently about some the employee sentiment, and that I think was taken maybe out of context on certain stores. The 2 leases that we had actually coming due this quarter, both of them exe
componenttext: We really haven't. I think there was some news stories that came out recently about some the employee sentiment, and that I think was taken maybe out of context on certain stores. The 2 leases that we had actually coming due this quarter, both of them exercised options. So I think that gives you some insight into it's still very much a trying to make do with what they can. But we continue to monitor it. We only have 21 sites left, a little less than 1% of ABR. We have 4 coming due in 2017 without any options that are all redevelopments. So we're still continuing to monitor the situation and look to try and redevelop that real estate.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean -- this is Ray. I mean, Kmart has a lot of flexibility because they haven't signed a lease in 20 years. So every one of the leases is probably the last 5 years of the main term with an option period. So they have a lot of flexibility to renew lease
componenttext: I mean -- this is Ray. I mean, Kmart has a lot of flexibility because they haven't signed a lease in 20 years. So every one of the leases is probably the last 5 years of the main term with an option period. So they have a lot of flexibility to renew lease where they're making money like they did with a couple of ours. And where they're not making money, get out of them without having to pay lease disposition programs. So they have a lot flexibility on the Kmart side to wind down stores in a short period of time.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from R.J. Milligan of Baird.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from R.J. Milligan of Baird.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, a question about 2017. As we look into next year, what do you anticipate the potential impact to same-store NOI growth will be from the empty Sports Authority boxes? I know it's going to be partially offset by higher rental rates. Just curious if y
componenttext: Glenn, a question about 2017. As we look into next year, what do you anticipate the potential impact to same-store NOI growth will be from the empty Sports Authority boxes? I know it's going to be partially offset by higher rental rates. Just curious if you could sort of give us a range as to what you think the impact might be.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's probably in the 50- to 60-basis-point range.
componenttext: It's probably in the 50- to 60-basis-point range.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And largely dependent on timing of when those leases start paying rent?
componenttext: And largely dependent on timing of when those leases start paying rent?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are no additional questions at this time. This concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to David Bujnicki for closing remarks.
componenttext: There are no additional questions at this time. This concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to David Bujnicki for closing remarks.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carrie. Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO.
componenttext:
Thanks, Carrie. Good morning, and thank you for joining Kimco's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. With me on the call this morning is Conor Flynn, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Ross Cooper, Chief Investment Officer; and Glenn Cohen, our CFO. In addition, other members of our executive team are also available to address questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks, including Milton Cooper, Dave Jamieson and Ray Edwards. 
As a reminder, statements made during the course of this call may be deemed forward-looking, and it is important to note that the company's actual results could differ materially from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to the company's SEC filings that address such factors. 
During this presentation, management may make reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures that we believe help investors better understand Kimco's operating results. Examples include, but are not limited to, funds from operations and net operating income. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Conor.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. I'm pleased to announce another strong quarter driven by our high-quality operating portfolio and the tireless efforts of our team. This quarter, we made the decision to remove any contribution to our NAREI
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us today. 
I'm pleased to announce another strong quarter driven by our high-quality operating portfolio and the tireless efforts of our team. This quarter, we made the decision to remove any contribution to our NAREIT-defined FFO from [indiscernible] monetization for 2 major reasons. First and foremost, we believe we should not succumb to the pressures of short-term [indiscernible] and pursue the sale of a portion of our Albertsons investment in an environment that would negatively impact creating long-term value for our shareholders. Currently, grocery stores are dealing with food deflation, while the IPO more remains challenging. Despite these headwinds, Albertsons continues to increase EBITDA providing free cash flow to pay down debt and invest in the business. Second, and sometimes forgotten, are the significant real estate holdings of the company. Close to half of the chain's 2,300 stores are either owned or under long-term ground leases, with concentrations in desirable markets, such as Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Washington, D.C. In fact, the recently updated S-1 noted an estimated value of $12.1 billion for its real estate holdings. We believe that over a medium-term horizon, our investment in Albertsons will provide Kimco with significant capital to reinvest in our recurring business activities and create long-term shareholder value. As a reminder, we are just shy of 2 years into the merger of Albertsons and Safeway and the company continues to reap the benefits of scale through execution on the planned synergies. The S-1 remains current and we continue to monitor the markets with our partners. To be clear, we remain focused on our core business and we'll continue to fund capital requirements of free cash flow after dividends, opportunistic use of our ATM and disposition proceeds. 
Our 2020 Vision outlines our plan to create long-term shareholder value by focusing on our building blocks of growth, reducing leverage and maintaining our cost efficient capital structure. The fundamentals of our opener shopping center portfolio remains strong due to favorable balance of supply and demand in the major metro markets. As the performance on key metrics demonstrates, our operating platform continues to deliver value to our shareholders. A wide range of opener retailers, including our first Nike store, continue to expand and seek growth opportunities in high-quality real estate. Supply has modestly increased recently due to bankruptcies and an [indiscernible] closings and we are monitoring closely the shadow supply coming from struggling department stores at enclosed malls. Overall, however, this environment provides the ability for us to position our real estate with best-in-class retailers that drive more traffic and sales. While The Sports Authority liquidation drove the dip in anchor occupancy, we are pleased with the leasing momentum on those boxes. Seven of our 25 Sports Authority boxes are now fully committed. The deals include: [indiscernible] sporting goods; a Land Rover Jaguar dealership; [indiscernible] supply hardware; home goods [indiscernible] combo; Burlington; and [indiscernible] Grocery. The anchor leasing volume was the strongest this quarter year-to-date, with 19 anchor deals fully executed. Small shop leasing continues to progress. Even though pro rata occupancy remain flat this quarter, this is primarily due to the dispositions of a number of fully occupied centers that had limited upside [indiscernible] and the purchase of assets, with significant redevelopment potential that included considerable small shop vacancy, which we believe offers future upsides. 
The strategic free development and development pipeline, which we are calling our Signature Series, continues to mature and deliver results. As an update, we moved the first phase of our flagship suburban square redevelopment for the active pipeline, where we have an executed lease to expand Trader Joe's and construction underway to build a new parking facility to provide Kimco with further densification opportunities. Separately, our Whole Foods development is now open and thriving in Wynnewood, Pennsylvania and has moved out of our development pipeline and into the operating portfolio. Our Signature Series continues to provide the company with significant internal growth opportunities and we remain laser-focused on the execution. This quarter, we delivered $65 million of redevelopment projects, producing on incremental ROI of 10%. 
I will now turn the call over to Ross who will provide a deeper dive in the transaction activity this quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Conor. The third quarter was a successful continuation of our strategy and transformation of the portfolio composition, resulting a higher quality asset-based, with stronger demographics and tenancy. This includes our [indiscernible] marketpl
componenttext:
Thank you, Conor. 
The third quarter was a successful continuation of our strategy and transformation of the portfolio composition, resulting a higher quality asset-based, with stronger demographics and tenancy. This includes our [indiscernible] marketplace acquisition in Metro DC, which offers significant value creation and redevelopment opportunities for our team. In just 2 short months of ownership, our plans to reposition the asset are underway and the preliminary interest has been very strong. We expect to begin seeking municipal input regarding our plans in the coming month. Also, during the third quarter, we bought out a JV partner on a 4-property portfolio, with asset located in our core markets in Atlanta, Houston Washington, D.C. and Pittsburgh and acquiring additional JV asset, Gateway center in Seattle, where we are working on a supermarket and pharmacy lease to reposition this well located asset. These acquisitions, along with the Canadian asset sales, helped further reduce our JV portfolio as we continue to simplify our ownership position while increasing the percentage of wholly owned net operating income coming from the overall portfolio. The wholly owned NOI is now 85% compared to being at a low of 60% level a few years earlier. In Q3 2015, we had 264 JV properties and at Q3 2016, we have only 135 JV properties, nearly a 50% reduction in 1 year. 
The acquisition [indiscernible] continues to be extremely competitive for core assets as investors of all types chase hard assets in the United States. Pension fund advisers, REITs and private operators have all narrowed the definition of core, which has further limited the available supply of institutional quality assets. This has created bidding wars for the highest quality assets in major MSAs, pushing down cap rates even further, notwithstanding the potential risk of interest rates hikes in the future. While some may view the current real estate environment as expensive, on a relative basis, we continue to believe that, compared to alternative investment options, our asset class remains a wonderful investment, with a healthy spread between cap rates and treasury's. Our focus remains on making investments and solid real estate with a strong business plan. 
We also consider the dynamic that new shopping center development remains at all-time lows, together with the living and shopping [indiscernible] of millennials to recognize that the first ring outside the Irving core has become extremely desirable for investment, redevelopment and repurposing. This has created mix use opportunities offering a live work play environment, which we believe offer attractive investment opportunities. We are constantly evaluating these types of projects while remaining disciplined in our search for quality assets. 
On the dispositions side, the sale of our interest in 5 Canadian assets has reduced our ownership in Canada to 1 remaining shopping center and 2 land parcels. In just 12 months, the NOI coming from Canada have gotten from approximately $19 million in the third quarter of 2015 to roughly $1 million in the third quarter of 2016. We are thrilled with our progress. In the United States, we sold 7 assets for $53.3 million, 49 million Kimco share. Execution on sales of noncore assets has become more challenging and it is critical to perform due diligence to the buyer [indiscernible] before selecting the buyer. In addition, we've seen the pricing between the core trophy and the secondary market assets, particularly non-grocery, widen from 9 to 12 months ago. Fortunately, we are at the tail end of the heavy lifting and expect to close approximately $100 million of asset sales in the fourth quarter. We will continue to review the portfolio and judiciously sell assets that do not fit within our long-term 2020 Vision. 
Now I would like to introduce Glenn to provide additional color and insight on our financial performance for the quarter.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ross, and good morning. Our execution during the third quarter takes another step forward towards achieving our 2020 Vision. Our operating results were solid despite the short-term headwinds of The Sports Authority store close. We also successfu
componenttext:
Thanks, Ross, and good morning. 
Our execution during the third quarter takes another step forward towards achieving our 2020 Vision. Our operating results were solid despite the short-term headwinds of The Sports Authority store close. We also successfully completed 3 strategic initiatives related to our Canadian debt repayment, U.S. debt repayment and the merger of our TRS into the REIT. Headline FFO per share, which represents the official NAREIT definition, was $0.18 per diluted share for the third quarter. Included in the headline result is $45.7 million of early extinguishment of debt charges in connection with the prepayment of 350 million Canadian denominated bonds, with a weighted average interest rate of 4.77%, the prepayment of our 5.7% $291 million U.S. bond and the prepayment of $137 million of 6.32% mortgage debt encumbering 10 properties. Also included in the headline result is a non-cash FFO charge of $36.2 million associated with the deferred tax valuation allowance in connection with the TRS REIT merger. The one-time charges associated with the prepayments in the TRS REIT merger totaled $0.20 per share. These initiatives will enhance our future profitability and our tax efficiencies. 
FFO as adjusted, or recurring FFO, which excludes transactional income and expenses and nonoperating impairments, was $0.38 per diluted share for the third quarter, up 5.6% on $0.36 per diluted share last year. These solid results include the diluted impact of further transforming and simplifying the business over the past year with the sale of over $1 billion of U.S. assets and another $1.1 billion of assets in Canada and Mexico. The proceeds raised from these efforts were used to acquire $800 million of high-quality, wholly owned U.S. assets in our key markets from our joint venture partners and third parties. The net effect of this activity reduced net operating income, including our pro rata share from the joint ventures, by $23.5 million. This was largely offset by a reduction in financing costs of $18.2 million related to lower debt levels of $1 billion, lower interest rates on debt refinancings and the redemption of our $175 million, 6.9% preferred tax last year. Recurring tax savings from the TRS REIT merger were an additional contributor. 
Turning to our operating metrics. U.S. occupancy stands at 95.1%, down 90 basis points from last quarter and 50 basis points from a year ago. The Sports Authority's store closure account for 85 days as points of the decrease from last quarter. Positive net absorption of 35 basis points from a year ago mitigated the TSA impact. As Conor mentioned, our operating team is making great strides in releasing these boxes, with a higher quality tenants that will drive increased traffic to the centers. Occupancy of our boxes over 10,000 square feet remain a healthy 97% in our small shop occupancy [indiscernible] 89.2% of 120 basis points from a year ago. Leasing spreads continue to be strong, with new leasing spreads of 26.6% and renewal on option spreads, up 7.8%, for a combined spreads of 12.9%. U.S. same-site NOI growth was 3.3% for the quarter, notwithstanding a 110 basis point negative impact from The Sports Authority bankruptcy. Redevelopments contributed 60 basis points this quarter. For the 9 months, U.S. same-site NOI growth stands at 2.9%, including a negative 60 basis point impact from TSA. We have narrowed our U.S. same site NOI guidance for the full year to a range of 2.7% to 3.3% from the previous range of 2.5% to 3.5%. We remain focused on further strengthening our balance sheet metrics and debt maturity profile. Consolidated net debt to EBITDA, as adjusted, is 5.8x, with a target of 5x to 5.5x. On a look through basis, including pro rata joint venture debt and perpetual preferred stock, the look through metric was 7.1x, with a goal of 6.46.9x. During the quarter, we issued a new $500 million 10-year unsecured bond and a coupon of 2.8%, the second 10-year coupon ever issued by a REIT. Over the last year, we've extended our consolidated weighted average debt maturity profile to 6.7 years from 4.3 years just a year ago. 
We opportunistically utilize our ATM program to issue 4.8 million shares of common stock at a weighted average sale price of $30.59 per share, raising $146.7 million of proceeds. The proceeds we used for accretive and value creating acquisitions of the 4 property joint venture buyouts and the Kentlands project that Ross mentioned in his remarks. Year-to-date, we have issued 9.8 million shares of common stock, raising net proceeds of $285 million. 
Let me spend a moment on guidance. Based on the solid results during the first 9 months, achieving $1.12 per diluted share for FFO as adjusted, we are narrowing our FFO as adjusted per share guidance range to $1.49 to $1.51 from the previous per share guidance range of $1.48 to $1.52. For the 9 months, we achieved NAREIT-defined FFO of $0.94 per diluted share. We previously stated that our 2016 NAREIT-defined guidance included a partial Albertsons monetization in the fourth quarter. As Conor mentioned, we're not anticipating a monetization of our outlets and investment this year. As such, we revised our NAREIT-defined FFO guidance to a range of $1.30 to $1.32, with a midpoint of $1.31 from the previous range of $1.34 to $1.42, with a midpoint of $1.38. The reduction is solely attributable to not monetizing a portion of our Albertsons investment this year. We remain confident that we will be able to do so in accordance with our 2020 Vision. 
We are currently deeply into our property by property budget process and we'll provide 2017 guidance on our next earnings call. 
Our initial 2017 NAREIT-defined guidance range will not include any transactional encumbered expense. As such, our NAREIT-defined FFO per share range and our FFO as adjusted per share range will be comparable at the start of the year and will only differ upon the execution of specifically identified transactional events. We remain focused on growing our recurring earnings and cash flows. 
Lastly, we are pleased to announce that based on our 2016 performance, and expectations for 2017, our Board of Directors has approved an increase in the common stock quarterly cash dividend to $0.27 per share from $0.255, an increase of 5.9% on an annualized basis. Our FFO as adjusted payout ratio remains conservative among the lowest in the peer group. 
And with that, we'd be happy to answer your questions.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, as you think about the possibility that we're nearing the end of the cycle, there's increasing evidence of softness in retailing and you talked about, in your opening remarks, about greater supplies fees. You have a lot teed up in terms of larger s
componenttext: Conor, as you think about the possibility that we're nearing the end of the cycle, there's increasing evidence of softness in retailing and you talked about, in your opening remarks, about greater supplies fees. You have a lot teed up in terms of larger scale redevelopment [indiscernible] over the next several years. How might your capital allocation priority shift with the potential for a slowdown in demand [indiscernible]?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. I think when you look at our pipeline of opportunities over the next 5 years, a lot of the projects that we've identified have an enormous amount of pre-leasing involved in those projects. And when we always look at the projects, we
componenttext: It's a good question. I think when you look at our pipeline of opportunities over the next 5 years, a lot of the projects that we've identified have an enormous amount of pre-leasing involved in those projects. And when we always look at the projects, we also look at [indiscernible], so to give us the opportunity to hit the pause button [indiscernible] our cost of capital changes or if the market changes on us. But we feel really confident in the projects we've identified. We're also making big strides on announcing pre-leasing on all those projects. So I think when you look at the risk reward, we still feel really strong about what they will deliver to our shareholders over the next 5 years. That said, going forward, we're going to be very careful on what we add to the pipeline. We want to be sure that it's something that checks all the boxes with our strategy and where we want to take the company and the portfolio. And we also want to be very careful in terms of how much more we add to the pipeline. You'll probably see maybe another development deal or 2, but maybe probably not much more than that over the 5 years. But you will see us ramp up redevelopment where we see the opportunity because we continue to believe that, that's the best use of our capital risk-adjusted and continue to think that there's more to come when you look at our shadow supply.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we spend a lot of time trying to be a low-cost provider. We spend a lot of time watching the maintenance thing that have to happen at the projects. So we try to keep costs down as best we can as we go along, and you see that over and over again. I
componenttext: Again, we spend a lot of time trying to be a low-cost provider. We spend a lot of time watching the maintenance thing that have to happen at the projects. So we try to keep costs down as best we can as we go along, and you see that over and over again. I think the other thing you have is, some of it's also a little bit of timing based on wet weathers and things like that, whether it be from a step side, where snow is hitting, which obviously hasn't [indiscernible] parking lot projects that we have in any given point in time. But the main focus really is maintaining and keeping costs low and efficient at the properties.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add that it might be the early signs of our clustered strategy starting to take effect because we are a bit more efficient now that we look at our portfolio today versus 5 years ago and how [indiscernible] concentrated it is, it allows us to
componenttext: I would just add that it might be the early signs of our clustered strategy starting to take effect because we are a bit more efficient now that we look at our portfolio today versus 5 years ago and how [indiscernible] concentrated it is, it allows us to manage more with less.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start, I'm sure Conor will add in. Roughly, 75% of the tenants exercise their options. So that -- you see this wide gap, which is why the amount of liquidity in the leases that happens in any given year is relatively modest. In terms of upside in the
componenttext: I'll start, I'm sure Conor will add in. Roughly, 75% of the tenants exercise their options. So that -- you see this wide gap, which is why the amount of liquidity in the leases that happens in any given year is relatively modest. In terms of upside in the below-market rents, we know that over the next 3 years, we have close to 90 leases, 90 anchor leases alone where we think the upside in those leases is roughly 50% in total. So we see a fair amount of upside as we look out the next few years.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and as part of our strategy and has been for a long period of time, to focus on huge mark-to-market opportunities and to acquire assets that have below market leases. So when you look at those anchor maturity schedule, the ones that are below-market
componenttext: Yes, and as part of our strategy and has been for a long period of time, to focus on huge mark-to-market opportunities and to acquire assets that have below market leases. So when you look at those anchor maturity schedule, the ones that are below-market are typically going to exercise that option, unless there comes a time where they give space back to us. And we're starting to see some opportunities there come to fruition. So when you look at our mark-to-market opportunities, what we try and do is we show you the ones where we have control over, where there's no more options left or we think that those spreads are very much achievable and continue to try to harvest that [indiscernible] portfolio.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about a couple of different places, cap rates and narrowing definition among institutional investors in kind of what is core, what's not and how a little bit harder to sell noncore assets. Could you maybe dive in a little bit more, is there a w
componenttext: You talked about a couple of different places, cap rates and narrowing definition among institutional investors in kind of what is core, what's not and how a little bit harder to sell noncore assets. Could you maybe dive in a little bit more, is there a way to kind of quantify maybe how much that spread has widened in the past 6, 9 months? And then in what ways is the definition getting there? Are we talking about secondary markets? Or just sort of demographics within metros or the tenancy of a center? Any detail?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When we look  [indiscernible] experience in the market today, that the fully occupied stabilized assets are the ones where we're really seeing the shallower buyer pull, particularly without a grocery anchor. The grocery anchored shopping center stil
componenttext: Sure. When we look  [indiscernible] experience in the market today, that the fully occupied stabilized assets are the ones where we're really seeing the shallower buyer pull, particularly without a grocery anchor. The grocery anchored shopping center still a see a bit of a deeper bench of bidders. By way of example, our Q3 dispositions average in the mid-7s on a cap rate range. Overall, for the year, blended, we're closer to a seven. So the efforts are a little bit of the context. But that being said, we are fortunate that we're in the very latter stage of our disposition process, so not every property that we put into the market is transacted. If we don't like the pricing, then we haven't sold it but we've been pretty successful so far this year and we think that we will be for the rest of the year. In regards to the second part of the question. I think that all buyer types, whether institutional or private, are chasing upside value add in some form or fashion. So it really is, regardless of the location, the flatter income streams without any foreseeable growth have been challenging to move. But certainly, I think the definitions of core from a market perspective continue to narrow to the major markets, and it's the secondary and the tertiary markets where the institutional investors are just really not focused at all regardless of the quality of the asset within that market.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up on Albertsons. You talked early in the year about exploring may be a pre-IPO options for monetization. And I heard you say that, that's not going to be in your kind of initial outlook for '17, at least in terms of the guidance. Is that
componenttext: And as a follow-up on Albertsons. You talked early in the year about exploring may be a pre-IPO options for monetization. And I heard you say that, that's not going to be in your kind of initial outlook for '17, at least in terms of the guidance. Is that still on the table? I mean, or are you just kind of looking at may be a longer-term sort of situation there? You commented on the real estate value of $12 billion. Is kind of that one mechanism may be for you to just kind of start to take some of the [indiscernible] table?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Albertsons, we're monitoring investment very closely. Again, there's a lot of headwinds at the moment just relative to the supermarket industry between the food deflation that we've talked about. And quite candidly, the IPO market is still
componenttext: Well, I think, Albertsons, we're monitoring investment very closely. Again, there's a lot of headwinds at the moment just relative to the supermarket industry between the food deflation that we've talked about. And quite candidly, the IPO market is still pretty challenging. Having said that, the business is performing very well. The synergies that have been forecasted are coming to fruition and [indiscernible] we go, more of those synergies come and create more EBITDA for the company. So it's really the group itself, us and our partners, are monitoring the market closely. You see that with keeping our S-1 current. So we're real watching very closely for the right opportunity to begin to monetize the investments. You can look at where our partners are and know that at some point, where it makes sense, we are going to look to monetize the investment. That is clearly the path for all of us. But we want to do it prudently and where it makes the most sense to create the most shareholder value for us and everybody else in the group. So we have the ability to be very, very patient with it.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to Christie's question and some of your opening remarks about the [indiscernible] increase in supply and continuing to monitor shadow pipeline and potential increase on [indiscernible] department stores. So based on what you're seeing
componenttext: I wanted to go back to Christie's question and some of your opening remarks about the [indiscernible] increase in supply and continuing to monitor shadow pipeline and potential increase on [indiscernible] department stores. So based on what you're seeing today, is it making you more receptive just getting some deals done when you can versus holding or pushing [indiscernible]? Or even waiting for some sort of ideal replacement there?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a balance every side is looked at on a location basis and what's going on in that market. You have to really look at the supply side. Clearly, we're looking at supply now with malls as part of that, and want to identify the highest and best use for t
componenttext: It's a balance every side is looked at on a location basis and what's going on in that market. You have to really look at the supply side. Clearly, we're looking at supply now with malls as part of that, and want to identify the highest and best use for the asset and what best retailer we have to replace the vacancy with. We still see a strong demand. I mean, if you look at our categories, we still strong demand from [indiscernible], home improvement, specialty and traditional groceries, sporting goods, arts and crafts, pet supply, health and wellness, beauty, fitness. I mean, these are all categories that are alive and well and looking to grow store count. And you see that coming up in our pipeline. I mean, this quarter, we did more anchored deals than we've done all year. And we have a healthy pipeline looking forward. So even though there has been a bit more supply added to the system, it's very much a local business. You have to look at each and every site individually and make the best decision you can, merchandising mix wise as well as for the net asset value of the property. And right now, where we sit, still feel that we're in the sweet spot of retail.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For my second one, just one on Sports Authority. You mentioned [indiscernible] fully committed, the base point if you go back to last quarter, you had talked about hoping to have everything released in 6 to 12 months. So I'm wondering, is that still the t
componenttext: For my second one, just one on Sports Authority. You mentioned [indiscernible] fully committed, the base point if you go back to last quarter, you had talked about hoping to have everything released in 6 to 12 months. So I'm wondering, is that still the time frame you're thinking about? And then, from a [indiscernible] commencement standpoint, [indiscernible] realistically be thinking about that [indiscernible] in your earnings?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's still like our goal for [indiscernible] to execute on. Clearly, we've got some work to do there, but we feel good about the momentum we've displayed this quarter and hope to continue to display each and every quarter. I think the right comm
componenttext: I think that's still like our goal for [indiscernible] to execute on. Clearly, we've got some work to do there, but we feel good about the momentum we've displayed this quarter and hope to continue to display each and every quarter. I think the right commencement will coincide, depending on the box and what we have to do it. Some of the boxes will be redevelopments, where we have to expand the box. And some of them, we'll be splitting, like we did for home goods and [indiscernible]. So those are a bit more complicated deals. And the RCDs may lag versus, say, just a pure [indiscernible]. But those are ones where we believe we're adding the best-in-class retailer that help the site valuation wise as well as traffic and sales wise. So you'll see us [indiscernible] approach to the RCDs.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of modeling, I would say, the second half of '17, the back half of '17 is when the cash will start flowing. So if you think about the way we calculate same site NOI growth, it'll be more towards the back end of '17 where we can flow.
componenttext: In terms of modeling, I would say, the second half of '17, the back half of '17 is when the cash will start flowing. So if you think about the way we calculate same site NOI growth, it'll be more towards the back end of '17 where we can flow.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just kind of staying on the path, just given the amount of boxes that have been going off-line over the last few years from bankruptcies, is there anything different you're doing internally may be versus a couple of years ago to become more efficient t
componenttext: So just kind of staying on the path, just given the amount of boxes that have been going off-line over the last few years from bankruptcies, is there anything different you're doing internally may be versus a couple of years ago to become more efficient turning them around? I know it's a normal part of the business, but do you need to or have you shifted or added resources to this effort to maybe mitigate some of the downtime?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's always been part of our business. We think we're one of the best-in-class when it comes to leasing. I mean, we talk about it every day in and day out and talk about how we can be more efficient and what we can do to drive more leasing because that's
componenttext: It's always been part of our business. We think we're one of the best-in-class when it comes to leasing. I mean, we talk about it every day in and day out and talk about how we can be more efficient and what we can do to drive more leasing because that's the fuel. That's what makes the business run. So looking at everything. I think when we try and be creative, we throw everything up the wall and we like to come up with ideas and incentives that make us unique and make people want to do deals with Kimco, first and foremost. So we will always take that approach. And then always try and make sure we're doing everything we can in our power to get the leases executed as quickly as possible, whether it's condensing the deal flow in terms of how long it takes from start to finish. And then also getting that right commencement quickly and making sure we try and [indiscernible] that time frame. So we're looking at everything we can. So it's not a silver bullet type thing, every deal is different.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add. You have to understand, we have our entire platform of operating people looking at every lease that we have, we have a watch list. So we are always analyzing and looking for who the potential might be that might go out and talking t
componenttext: Yes, I would just add. You have to understand, we have our entire platform of operating people looking at every lease that we have, we have a watch list. So we are always analyzing and looking for who the potential might be that might go out and talking to tenants well in advance. So that when it does happen, we're not starting at ground zero. We've already have a lot of conversations because, again, at the end of the day for us, the key is get the rent flowing as quickly as we can. So we really are focused on the watch list tenants and where we can put someone back in place if someone was to go out.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a quick follow-up to that, as you work to your budgeting process for '17, how are you thinking about potential bankruptcies for next year? How does that watch list look? Has it been growing or is it shrinking or about the same?
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a quick follow-up to that, as you work to your budgeting process for '17, how are you thinking about potential bankruptcies for next year? How does that watch list look? Has it been growing or is it shrinking or about the same?

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's about the same. I mean, when we look at budgeting for next year, we always carry a pretty sizable amount for bankruptcies. And so we feel like we have a nice cushion when you look at our portfolio of spread of risks and our #1 tenant is TJX, a
componenttext: Well, it's about the same. I mean, when we look at budgeting for next year, we always carry a pretty sizable amount for bankruptcies. And so we feel like we have a nice cushion when you look at our portfolio of spread of risks and our #1 tenant is TJX, a relatively small percentage of our NOI. And then, we look and see what we can do in terms of leasing. And right now, we feel like we still have momentum moving in our favor and obviously, we have a lot of execution that needs to get done but when you look at our pipeline of people that are extending, we feel good about the occupancy growth that we can provide and just need to execute on that.

headline: Kimco Realty Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
